Super hoppy and intense herbal notes on the nose. So smooth and velvety, light caramel, juicy and spicy. Fresh herbal flavors, grassy, fresh and delicious, juicy. Gawd!

Aromas of citrusy, tropical, and piney hops, some honey. Clear golden orange with a fully lasting white head. Dry, bitter, hop-forward, but with a great nutty, honeyed malt backbone. Light-medium bodied.

Bottle courtesy of Willy J, thanks for the coast to coast same day transport. First, off... not the first to the (pun)chline here Im sure, but its more like "Piney the Elder" if you ask me. Pours super clear gold, small white head. Aroma is major pine, hop resin, grapefruit rind, sweet malt, caramel. Taste is a very sweet and delicious hop bomb. Super smooth, med body... Really beautifully executed / amazing balance.

Bottle kindly brought to the UK. Beautiful golden with a bit of a head. Incredible citrus aroma. Thankfully not sweet, instead a crisp dryness that sets it well apart from a lot of American IPAs. An ode to hops, and a beautiful one at that.

Im not sure it gets much better than This for an IPA. It just smells wonderful, I literally smelled this like 10 times before sipping. When I did sip, I was blow away. The hop characteristics are at an elite level, and the way it balances at the end with a malty sweetness is unparalleled. The reputation of this is warranted.
510ml bottle thanks to one of the cousins from the barrio. - nose is citrus and already screaming malty back bone. Smooth for the ABV. Top 50? Really. Fairly bitter.

Im a rebel, a wild child, a misfit, an anarchist without any respect for the authorities. I mean, the other day I took TWO paper towels from the paper towel dispenser at work, even though a sticker on the dispenser clearly reads "One paper towel is enough". Oh yeah. This is how it is to be living on the edge. So, when I get a 15 month old Pliny the Elder, what do I do? Do I adhere to the orders given by the label: "Consume fresh or not at all"? Oh no, not me, not this crazy bastard. I open the bottle, and I pour a glass of crystal clear, medium amber liquid, with a large, off-white head that is pretty short-lived, but the thin layer that is left is fully lasting, and here be laces. The aroma is strong and is heavy hoppy and moderate malty. Lots of overripe tropical fruits, the mango and peach are in place, also orange and orange marmalade. And to back up the hoppiness there is a wall of caramel malt. The flavour is also strong, the overripe tropical fruit basket still have contributions from the mango, but also pineapple and melon. Lots of sweet caramel, and orange marmalade and orange peel freshen things up. The taste is moderate sweet and the long finish is heavy bitter with resinous notes. Smooth and oily on the palate, mid-bodied with a soft carbonation. A wonderful beer! If this one really is that much better fresh, it must be utterly amazing!
[51 cl bottle, courtesy of Cunningham a.k.a. The Kindest Man In This Part of the Galaxy, enjoyed 15 months after bottling]

Poured from bottle into a tulip: Pours golden with a decent white head. Aroma is grapefruit, resin, and malt. Flavor is a bit malty, but is nicely balanced with the resinous hops, and a touch of citrus / grapefruit. Medium body, bitter on the back end, fairly dry finish. This is a really nice IPA but is overhyped in my opinion.

Des arômes parfaitement équilibrés de conifères, de fruits tropicaux, dorange, de miel, de caramel, de fruit de la passion et dananas.Les accents de houblons sont herbacés, résineux et sentremêlent de façon parfaite. Un profil aromatique complet et parfaitement représentatif du style.
Le visuel est doré / ambré, clair, à la mousse généreuse, de bonne densité et au maintient très long. Les traces sont bien présentes et la dentelle bien définie.
Le gustatif présente une explosion de fruits tropicaux en attaque. Les notes de mangue, dorange, dananas et de fruit de la passion introduisent à merveille une longue finale de résineux aux accents de cèdre et de pin. On y perçoit également une touche de poivre. Une texture ronde et pleine, un équilibre parfait, ainsi quune effervescence douce et bien dosée, font de cette bière un des plus beaux exemples du style.
Smell of sweet tropical fruit, appearance is clear gold with fluffy white head, taste is nice juicy fruit with a malty smoothness that kills the hoppy bitterness.

WOB Denver... Pours cloudy golden, perfect head that lingers. Aroma is fresh pine, weed, floral and fruit. First sip delicious, bitter but refreshing, awakening. Palate is clean. Great overall beer. Served in a snifter type. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a nice clear golden color with white head. Pine, grapefruit, citrus, and some spruce on the nose; follows onto the palate. Not bad, but overhyped.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2014 Keg at Russian Rivers Brewery Tap, Santa Rosa, CA. Amazing grapefruit smell with strong tropical fruits. Could smell it the second it was served to me! Taste is beautifully fruity, plenty of grapefruit, mango, tropical fruits, bit of lemon and lime with some malt. Amazing nicely balanced bitter finish. This was the highlight of my trip to Sonoma County and it did not disappoint one bit. Just incredible and the pinnacle of brewing excellence.

Instantly fills the room with its incredible smell. Pours with a beautiful golden color. First taste is so crisp with hops fruits and malts. Finishes with such a nice sweet flavor. All I can say is AMAZING

Tasted from draft. Pours a clear gold with white head. Aroma is floral, pine and resin hops. Some mild floral notes. Taste is incredibly smooth. Goes down way too easy. Nice clean bitterness balanced by a very nice malt backbone. One of the most balanced IPAs I've ever had. Pine, floral, caramel, grapefruit taste. Excellent beer. Definitely one of the best. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

if you can get your hands on it, one of the most enjoyable IPAs you could ask for. pours a slightly hazy amber with a fast-dissapearing head. nose offers balanced notes of citrus, hops, and some pine. tastes of citrus on the front end followed by a mouthful of gloriously bitter hops...which will linger till your next sip. awesome!

A: Pours a light amber hue with minimal head and thin lacing, very clean and clear

A: piney, citrusy American hop notes, but not intense. Faint biscuit aromas from the underlying malt profile

T: light bitterness up front with plenty of citrus hop flavors, grapefruit, maybe a little mango or pineapple, not as piney as I thought it would be; the beer is light without tasting watery, medium length, bitter but not too bitter finish. as it warms up, bitterness and hop flavors dissipate slightly to reveal a slightly sweet, biscuity malt profile. Overall, very easy on the palate for an imperial/double IPA.

M: overall very light, not overbearing. Smooth carbonation

O: Lives up to the hype, and at less that $6 a bottle you really cant beat it
Pliney is a benchmark IPA, clean with a crisp fermentation profile, on the bitter side, does not have the hit you in your face hop character as other popular ipas

ivorywhite head disappears with structured lacing. blonde yellow colour. aroma of grapefruit, passionfruit, hop, weed. taste like aroma with slight sweet, long bitter and rasinous finish. medium body and carbonation. very well balanced.  bottle @ cantillon quintenssence 14
Draught at Backcountry pizza. Amber color, white head. Bitter taste with floral hops, citrus, peach, resin, pine and caramel. Bitter finish with hops, peach, resin and citrus. Exquisite imperial IPA.
Wonderful IPA. Huge grapefruit with apple, apricot and light floral hints. Pours golden with good head and lacing. Finishes very bitter. Pine and mint elements here as well. Tap at monks cafe.

I try to grab one every time on the west coast. Good double IPA. Very hoppy but well balanced. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Huge thanks to Colin!!! Pours a clear gold with a white head. Aroma is lightly funky with light piss and some ripe trop fruit. Medium body, medium carbonation. Light bitter woodiness, pine, some lemon, very light caramel, leaves, a light sherbet zing... Great balance. Very tasty.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2015 On draft at Falling Rock in Denver. Clear golden color, thin white head and good lacing. Smells so great, citrus blossoms and pine forest. Taste follows suite, so smooth and well balanced. Absolutely delicious, sets the standard for Imperial IPA's!!!

Poured into a tulip glass. Color is cloudy gold, bright and beautiful. Explosion of pine, sweet freshness on the nose. Mouthfeel is pleasant. Hoppy, fresh, balanced and delicious! I'll have another one!

Liquid gold color. Strong citrus and fresh cut grass aroma. Aroma carries over into the taste. Hops most present in flavor rather than bitterness. Crisp clean finish. Not usually an IPA fan but this may start to convert me.

Found in a bottle shop in Amsterdam (Bierkoenig, two thumbs up!!!), bottled less than 1 month before. Very nice IIPA, I havent been able to find in over 5 years since trying it the first time. Pours clean and clear, great aroma. Piney and citrusy flavor with nice hoppy aftertaste. Not as bitter as I remembered but very solid beer.
The best double ipa I have had. The aroma could have been a little better. Citrus and grapefruit in the flavour and aroma. Very dry finish with just enought bitterness.

This was a great IPA, pours orangy yellown with a white head that perisists, the aroma of hops is mainly constituted of pines and citrus. It taste a bit tropical followed by loads of piny taste to be balanced with some citrus there is a bit of bitterness but it is not overwhelming, This is a great beer, hopped it wasnt as dry as it was

It really doesnt get much better than this. Then again you know this. Nose of citrus, pine, earthen notes rises from a body of golden orange. Appearances alone set this brew apart, never mind superior taste. The flavor is a perfect balancing act of heavy, caramel sweet malts, and a plethora of fresh hops. Get your hands on this when you can, a real treat.

Poured from a tall bottle into a snifter. Great piney aroma. Pours crisp clear golden with a medium thick white head. The palate feel is a little creamier than the crisp color would let on. The taste is very piney with slight citrus coming through. Sampled this with Heady Topper so that's why the rating might be lower than usual. Elder is a great IPA. Heady Topper might be the best. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I just finished my first Pliny the elder and I have to say it was hard to find, I got this one fresh as it was delivered today. First aroma was pine like hoppy notes up front with shuttle hints of citrus fruits, big head on it, as this is a double, you can definitely smell the burn on it. First taste was not as bitter as I had hoped it to be it was a more "wet" fruity taste, . As I have heard all the hype of this beer from the internet I now know it was judged by more mild pallets than those of us that enjoy imperial IPAs often. Its a great IPA for sure ...but not the best

On top at Russian River Brewery- The aroma is floral with pine notes. Pours a slightly jazzy amber with a thin, but lasting white head. The taste is much like the nose - hop forward with tropical fruit, biscuit, and a nice malty support. Medium body and medium carbonation. Crisp mouthfeel. Overall, a well crafted and drinkable Double IPA.

Bottle from Lothore, thank you very much Tyler! 

Pours a golden-amber hue, with a decent head, leaving a thin lacing. This beer smells wonderfull, as it is defined by intriguing aromas of grassy, fresh hops, along with oily pine, earthy malts and fruity papaya notes. As complex as the aromas are, the nose of this beer is very much hop centered, in a gentle, well balanced way - and I love it. As I had my first sample at the Cantillon Quintessence, I actually didnt want to drink the beer at the first moment, because I never had experienced such great aromas so far.

Almost dough, smooth beginning with oily, wooden flavors of pine, until the hops become recognizable. In an impressive way. They deliver a fantastic grassy bitterness which gets coated up by wooden malts and pleasant, warm oak. Hops define the taste of this beer, without washing away any of the supporting, complex flavors. This allows a multi-layered depth on the palate, which results in a long, dry aftertaste, as hops take over in the end. Citrus peel, kiwi and lime add crispy, fruity hints to the hop impression, altough they dont stand out too far on their own, but line up with the more present floral and herbal notes. The most pleasant thing about this Double-IPA is its perfect balance. While it is in fact very hoppy, nothing sticks out too much, nothing distracts from the unique complexity, very well done.

Yeah ok this is pretty good but knock me down 100%? Subtle for the style and abv but of course shows buckets of class and balance. Never gets above mid weight and really more classical in style than the resin-laden Cali style. Grows on you and the subtly becomes increasingly attractive.
One of my white whales! Not enough superlatives to rate this great brew. Order, sip and savor. One for the ages.

A big deal and deservedly. Tap at lucky Baldwin. Pours yellow slightly cloudy limited head lots lacing. Nose is a pine explosion. Notes of citrus, and a grapefruit and pine lunch in the face. Maybe some light cereal in the background. Taste was heavy/med bitter and light fruity sweet. Full body lively carbonation and long lasting bitterness.
Had thanks to VanS in a trade. Pours golden amber, classic IPA color. Russian River never disappoints. Aroma is strong of citrus and hops are incredible. Very refreshing IPA.
UPDATED: MAY 18, 2014 Fresh growler thanks to spencer. Nice and crisp with a good amount of hops. Always glad to drink this.
Clean, light copper pour. Has a very hoppy nose with smells of pine and citrus. Pine is more prevalent in the taste. Juicy and smooth. Delicious.

Bottle at home. Huge thanks to Mr Theydon Bois for muling this back and trading with me. Bottled only 3 weeks ago so super fresh. .

Aroma is initially citrus and tropical fruits, peach, some cat pee and some dank mustyness. Light caramel malts in the nose. 


Brilliantly clear golden orange coloured pour with a lasting white fluffy head. some lace. 


Flavour is muti-layered hops with initially resin and pine, then spicy and finishes with fresh citrus grapefruit. Malts are clean with a light sweetness and with light biscuit, providing a platform for the hops. Bitterness is assertive, citrus and grassy in nature and super clean and balanced. 


Palate is semi-sweet and somewhat chewy, but melts on the tongue nicely. Medium to high carbonation. Coats the tongue in hop resin.


Overall, I really dig the layering of the hops. The beer packs a punch, but is restrained in many ways and the end result is a very drinkable beer. I could drink this til i could not longer stand up. Really need to visit Russian River now.

Its HUGE hop aroma is so fresh/and re-freshing; smack you around,and tie you up with the hopvine aggresive.That in itself makes this a hop-heads wet dream. But it carries into the balanced body,crisp dry mouthfeel and follow through,giving it Amazing drinkability...It would always bring my palate back to neutral,after some "less worthy" brews!

Pours a golden amber color with a thin white head with medium retention. Nose is grassy, piney, light citrus, and pale malts. Taste is a perfect balance between hops and malts. One of my favorite all times, especially fresh.

Bottle. Thanks Jesse and Liz for sending this my way! Ive had this several times, its always an event when one of these is opened. Pours a clear golden amber color with lasting white head that leaves even lacing. Aroma is citrus and floral, with pine notes. Flavor is incredible: quenching sublime hoppy bitterness that makes me want more. The alcohol is completely masked, and the finish is perfect. One of my favorites. From notes January 4, 2014.

Medium amber with a full two fingers of creamy white head. The aroma initially seems breathtakingly bold, with waves of grapefruit, tangerine peel, citrus sweets and a pinch of resin. However the aroma doesnt quite live up to many of the more multi-layered symphonies that are now climbing the rating boards. The eagerly anticipated first taste reveals a silky smooth medium body with just a snippet of over carbonation. Grapefruit again rides front and centre, along with a mild floral note, citrus peel, honey and lightly toasted malts. A well balanced non fatiguing bitterness rounds of a semi dry finish, and lends this legend a fantastic sessionability.

Clear pale body with low white head. Aroma has tropical fruits, mango, pineapple, little bit grassy, the aroma is well balanced. Taste has high tropical bitterness with medium malty sweetness. Body is full, high carbonation. Not sure why this is so overhyped, its pretty average, still good, but average.
One of the best, cant thank my son enough for snagging me some when I went to San Diego. Nice in all elements a must have for craft beer enthusiasts

Bottle 23/04/14 from Joe. Cheers buddy!
Clear golden/amber color with beautiful lasting 2 finger head. Potent juicy grapefruit and sweet tangerine. A light pine in the undergrowth. Not the most bold or original of aromas but its juicy and enticing. Very nice lacing. Tight bubbles in head. Immaculate in the glass.

Medium body, dry and perfect carbonation. Sweet tangerine kisses the front palate before bitter grapefruit pith grows along with a medicinal honey flavor. Both carry into the bitterness which is medium and lasting. Caramel malt balances the beer beautifully, showcasing the hops but restraining their dominance. Also some faint pine resin. Incredibly drinkable and juicy. 

Dont expect extraordinary, eccentric taste or flavor. In fact its pretty generic...but still very enjoyable. Its redemption lies in its exemplary execution of the fundamentals - balance, aesthetics, carbonation and drinkability. A top DIPA.

Overall a really good beer - not so much for the taste, but for the superior quality of all its other parts. Good balance and character. Slightly saddened that it didnt blow my mind as unrealistically as I had hoped, but happy to be able to say I hunted it down and had a taste.

Bottled 4-23-14. This is quite the amazing brew. The appearance is perfect, Crystal clear with a frothy white head and tight bubbles. Aroma is the epitomy of a west coast ipa, very bright citrus and pine and bursting with hops. Taste is awesome! Onslaught of hop bitterness up front, followed by a super flavorful hop profile. Big citrus, pine, and astringent notes followed by a perfect malt backbone. I get a perfect balance of sweetness in the middle and an absolute superb mouth feel. Creamy, sweet, and juicy hops makes this mind blowing good. Finishes nice and dry, with lingering hops in your mouth and leaving you begging for more. Overall, extremely drinkable and the best west coast style ipa I have had to date.
Bottle from a trade, probably a month old. Great pine and citrus smell. Nice head and clear amber colour in the glass. Really enjoyed this, it deserves the following it has.
Sampled at DLD 2014. It poured a clear golden color with a small white head. The aroma was of citrusy grapefruit and some pine. The taste was of citrus, pine and hops. Very nice!

Bottle. Pours golden yellow with mild haze and with thin white head that lingers. Medium hop aroma over mild carbonation. Lemony sweet hop flavor with moderate complexity. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2014 Finally got to try this one. Poured by none other than Vinnie Cilurzo @ Cantillon Quintessence 2014. #10 Russian River beer. 500 ml. bottle sampled. Should be about 2 months old. Pours a hazy orange with a creamy white head. Looks lovely. Nose is incredible, full of very creamy grapefruit, pine, citrus fruit, very fruity with sweet toffee and sweet resin, very tropical, nose is absolutely stellar. Taste is quite bland afterwards sadly, creamy oily & bit bland pine resin, touch salty caramel, brown sugar, pine seeds, sweet resin, caramel, oily, sugary, very oily body. There is nothing wrong with it other than the fact that it didnt live up to the incredible nose. While I respect it for what it is, so many DIPAs are so far beyond this one, this days, come from them, this one didnt surprise me in the least to be honest.
2014.04 - Cantillon Quintessence 2014 - neus : tropisch fruit, gemaaid gras, kruidig - mond : pompelmoes, zacht, lichtbitter

3 day old bottle. Have had Pliny several times now and each time I get a chance to enjoy another, it always reminds me of the first! Such a great and consistent beer. Not sure I can add anything that hasnt been said already. Has a great appearance, very bright. Great aroma of citrus and pine. A balanced flavor, a "classic" flavor. Nice bitterness and a dry finish. Wonderful bouquet of a beer.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2016 Bottle to snifter. Bottle date about 5 week earlier. Even though it wasnt super fresh, it was extremely tasty. Pour was a nice gold, mostly clear, but a bit of haze. Decent head with lacing down glass. Aroma was mildly dank with citrus notes with grapefruit standing out the most. Some sweet malts present. Taste had more citrus burst, with a good amount of bitter present. Small hints of alcohol toward the end. It took me a while to try one of these, but I understand the hype now. Outstanding beer.
Still searching for a "fresh" Pliny. Had two that were about a month old each. While I still think they have been great. I just can't say it has been the best IPA I've ever had yet.
hoppy malty well balanced. notes of citrus peel were obvious. a very nice texture.

Drank on 3/30/2014 Poured from a bottle into a Prairie Teku glass -- Amazingly clear golden yellow with sticky bubbles clinging to the sides of the glass. Aroma is very strong citrus, smells like truth and justice. Taste is a little less zesty from the hops, a little lemon and lime, bitterness is the prominent flavor. This beer is really well done, fizzy in all the right places and firm in the same. I would love to get my hand on an endless supply.

A crystal clear light amber beer with a fluffy white head, with amazing lace clinging to the glass.
Strong citrus and pine aromas, juicy tropical fruits, bubblegum and honey like malts.
The flavour is so smooth and balanced, big juicy grapefruit and lemon zest, passion fruit and sultana. Razor sharp pine resins and honey on toast like malts. Amazing hop bitterness balances so well with the sweet malt backbone.
The finish is citrusy and bitter, leaves a nice sweet honey like coating which the bitterness just cuts through. An amazing example of an IPA.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Monks Cafe, Philadelphia. Definitely one of the best IPAs Ive ever had. Piney aroma and taste - thats what Im looking for in IPAs. Very ballanced and extremally drinkable. Full bodied. Almost a perfect IPA.

A - 5 - amber golden clear color with nice white head that sticks throughout and leaves a nice lace on the glass
Aroma - 10/10 - super dank, hardcore garlic/pine/grapefruit with nice bready malts in the background.
Taste - 10/10 - again, very dank, citrusy beer with garlic/ pine/grapefruit/orange/mango/papaya flavors. A flavor from the sugar that I can always taste in beers they use corn sugar in... its there, but its OK and it is what it is.
Palate - 5/5 - light-medium, alc covered, aftertaste is garlic/citrus/ grapefruit flavors.
0 - 20/20 - what can be said about an ipa this classic and legendary? People seek it out because of its reputation, and it deserves it.

On tap at the brewery. Golden, white frothy head. Peach, grapefruit, lemon, pineapple, hop, some pine, hint of alcohol. Medium bitter. Some sweetness. A tiny bit over medium body. Medium carbonation - quite small bubbles. Closer to an IPA in my opinion and super good! Cheers to Peter, Olivia and Heidi for an incredible day in Napa and Sonoma.

Aroma is amazing. Citrus and pine hits your nose with an overwhelming feeling. My mouth started watering as soon as I smelled it. The appearance is a golden yellow with a thin white head. Nice and clear. Taste is of citrus...grapefruit. Nice taste for an IPA. Palate is smooth when you first drink it. Light body with a thin texture and bitter finish. Overall, this is a great beer and I would definitely drink more of it!
Bottle - pours a deep gold . Huge resinous pine aromas . Taste is well balance bitter vs sweet . Smooth palate . Very tasty .

Great dIPA.
Pours clear and pale, with a nice head.
The aroma is amazing. Super fresh citrus and pine notes.
The taste is super refreshing and hoppy. It is really well balanced, and you dont get the 8% ABV at all!

UPDATED: APR 19, 2014 Finally had Pliny....and couldn?t help doing a side by side with Heady Topper. Pliny is an excellent beer. Pours out a light orange and crystal clear. Smells of pine and citrus. Taste follows the nose and finishes quickly. Very balanced for a DIPA, doesnt kick you in the face and strip the enamel off your teeth. There are plenty of other beers that compete with Pliny.

Bottle thanks to my landlord Frank! About a month after bottle date. Poured clear golden orange with thick creme head. Pleasant aroma of pine citrus. Light tingly carb med bod. Smooth balanced hop that drinks well. Hidden for the ABV.
Bottle from San Diego sister. Pours golden with nice white head. Nose is citrus, pine, oranges, and melon. Taste is sweet and hops. Great!
Nice golden pour...very clear..floral and slightly piney aroma, citrus and hoppy, with a slight grapefruit flavor. Nice and balanced DIPA
Very fine beer. Highly hoppy, but still nicely balanced. Golden coloured, thin head which lasts a while. Just fizzy enough.
The best! What can I say about this beer that hasnt already been said. Just give a smell if youve never had one, you will not be disappointed.
On tap at Russian River Brewing. Best balanced DIPA ive had, Surly Abrasive is up there with it. Perfect blend of hops & malt.

Poured a hazy golden color with a small, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of floral hops, sweet tangerine, and caramel malts. Taste of sweet, chewy caramel, toffee malts, grapefruit, with a very bitter hop finish, and alcohol as well.

4/5/14. Traded for this with a couple BCBS. Drank after eating @ Isabelbyob Was dying to try it after getting home. Very good beer that is really easy to drink. Great color great taste great stone. Glad to have finally tried Pliny but there are other IPAs just as good

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a bright orange with a medium head that dissipates. Aroma is a lot of citrus, pine and hops. Taste is crisp and refreshing with a citrus forward character with a balanced hop middle and a pine/citrus finish that lingers. Mouthfeel is smooth. Palate is supremely well balanced with the citrus/pine playing nicely off of the hops.

Definitely a great IPA! Very very similar to many others in a crowded field. For historical value and rareness on the east coast, I get it! That being said it simply is not amongst my top 7-10. There definitely are IPAs more readily available, that imo are more enjoyable like... Another One, Head Hunter, Sculpin and Lunch to name a few. Still just about lives up to the hype, and should be sampled by all IPA lovers. Very, very good stuff. Kind of in the bells two hearted level ... imo really good, but just a tick over hyped!

Easy drinking for a DIPA with a wonderful mouthfeel. Great complex flavor. piny, floral with a complex citrus aftertaste. Hints of peach, mango and grapefruit. Almost worthy of the hype, this beer is excellent.

Random extra from BOLTZ7555 incredibly thankful to try this! the aroma is a potent pine and citrus, the Taste is incredibly powerful strong pine notes with a slight citrus feel. incredibly tasty and gives an almost mouth numbing aftertaste that is awesome. and with all the things going on in this beer there almost no detection of alcohol

After searching for what seemed to be eons, I finally got to try Pliny the Elder at Monks cafe in Center City Philadelphia. 

The pour was very light, lighter than Amber almost like a wheat beer. 

The aroma, lots of hops, coffee ish flavors but nothing extra ordinary. 

The taste, this was the biggest disappointment of all. I did like the beer, don't get me wrong but I thought it was just a tad too monotonous. Maybe I've been waiting too long and the weight of the expectations is what crushed it for me. I personally love dogfish head 129 minutes. This beer felt like a lighter version of it, which is a-ok in my book.

Overall, in isolation I don't know if I would call it the best beer in the world(or the 2nd best) but it is a solid beer and delivered on the promise. I don't have any qualms about trying it and would happily spend the $10 for more over and over again.

Tap. Pours clear orange with thin white head that lasts and laces. Smells of pine and resin predominately with undertones of citrus and floral. Drinks with moderate to heavy hop bite and moderate lingering bitterness. Medium to full bodied. Tastes of pine and citrus predominately, balanced well by the malt bill. Silky mouthfeel. Finishes with lingering pine flavors.

Poured from bomber bottle bought at the brewery

Aroma - Citrus and Pine. Clean malt. Hint of caramel. 

Appearance - Crystal clear orange. Thin white head. Good retention. Great lacing on the glass. 

Taste - Very clean. Citrus and pine hops forward. Slight malt backbone. Incredibly clean. Good bitterness that never gets harsh. 

Overall - fantastic beer. Incredibly well made. Dangerously drinkable.

Overall: Fresh, citric, piney, grape-fruity. Lovely.Note: On-tap at Toronado. Reviewed 2014-03-22.
Overall a good beer. I am not an IPA fan but still find this beer a good choice when on tap at a bar.
smooth smell and taste. not much appearance in the glass, could be anything. even on tongue with excellent finish. Not as strong as some other IPAs in the style. But oh so satisfying.
tap at Stone. Deep golden with small head. Huge bright crisp hops with both citrus and pine elements. Enormously delicious. Very smooth.

Smooth, almost too smooth. Just as good as everyone says. Yes, hard to find, dont worry, missing it wont change your life, its just a really great beer. If you like beer with a kick, this one is nice, and could be handled on a warm day, unlike a boozy-er tasting IPA.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2014 Enjoyed on tap at Mohawk Bend in Los Angeles, CA. I went searching for this for quite a while and it was a goal to find on my west coast trip. Overall this is like a hoppy Gumballhead (3 Floyds brew) that finishes equal parts dry and bitter. Really is a great DIPA, happy to have had it.

This was my first Pliny. Definitely lives up to its rep. Maybe the smoothest bodied IPA Ive encountered. Aroma is incredibly balanced and full of flavor- pine, citrus, malt and sweet layers. Incredibly clean. Delicious and memorable. I cannot wait to have another.
Pours a hazy golden color. Aroma is a pleasant combination of caramel malt and pine. Taste is very similar. Finishes in the dry side. Very good beer

Purchased from Whole Foods of all places. Smells very Piney with underlying grapefruit tones. Pours a clear golden with a foamy white head. Taste hoppy, hides the abv well. Piny with some fruit notes kinda like most any other IPA that comes out today, but does nicely have more of a roasted malt backbone. Finishes dry, this is a good beer but nothing out of this world, at least anymore.

2014.03.14 - Russian River Pliny the Elder - 510ml bottle, from the bottle (hey, I'm in the middle of nowhere by Sequoia National Park in CA with no glassware). Finally got a few bottles of this and get to try it out.

Pour: no notes, drinking from the bottle. Considerable head and carbonation visible in bottle.

Aroma: fruity, pineapple, mango... Maybe some hops but not much relatively.

Taste: follows nose. Fruity, maybe a bit more like grapefruit in the mouth. Followed by and in good balance with hops and pine.

Mouthfeel is overall pretty light. Foamy, mild carbonation.

Overall: it's in the Bell's Hopslam neighborhood of Double/Imperial IPA; hoppy but balanced with fruitiness/citrus. To my taste, Hopslam seems more pineapple and honey notes, Pliny seems more grapefruit and mango-ish notes. It's a nice brew. I'd rate it higher, I'm just not a big IPA fan.


Aroma: 7/10, Appearance: 3/5, Taste: 8/10, Palate: 3/5, Overall: 18/20.
UPDATED: OCT 29, 2014 Still Amazing. Smuggled a few bottles back to swissland. Not much to say about this that has not already been said. Sooo good
Smooth for an IPA. It bites less as it warms up. Mild citrus flavor goes a long way to enhance the flavor of the hops.

c/o JSW (Bottled on Feb 13, 2014)

Aroma - caramel malt, resiny, citrus hops, floral hops, sweet fruits
Appearance - golden amber body; liquid is just slightest of haze; the head is about 1" and off-white, it settles into a ring with foam on the top.
Taste - combination of West Coast, floral hops, resin hops, and citrus (pineapple, grapefruit, and lemon)
Body - body is medium; texture approaching oily, but not oily; carbonation average; finish long and hoppy on the top of the tongue

Pours relatively clear golden with wispy head. Nose is pineapple, tropical fruit, pine resin, floral hops. Taste is sweet and fruity, with pineapple, mango, tropical fruit, hops, then pine bitterness at the end, not nearly as much as I was expecting. Moderate mouthfeel. This beer completely lives up to the hype. So good.

Lives up. As advertised. Delicious. Had at a bar on Long Beach CA. But does not exist in AZ. Let's get it out here! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

American double / Imperial IPA 
8% ABV
100 IBU

APPEARANCE: Pours a bright, vibrant golden hue. Seems to glow or burn like fire dancing with orange highlights. Dense, billowy three fingers of head with great lacing. 

AROMA: Did I just snort a line of hops? In your face hops, intense pine and resin. Very dank and earthy that starts to give way to a fruit bomb of grapefruit, mango, papaya and citrus. End with light floral and grassy notes. 

TASTE: like tiny angels dancing on my tongue! First taste is that hoppy bitterness that takes over your mouth. Once you get used to it the layers of sweetness from the fruit really shine. Light lemon grass and floral hits with that great bitterness remaining throughout. 

MOUTHFEEL: Medium body with lively carbonation. Coats the entire mouth allowing the complex layers to really come out. Finished perfectly dry with nice lingering bitterness. 

OVERALL: This is the IPA I hold all others up against. For me and my pallet it's perfect. I 100% understand the hype behind this beer. From popping the bottle to the last sip out of my glass it never disappoints. 

RATING: 5/5 Zombie Heads!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From tap at Toranado in SF. Great beer but expected a little better. A smooth piney, citrusy IPA gold in color.

On tap at Choice City Butcher. Appearance: two fingers white head, golden color, clear. Aroma: floral, orange, very light caramel. Palate: light to medium body, average carbonation, sticky texture, slight dry finish. Taste: light floral sweetness to great bitterness that lasts. Bottle shared thanks to Kraddel. Pours golden with white foam. Aroma is exotic fruits. First taste little fruitiness, medium bitterness. Aftertaste more fruity.

Smells and tastes like heaven. Pine, citrus, and fruit on the nose and palate. So smooth. So good. Best beer Ive had to date.

Poured from bottle to glass. Golden honey hue with nice white head. Aroma citrus, pine, oranges, ripe limes, melon, sugar. Mouthfeel is nice with a medium body and good carbonation. Taste is sweet initially with a nicely balanced hop following and a nice CO2 sharpness in the finish. Overall this is a great IPA...better than Younger in my opinion.
On tap at Rose&Crown. Aromas of caramel, flowers, liquorice. Long taste, well balanced.

Dont get me wrong, its a superb beer...I just dont think its worth the hype it receives, which I believe is due in large part to its limited releases. I personally think Stone Enjoy By is an all around better crafted double.

BFF from Palm Desert got this.....best beer EvEr. Chicks its pure cut grass an grapefruit with a ting of heat. This makes your legs weak fir a week. Cant find this sh&t wonderful made Bach party spendicious. Drink this one last as it will destroy your tadtbuds....bucket list. The younger....

Draught @ Monks: My first impression was "what is all the fuss about?" So I asked our waitress if I had gotten the correct beer. She brought me another. As soon as I saw it we realized the first one was the wrong beer. They have Damnation on tap as well and mistakenly given me one of those. The Elder pours a darker golden color with about a finger of off white foam. It didnt linger long but did leave a little lacing. The nose was huge! Lots of grapefruit and pine notes. Hard to smell the malts, but can faintly pick some up. The taste is excellent! Hops are not overpowering. Big malt body. Extremely well balanced. An extremely good beer.

From notes, consumed on 5/23/13. Bottle (dated 4/17/13) poured into a tulip. Pours a golden yellow with 3 fingers of quick fading off-white head. Good sticky lacing. Aromas of pine/resin, grapefruit, light caramel, tropical fruit. Tasting notes of grapefruit, juicy citrus, pine/resin, biscuit, caramel. Big semi-dry bitter hop finish with a medium body. Good carbonation.
Growler from RR, about 2,5 weeks old. Golden with white head. Aroma massive, of pine, resin, caramel and ripe fruit. Taste is medium sweet, resin, pine and caramel. Big hype and decent beer

Not an introductory beer for the IPA style but definitely the one of the best foe the experienced beer taster. one of my favorite in its style. the hoppy bitterness is well balanced by a full body and a matching abv level. 
amazing aroma.

A double IPA for a fortnight and a day #15...best for last.....pine citrus grapefruit nose absolutely fantastic....falvor is great with grassy crisp fresh hops...finish is perfectly clean...wanting more...and more is better.

Growler fill at the brewery, thanks brenn79. Clear gold pour with a lacy white head. Strong grapefruit nose, pine. Delicious. The problem with comparing this from a growler at the hotel to the 10 oz pour of Pliny the Younger at the brewery is due to a number of reasons. Most of all, it was pretty hard to rate in the crowded brewery. I think if I was able to concentrate better, I could have given it a better review, and maybe the Younger would have gotten a better score than the Elder. Both are fantastic, for sure.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2014 Growler from the brewery- pours clear golden with small white head that sustains. Aroma is dank citrusy grapefruit, pine. Taste is citrus and pine, nice and hoppy. Had younger just earlier today and for the true hophead
it is better, but this is extremely awesome!
Great beer. Good citrus hoppy flavor without the typical IPA bitterness. Maintains good smooth flavor throughout.

Bottle from @VanS. Thanks dude! Pours a clear golden copper color. Huge aroma of fresh piney hops. Taste is smooth up front with tons of fresh hop flavor. Finishes really clean. Glad I got to try this. Great stuff.

This was one of the best hoppy beers I have had a chance to taste and I would wish I could have access to alot more as it does not makes its way up here.I had it at Green Dragon in Portland...a few years ago.

Very good, but not in the same league as heady topper. Not worth going way out of your way for a cross continental beer trade.

Pours gold with a white head. Huge pine smells with citrus hops. Taste is tropical fruits and also a lot of pine. Only drawback is the funky pine smell you get when you smell it once in a while. Other than that, a perfect beer.
10 East got a few bottles. "Pliney" rhymes with "piney," which is what this beer smells a lot like.

Worthy of the hype. I drive to Santa Rosa to drink this beer fresh at least monthly. It is an outstanding, probably the best example of a West Coast IPA. Very hoppy with citrus and pine flavors, but well balanced with malt on the finish. There a lot of super hopped-yp IPAs out there, but few have the balance and drinkability as a Pliny.
Thans bursprak! Golden colour, white foam. Very fruity and hoppy aroma. Loads of hops. Very easy drinkable. Very good!

From a bottle, that was bottled five days ago. Incredibly clear much like Firestone Walker Union Jack. Aroma is amazing so clean and a blend of citrus and pine. Taste brings forth tremendous balance for such hoppy beer. It is a great mouth feel of sweet malt layered with complex hops. So enjoyable.

Russian river believes in very dry IPAs and this is no departure from that. The lack of sweetness and body really allows the hops to shine. Overall a very nice imperial IPA.

Pours a beautiful golden color. Aroma is sweet citrus and grape fruit. Taste is very interesting. Sweet malt upfront followed by a grapefruit bitterness. Full body medium carbonation.

Citrus hits the nose right away, along with some spicy piney notes and a little dank as well. Taste is...perfect. Bitter and citrusy taste right away, slightly sweet, and a hoppy and bitter note throughout that compliments the rest of the flavors. Smooth, dry, and so pleasant to drink. Shared 510 ml bottle. Color is light bronze with a beautiful frothy offwhite head. The aroma is out of this world. Incredible hoppiness with pineapple, gooseberry, peaches and elderflower. Taste is not as nice as the nose but still very good. Sweet, exotic fruit with a slightly bitter finish.
On tap at Falling Rock in Denver. Awesome aroma and just an excellent DIPA, but a little overhyped. 90 min and Hopslam have it beat in my opinion.

Flaske, 50 cl, hjembragt af Martin. Tappet den 10-1-2014. Klar og gylden, med et stort frodigt, luftigt hvidt skum. Utrolig indbydende humlenæse. Stikkelsbær. Mynte. Solbær. Fersken. Grapefrugt. Pomelo. Velafstemt malt med en god karamelnote, ikke for sød, ikke for tør, men i perfekt balance med malten. Meget høj drinkabillity ifht en abv på 8. Det er dog aromaen, der for alvor bærer denne frugtige DIPA.

Bottle cheers to jonnyguns. Pours golden orange with a delicate khaki head. Huge tropical fruit and pine aroma, backed up with a solid caramel malt profile, smells amazingly well balanced. First flavours on the tongue are lots of delicate citrus flavours, mixed with some pine and resin. Then caramel malts come into play with some sweet biscuit flavours. The mouthfeel is what makes this beer - chewy but dangerously quaffable. Fucking phenomenal beer, hit expectations on the head.

The best. Balanced with just the right piney hops and bitterness. Golden with white head.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Much thanks to my friend A Wickstrom for getting a bottle out my way. Bottled 12/31/13. Pours a clean copper gold with a nice frothy white head. Aroma is green pine needles lightly spritzed with ruby grapefruit juice. Flavor is citrus with a subtle malt backbone. The balance in this is exquisite. A little bit of floral spice, lightly sweet, a solid bitterness and with a drier finish than most IPAs. I can see why there is so much hype surrounding this, it is quite excellent.

(backlog ZBF 04/2013) Fresh bottle from the source kindly shared by BA-Mitch, unfairly competing with Camba Bavaria IPA. I believe the key ingredient in this DIPAs success is the balance it strikes between supporting pine bitterness, fairly light and crisp pale malts and a cornucopia of citrus (pink grapefruit) and whiffs of pineapple sitting on top of that. Drier than most juicy DIPAs of this calibre. Whilst West Coast C-hops in themselves by now have nothing left to prove, this beer has a lot to teach lesser US hopmonsters in terms of sheer modesty and restraint, the true seal of craftmanship, making this a paragon of its genre that could represent US DIPAs far more gracefully on this side of the Atlantic than some of the more readily available ones.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2014 Russian River Company. Do I need to say anything more??? Top Notch and unbelievable stuff! I relished my Pliny and brought it all the way back from Portland OR to Midwest and almost didn't drink it BUT you don't sit one something so fresh like the Pliny! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
One of the top beers I have had. It is worthy of all of its praise. Wonderful balance of hops.

Bottled 17 days ago, poured into a snifter

A: Golden beer with an inch and a half of white head that settles to a foam.

S: Floral, piney, and citrusy, there is also an air of freshness to the nose of this beer.

M: The feel is crisp and clean. For a double ipa, this beer has a surprisingly light body to it.

T: The taste is citrusy, grapefruity, piney, hoppy, but not overtly hoppy. There is almost no bite on the back end, however you can slightly taste the alcohol, but not in an unappealing way. At first the hops overwhelm your senses, but after your sip you are left refreshed desiring to taste more.

O: This beer is incredible, and makes me ponder moving to into its distribution area, well maybe not entirely. This is my first time trying this beer thanks to a trade I made earlier this week. This beer is crisp and flavorful. The hops in this beer work so well together. Makes me glad I have another on the way next week!

Serving type: bottle

FRANÇAIS

Flavor is Mandarin orange, medium-heavy bitterness bu clean and does not linger. Nectar. Sweet, light, moderate-intensity caramel. Body is medium-heavy, somewhat syrupy, blanket of moderate carbonation, light prickliness. This was part of my summer quest in 2013 - I first found the elder on tap at an Italian restaurant in Sonoma ... it did not disappoint. One of the best in class by far due to its balance.
What can I say that no one else has said? Im just glad I broke my Pliny cherry. Btw, there was no hint of cherry in this beer.

Blind tasting between this and Heady. Heady wins. No contest. This was clear gold to amber in color, little white head, nose of pine and grapefruit, taste was similar with a little floral finish which was excellent. The hype has brought this one over the top a little Im afraid.

Its Pliny. What else is there to say? An IPA at its finest. Well balanced and wonderful to drink

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2013 Bottled 12.12.13. Bottle 1 (12/29): A pleasant pine and citrus peel IPA that holds up to the Christmas spirit.

Bottle 2 (12/31): Drinking side-by-side with Drakes Denogginizer (99 rb score)  for comparison. Wow... getting a lot of hemp / marijuana on the nose. Maybe this is why everyone loves this beer so much? Also, great carbonation.

Although it is a bit overrated, this is still a world class IPA. Grapefruit, huge floral hops in the nose. Its indeed very piney. Not very malty either. Its mostly a big, aromatic, west coast IPA. Last batch I had is also quite sweet, which I found slightly strange. Not overly bitter either. Delicious stuff, if a bit overhyped. I think Blind Pig is their best IPA.
Standard example of an excellent double IPAA very grassy very rich very piney excellent all around the piney and extremely bitter excellent brew.

Huge thanks to Bytemesis for the awesome Christmas gift!!! Across the board fantastic!

Bottled 1/12/11
Poured to duvel tulip. 

A: golden corn colored ale with single finger head. This dissipates to spiderweb egg shell white foam. Consistent bubbling from bottom. 

S: pine, resin, citrus, cotton candy. You know, all the different things u can get from a hop. Nice. A bit sweet. 

T: bitter malty and big. Quite nice. Pines, resins. 

M: smooth, lively. Not bad. 

D: very very drinkable. I cant say this is the best impy ipa. Theres a ton of discussion about how fresh to drink an ipa. I cant day this is the freshest, but a month out is not old by any means. An being continually refrigerated, the beer didnt lose that much beta acid.

Serving type: bottle

02-19-2011

12 oz bottle 2 weeks past bottling date...poured holden clear with 2 fingers light tan head and sticky lacing. Mild carbonation. Nose is citrus and floral hops. Taste is citrus fruity hops with a slightly bitter piney hops finish.

The beer pours an oranging yellow with amber highlights, kind of like a sunrise The beer forms a big, pillowy head of rocky white bubbles that are slightly off-white. The head lasts nicely, but does mellow down from its initial height to about a half-fingers width. As the head dissipates, it leaves a nice sticky patchwork of lacing on the glass. In body the beer is crystal clear and clean, but does present a slight haze from the malt. On the nose, the beer smells of citrus and spicy pine. Floral and herbal notes dance around the edges of the nose but big citrus tangerine and grapefruit are the primary players in the beer. The nose is not blowing me away, but is just a very solid example of a hoppy beer dank pine and a touch of sweet caramel can also be sensed in the smell. As a whole, the smell tends to remind a little of a fresh pineapple blended with pine. On the tongue, the beer tastes surprisingly balanced. The bitters are big and coat the mouth, but there is a strong bready sweetness to add balance. Light stone fruit notes can be picked out in the hop character, as well. The finish sees the strongest bitter kick, which is a bit over powering and should feed any ones bitter cravings. Acidity in the beer is light but bright on the sides of the cheeks. Again, this beer tastes like a classic DIPA. In flavor, the beer begins as sweet, candied citrus, expanding into fresh Florida oranges, with a touch of orange peel and rind. Grapefruit, pine needles, and pineapple dance in the back along with the malts superbly balanced sweet caramel bread, which helps to give the hops their candied quality. I wasnt that taken with this beer on the initial sip, but that was foolish of me. Pliny is a subtle beast, building simple complexity from its hops, and making each sip different. Soft boozy heat can be felt in the back of the throat, but that is just another part of the complexity of this beer. This flavor is one I could sip all night. In the mouth, Pliny feels surprisingly on the light side of medium in body, with a fluffy carbonation that pillows the tongue nicely. Mouthfeel is slick, and crisp, making the beer dangerously easy to drink. Slight astringency can be felt as the beer moves across the tongue leaving the mouth only softly tingling with bitters. Saliva does gently pool in the cheeks, but overall the mouth is left rather clean and ready for further sips. Overall, this beer is a whale worthy of whaling after. Beautiful complexity and subtly make this a beer I could drink several of, which is dangerous for its ABV bracket. Where many of the modern DIPAs slam you in the face with juicy hop character, Pliny is subtle and perfectly balanced. This will please the hop heads and even those that are skeptical to hops. My mother, a diehard stout fan, but pale and hoppy beer hater, actually loved this when I brought one over last night. My only complaint is that the nose is mild compared to some DIPAs, but to be fair to Pliny, its recipe was developed before the designers of those other DIPAs even knew they liked hops. Pliny the Elder is a pleasure to drink. I cant wait to get my hands on more Russian River beers.

Pours a somewhat hazy golden color and leaves the same color body with a one and a half finger white foamy head that dissipates within less than a minute, carbonation is seen rising, light lacing is left in the wake but not that much as I thought I would have seen; the aroma has a combined citrus and piney hops up front and very powerful that it lasts through the entire drink, however, there are some malts that do come through ever so lightly as it warms; the flavoring is mainly bitter but has a light citrus sweetness comes through in the malts, strong bitter citrus/pine aftertaste, super dry finish; its somewhat easy on the palate or as much as a DIPA can be and assaults the palate as a superior DIPA should; overall, a superior DIPA that I would very much have again if available, but I got this in a trade and wouldnt mind having it again

had at Russian river Sept 2013. draft destroys btl. amber haze. nose is a amazing balance of citrus and pine. exactly what a American DIIPA should be. flavor is the perfect follow through. malt is there but cannot do anything but assist this praise of the hop...
UPDATED: DEC 23, 2013 Im not an ipa fan, which means this is a very high rating. Delicious sharp bitter aroma. Smooth drink and impressively the head lasts to the last drop.
OMG! This beer lives up to its billing! Color, flavor, aroma and palate embody hoppiness without killing your tastebuds.
Wonderful aroma of hops and citrus, light caramel colour, with a great head nice lacing. Complex taste of citrus, caramel and slightly bitter. A bitter sweet palate that lingers.

Second rating in July 2015: Well, yup. This is still awesome, but not perfect. Ill have to retract the 5.0 though and revise to 9/5/10/5/18 = 4.7, which still makes it my current best on Ratebeer.
Hop goodness what more can you say, if fresh one of the top 5 IPAs. Wish I could drink this every day but hard to get my hands on especially since I have moved.

A little thin on the tongue but the bitterness does not build up. A fading head but remains thin. Not thick on tongue. Very nice and perfect hop flavor. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Nice citrus aroma. Light lacing and pale straw color. smooth drinking with minimial stickiness. Hate to do it but it resembles Maine Lunch (or the other way around). love it. received from a r/beertrade from LA.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2013 510ml bottle. Bottled on Oct. 28, 2013. Consumed Nov. 9, 2013. Pours a clear orange/yellow colour with a thin, white head. 
Aroma is big tropical fruits. Pineapple, grapefruit, pine, and resin.
Taste is a big bitter with a fruity, piny aftertaste. Slight breadyness. Really really great.
Medium body with a low-medium carbonation. Lighter in the mouth with a  resiny texture and a slightly dry finish.
Overall a really great beer and well worth finding.
UPDATED: JUN 16, 2015 poured into a beer mug from bottle. nice golden pour with white log lasting head and lacing. Nice fruit hop aroma. A very good IPA

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2017 Re rating this beer. Aroma is boozy and some hopps. Flavor is pretty hoppy, light citrus l, and bitter.  Pours gold with a white heated. East coast style is much better now that I have experienced more iPas.
Draft at Bainbridge St. Barrel House. This stuff is amazing. Great aroma and goes down so smooth. Sure wish I could get some sooner than every few months, but at least it does come here.

Had at GABF 2013 and many times before. Litmus test for the double IPA. Big resinous citrus pine hops. Clear great carbonation t bring out hop profiles. I really cant say what others have not already said.

Amber with a thin off-white crown. Aroma is floral and vegetal with some moderate malt underneath. Taste is floral and vegetal as well with a decent malt backbone and moderate bitterness. While its not bad a little underwhelmed given the hype.

Aroma - Floral, Resin, alcohol, citrus
Appearance - Gold, clear, white head
Taste - grapefruit, citrus, sweet but not overly so...crisp
Palate - light body with a thinner texture. Average carbonation
Overall - Wonderful

Compairing a newer pliny to an older pliny.

Bottle Date: 9/19/12
A: Golden Straw Hue, Passes Most Light, White Head, Some Lacing
S: Grapefruit, Piney, Mild Grainy Malt
T: Piney, Grapefruit, Grainy Malts
M: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Bitter
Overall, a really great IPA with some really nice malt character and hoppiness.

Bottle Date: 10/4/11
A: Golden Straw/Orangish Hue, Passes Most Light, White Head, Some Lacing
S: Semi Grainy Malts
T: Semi Grainy Malts
M: Decent Carbonation, Light to Medium Bodied, Mildly Sweet
Overall, definitely an absence of hops...the hue was definitely darker and the malt character much more prominent.

Like the bottle say...Dont Age Your Pliny!

Bottle from City Beer Store, San Francisco - a (much cherished) present from my girlfriend. Pours an amber gold, with a lovely lasting white bubbly head. Aroma is huge and interesting - lots of citrus, grapefruit, spicy and floral hop notes, with equally prominent caramel and biscuit aromas, and a more bizarre but intriguing hint of marshmallow. Taste is the absolutely perfect blend of malty sweetness and hoppy bitterness, with a lightly spicy undertone and the vaguest of hints of seaside and salt. Dry and balanced bitter finish that lasts and lasts and lasts - it still stuck on my palate an hour later. Smooth and even carbonation. Almost as good as beer gets, to be honest. I wish I could get my hands on this more often.

My second Pliny, but first since 2009 and first full review. This bottle is courtesy of Eduardo.
Pliny looks amazing. A perfect yellow/amber/pale orange color with half an inch of white bubbly head. It has fantastic lacing as well. Sticky globules that hang onto the sides of the tulip. Aroma is wonderful too. Very floral and sweet. I love the hop balance. Lots of orange scents, with maybe a touch of lemon zest. Very floral, reminds me of this tiny yellow flower that grows here in FL. It also has the faintest hint of pine, which I normally dont like, but seems to be done really well in this beer. But where this beer shines is really in the taste. It reminds me of Six Points Bengali Tiger. Well balanced, hoppy/sweet combo and delicious. Pliny somehow takes this all up a notch! Everything I get from the nose, is doubled on my tongue, and in the best of ways. There is also the slightest of biscuity flavor too. Mouthfeel is simple, bubbly, very lightly creamy, and the hops do not attack my taste buds. I love this about Pliny. Most IPAs will sting your tongue with the aggressive hops. Also, this beer hides the 8% ABV extremely well; not as well as Compass from ST, but very very well. It drinks like a great single IPA.

Bottle. Decently fresh. Nose full if pine and trees. Slightly minty. Much citrus too. Very multidimensional. Very clear orange. Large white head. Taste is like orange with a touch of lemon. Moderate residual sweetness. Solid. Would prefer it a touch drier. Otherwise great b
Aroma is funky and dope, piney and hoppy. Flavor is hoppy and fresh, with a pleasantly bitter finish. Super well balanced, really tasty beer

FROM NOTES: July 1, 12
Poured into a RR pint glass at the Russian River Pub. Fairly amazing beer. Even with all of the hype, it did not disappoint. The epitome of what I like to call the California Hop-Nazi style. It is a quintessential DIPA. Lots of full hoppy, citrusy aroma and flavor. It had a big enough malt backbone to balance out the hop ridiculous character. It was crisp, dry, refreshing, and addictive. I had several on tap at Russian River while waiting for the 2012 Tour of California finish, including having to slam one in an effort to race over to the finish line. I do NOT recommend disrespecting this beer, or your stomach, by slamming it down. While I generally prefer beers with less hops, I was stunned at the balance of this hop-monster. You need to try it, the hype isnt just hype. Now the details: 
A: Big tropical notes with floral undertones. Sexy beer. 
A: Pours a golden color with a one finger head that left some nice carbonation after dissipating.
T: Sweet Baby Jesus! Great balance for a DIPA. Big hop flavor right off, but as it opens up, grapefruit notes appear that add another interesting dimension to the beer. Fantastic malt after taste which really helps make this beer taste great and sets it apart from other DIPAs. 
P: Modestly carbonated, very tasty and very drinkable. 
O: Not much more to be said than my opening about this beer, but clearly TOP 2 DIPA/IIPA Ive ever had. Its nice for something this hyped to actually live up to its reputation and following! Beg, borrow, steal, commit treason -- do what is necessary to try this beer!

Doing this from memory. Wonderful aroma. Great balance. Lots of hops. Awesome beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

(Aug. 2013, draft at Toronado and bottle various places, SF) One of my favorites, of not the favorite, in the pale ale department. Pours slightly hazy, golden like a hayfield on a summers day. Aroma is like a "best of hops"; sharp apricot, peach, pineapple, green and herbal, spicy and piny, a fair amount of sticky marijuana, super fresh. Taste is dry, super fruity hops, how your brain would reconstruct an IPA in a dream, just super crisp and loads of hash and hops. One of the best things about this beer is that you always get it fresh, so its bound to always be good. A timeless classic for sure!
One of the best double IPAs out there. Smooth. Light. Little to no bitterness at the end. Highly drinkable. A lot like Flying Fish Exit 16.

Bottle, opened almost exactly three months after bottling. Pours a breathtaking gold with a high, sticky white head that leaves huge amounts of lace all over the glass. Nose is camphor, sage, rosemary, dry lavender, white grapefruit, and spruce. The first impression on the tongue is velvety smoothness -- then a perfectly elegant blend of malty sweetness and hops astringency and bitterness kicks in. I find myself lacking for superlatives. Finish is long, citric, and bitter, and leaves me wanting more. The IPA as an art form.

On tap at the brewery. Happy to have purchased 12 bottles to take home as well.
This is every bit the perfection it is touted to be. 
Sweet lemon grass citrus upfront. Caramel finish.
Yep this brew is the tits. REALLY!!

Bottled. Courtesy of Jim - huge thanks. Clear orange pour with a foamy white head. What sets this beer apart is the massive fresh hop aroma. Incredible. I smell pine mostly, but my wife says floral. Probably a little of both. Its the oily richness of the aroma that counts. Good solid IPA flavor. Very smooth. Bitterness balances with the massive malty backbone. Earthy finish. Warming after a few sips. Overall a wonderful double.

Fantastisk öl som jag hade förmånen att pröva på plats! En färsk pliny the elder är något det bästa man kan dricka. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Had on draft at Hops and Pie in Denver during GABF. Of course, there is no way to objectively rate this beer outside of a blind tasting because of its massive reputation. While there was no way this beer could live up to the hype, it's still an excellent beer in a conservative, yet timeless way. It doesn't reflect any of the modern trends in IPAs and focuses itself on being Supremely balanced. This beer could be used as the definition for an IPA. There is something to love about that even as other beers have taken the IPA to new places.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From a bottle. Pours a reddish straw color with an impressive head. Aromas are citrus, pine, and floral notes. Flavors are citrus, orange peel, and pine. Finishes with candied fruit. Medium mouthfeel with a crisp, clean finish. This is what an IPA should be.

Bottle: deep gold with orange. Clear and light white head. Big lift. Tropical, apricot and stone fruit. Slight pine notes but less than Blind Pig. Spicy. Floral edge. Very rich. Medium low sweetness and medium bitterness but balanced. Hops dominate malt. So fruity. So much weight and length. Persists for ages. A monster but balanced. Classic West Coast but there is a reason everyone loves this beer.

Love the aroma cant keep my nose out of the glass. The golden color is clear and inviting. You can taste the hops on your tongue without to much bitterness at the end. The feel of the malt in your mouth is pleasant and satisfying. It is one of my favorites and I will go out of my way to find it.

Pliny never ceases to please. It was my favorite before the DIPA craze and it continues to be. 

Bottle from Blackwell's, pours with a robust head with an aroma of pine and citrus. Mouthfeel is high carb and taste is more pine and citrus.

This Pliny was 5 months old at consumption. I am guessing it is probably supposed to be fresher, because it wasnt quite the beergasm I was expecting given its reputation. Still great though, dont get me wrong. Pours a very light honey gold color with a fluffy, bright white head with nice lacing as it fades. Aroma is sweet orangey citrus and just a little pine. Very full body and mouthfeel contrasting the light color. Just a touch of booze. Lovely overall. Id probably be more blown away if I was in California getting something super fresh.

Mild pleasant aroma. Hoppy taste upfront but no bitterness. An exceptionally smooth finish. The best IPA I've ever had. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A very good DIPA. Citrus, mainly grapefruit, some earthy grass, very smooth creamy feeling, with a bold finish! I was expecting better because of all the hype, I was very close to getting it, but it is not an Heady Topper, but it will always be a must. I need to try the younger.

2 month old bottle, perfect to the DIPA style. Nice grapefruit, pines and citrus while pouring, then the easy bitterness and medium mouthfeel, thats what Pliny is. (shouldnt be compared to those extreme dipas either). 
Needs to be consumed within a few months of bottle date.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2013 Here is the thing. This was my first time having Pliny because I live in a state too far from any of RRs distribution zones, and when I visit CA the popularity and legend of this beer make it impossible to pick up at a liqour store or whole foods.That legend and hype thus preceded my first tasting of this beer and so my rating might reflect that disparity between legend and living reality. Also, maybe this wasnt the freshest pour, since I had it at a Denver bar during GABF.Appearance: all is beautiful here. Medium gold with creamy white head. Head dissipated fast in my glass, though. Aroma: grapefruit, subtle orange, piney hops. Taste: very well balanced bitter hops and sweet malts. Light grapefruit throughout and finishes clean on a spicy/piney hop note. Palate: medium to light bodied, somewhat slick, but a solid finish. My thoughts are this: Pliny became legend before more robust and flavorful DIPAs (ahem, Hopslam!) came along. I dont think it?d have its reputation if it had to, in its early days, go toe to toe with something like Hopslam. The balance in this is well played and demonstrates deft brewing skill. But the best beers push boundaries. If the IPA movement is analogous to the American frontier, then Pliny?s boundary is somewhere back by St Louis, and Hopslam is settling down in California.

Bottle from the brewery. Pours yellow/orange with medium white head that fades after a few minutes. Aroma of clean citrus, pine and resin. Bright citrus and pine flavors. Excellent bitterness balanced with light malt backbone. Such a great beer.

Bottle from DiarmaidBHK (thanks!) - Pliny is really exciting because its a big IPA, but it isnt smack yo mama bitter. Its bitter enough to appreciate, but you can still enjoy the complexity from the hops. Its enough to turn a non-IPA person, such as myself, into a believer.

Tap at the Falling Rock Tap House, Denver. Poured a clear medium amber with a frothy white head. The aroma is grassy hop and pine needles. The flavour is strong bitter with a liqourice grass nettle hop palate and a long lingering bitter finish. Its 8% ABV and thats where most of the liqourice bitterness comes from. Its a great beer, but Im not sure it deserves its rating. I have sat there and tasted this over and over again. I want to believe, but sadly I cant.

Poured from bottle, slightly cloudy amber color, foamy white head. Very smooth with light citrus and pine flavors. Mildly bitter finish, floral aftertaste, no discernible malt. Very nice, would love to drink more!

Wow, this is just a fantastic beer! Great head and lacing. Lots of piney hop aromatics followed by grapefruit and citrus. Taste is very smooth and consistent. Very drinkable. Overall, this is top 10 for me.
2/9/2013. Sample thanks to G&GKevin. Amber color, white head. Loads of hoppy aromas with grapefruit, citrus, pine. An explosion of flavors and a finish that just hangs around. Perfection in a bottle.

Flaske. Tappet 30.09.13. Drukket 04.1013. 
Kompleks humleduft men ikke så meget in your face. Afbalanceret sammen med en let sødlig maltduft af korn og IIPA sødme. 
Gyldengul som en guldøl og helt klar.
Fyldig humlesmag meget sød meget skiftende humlearoma. Kompleks og meget rund. Ret sød og fyldig ift. IIPA generelt. Virkelig en stjerne i sin klasse men mangler måske noget særlighed. Den er dog uovertruffen på alle aspekter. Lidt overrasket over klarhed og så mangler den en duft af humleeksplosion. Men det skyldes nok at den er fra flaske. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

500ml bottle. Bottled on 9/10. Pours with light, white head that sticks around. Aroma of pine and citrus. Very smooth, citrus, bitter, a bit of apple, with a great malt base. Extremely good IPA with a great and unchallenged balance.
Alla spina al brewpub. per questa birra (e non solo) è valsa la pena di farsi unora di macchina da SF. Elegante e pericolosa, intensa e pulita, rispetta in pieno le alte aspettative...

Big thanks go to tectactoe on this one. One of the best Double IPAs I have ever had. I would really like to get my hands on more of this. I actually named my current fantasy football team after it. "Pliny The Welker" - You see what I did there?

Finally got the opporitunity to try this while on my business trip to SD.

Wow this is everything I had hoped for. 
Poured a hazy orange. This is literally one of the most beautiful beers Ive ever seen. The color is just outstanding. Too bad I can only go 5.0 on here. Very little head and some lacing down the glass.

Smells of grapefruit/citrus with a little bready malt presence.

Taste is a hops overload of delicious citrus with a nice strong bitter finish.

Lighter bodied for a DIPA which is perfect for me. The hops really shine through on this and before I knew it I had drained the whole pint with little effort. I just wish I had a way of getting this close to home.
Rich hippy sweet aroma. Sweet at the front with a perfectly balanced hop flavor in the middle and bitter sweet finish. Medium carbonation with a silky full body. Yum!

as a non-ipa person, i can respect my hophead brethren. after all, most of them in return wouldnt know a quality hefe if you held them down and poured it down their piehole. so i can get why this is so beloved. for me, while it had a good ipa flavor, my tongue seemed to be slowly constricting for the next minute or so after trying it. similar to when you eat hot sauce, my taste buds cried out for relief. glad i got to try it. now, get it away from me.

A perfect Sunday in the mission at Monks Kettle. Piney, hoppy, rich, California goodness.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Btl pours clear light copper color. Thick, creamy off white head with tiny compact bubbles that has staying power and leaves tons of lacing on glass. Smell of pine,cannabis and grapefruit and a faint aroma of sweet malt. Taste is of sweet malts and lots of fresh,crisp just picked hops with mellow bitterness. Medium body with a creamy slick texture and perfect carbonation. Nicely balanced DIPA that has a fresh, crisp ,explosive, and exceptional hop flavor and aroma. I would drink this everyday if i could get my hands on it. Perfection!
A little torn on this one. I thought it was gonna be a little better then it was. Its a solid beer but thinking its a little overrated

Wow! Just wow! Pours like a golden thunderclap and has a soft piney citrus essence that wafts up to your nostrils. The flavor is akin to the warm Pacific mountaintops and cool ocean breezes filled with the stanky goodness of hop godliness. The cool yellow liquid has pleasant playful bite on the tongue that lingers like a lover's kiss. DAYUM THIS SOME GOOD SHIZ!!!

On tap at Capones. Pours a slightly hazy amber light color with an off-white two finger pillowy head that falls slowly to a thin ring and leaves light lace. The aroma is bold and bright with big pronounced hops, citrusy grapefruit and pine blended with a slight grassy note and mildly sweet base. Taste packs loads of citrus up front with grapefruit, orange, pineapple, lemon, and tangerine followed by a solid honey and biscuity malt backbone. The finish oozes pine and some spicy hops with a wee bit of alcohol. Medium to full sticky, rich, creamy body with moderate smooth carbonation.
Very delicious! Perfect aroma, hippy and very balanced between the two! Very highly recomeneded. If you can find it!
Pretty good piss. Balanced as fuck. Doesnt live up to the fucking hype. Muppet cunts.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2014 On tap at brewpub on 062013. Pours clear golden/light copper with a white head. Aroma is lighter than I expected and quite subtle and intriguing. Aroma is mainly pine, resin and citrus, some sweet mango and pineapple as well, light malty notes. Taste follows the aroma and has a resinous sweetness and a very smooth bitterness. Finish is medium dry pine bitter. Very smooth body, almost oily feeling.

On tap at APEX, PDX. The colour is a hazy light amber with a short white head. The first sip tells me all I need to know about how hoppy this is. Its super bitter with a grapefruit and citrus abounding. The mouthfeel is big and luscious and the caramel that underpins it holds it all together nicely. Does Pliny live up to the hype? For me, on this evidence, not quite, but the fine pedigree is obvious.

From Eelbasher. What a prize, thanks!! Clear orange golden with a 1 finger white head that leaves lots of lacing. Sweet grapefuit and pine on the nose. Taste is sour orange, a bit of ceral malt, resiny pine finish. So glad I got to try this! Tasted against a can of Heady of the same age (6weeks) and I have to give Heady a slight edge. Both are excellent!

Tap at Toronado. Hazy gold/orange pour. Huge grapefruit and orange on the nose, thick pine, grassy hops, some light herb. Taste explodes with fresh hoppy goodness: shedloads of orange peel, grapefruit, and pine needles. Lovely biscuit and cake dough malt. Huge oily hop bitterness coats the mouth. Massive lingering citrus and pine. Massive DIPA - excellent stuff.

12 day old bottle. Pours golden with coarse white head, settles quickly with minimal lacing. Aroma is hoppy, very resinous, piney, floral. Flavor is strong, piney hops, with a strong hoppy, floral, resinous aftertaste. Very tasty. This beer is highly acclaimed for a reason. Moderate carbonation, medium body, crisp texture and oily finish. A top notch IPA.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2014 I drink this often, but Im rating it today on tap. What more can be said? If you get fresh Pliny, its incredible. Ive had fresh Heady cans in Vermont and I prefer this. I buy it every time I see it with a recent bottling date, its a no-brainer.

Bottled, its still excellent but subtract a tenth a of a point for every few days since the bottle date. There are a lot of beers Id rate above a month old PtE.

On tap at apex - so if course my expectations were huge and I've had better, (even today) but still, a nice clean hop taste and I wouldn't throw ole Pliny out of bed for eating crackers

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dont let the color fool you. This pale yellow, noncarbonated beer needs to be taken seriously. The aroma is nice mix or floral and citrus hops, but not overpowering. Taste is a nice balance for an IPA with citrus and floral hops, and stronger notes of citrus towards the end that quickly get more bitter. Amazing beer!

What can be say that hasnt been said already about Pliny the Elder? Its everything the beer judges say it is and more. The only reason I didnt give it a 5.0 is I wanted to give Russian River room to improve, but I cant imagine how.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2014 Delicious! This beer pours a nice amber color with a great head. Perfectly balanced. Got it in south lake Tahoe at the bottle shop.You must ask as it was hidden behind a blue moon bomber

On tap @ Stone Brewing. Pours golden yellow with thin off-white head. Smells of huge grapefruit juice, citrus, pine, bitter hops and a little caramel malt. This beer smells really good. Taste is very balanced between the sweet and bitterness. Grapefruit, pungent pine and hops with a creamy finish. This is a full bodied beer that lives up to the hype. One of the best imperial IPA in my opinion.

Hoppy-tastic aroma, with a hint of grapefruit. Nice golden color, with a feathery white head. Definite sour taste - too sour for my taste. Super sour aftertaste. Ewwwww. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Last time I declined to rate this I assumed it would always be available locally. Oops. Aroma of pineapple wafts out before I even bring my nose to the glass. Citrus, grapefruit, pine, and a dose of light caramel. Clear amber pour, white head, irregular lacing. Tastes like the prototype for a great double ipa. Malt backbone is present, offering just the right amount of sweetness to allow the hops to shine, without being too sweet or too dry. Bitterness is assertive, with big beautiful pine and citrus presence. Full body, average carbonation, great slick texture without being syrupy or thick. Lasting bitter finish. Everything about this is just right. Overall: I can imagine a time years ago when there was nothing else out there like this. Now it seems like there are a lot of good breweries out there who can make a solid double ipa that comes close to this ideal. Some take it even further, some go the same distance with a slightly different profile, but most fall short. There's a reason that this is such a classic, highly-regarded beer. Really impressive. I'm almost glad I can't get this all the time, so I can appreciate this as a special treat.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Spectacular. If you are reading this you need to try. Another reason to live in California.

Huge beer. Smooth with an enormous hoppy taste. Lovely color and nose. Magnificent, lived up to hype. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Åpenbart en strålende øl, frisk som fy og full av all den herlighet man ønsker seg i en amerikansk DIPA - 8% alkohol gir den en fylde som plasserer seg igrunnen midt mellom IPA og DIPA i min bok, og gjør den relativt lettdrikkelig sammenlignet med mange andre i sistnevnte kategori.

Pliny the Elder pours a pale amber, lighter than expected, with a white, fluffy head that dissipates quickly. Not much lacing but that may be more because of the shaker pint it was served in. Aroma is big and fruity, lots of grapefruit, pine, and lemon. Grapefruit and pineapple hit the front of the tongue. Finishes dry. Mouthfeel can best be described as smooth, medium-light bodied with light carbonation, drinks much easier than its 8% ABV. Overall, this is one of the smoothest, easiest drinking Imperial IPAs out there. Outstanding job Russian River.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This pours a dark banana yellow, slight haze, golden honey color with a creamy soft white head that fell slowly and left really great lace. The nose took a while to fully realize itself.
