Gedronken bij dutchdrebus samen met benzai en joes, goudkleurig/oranje helder en witte schuimkraag. Ruikt hoppig,bitter, echt lekker. Imperial ipa

Bottle from my brother, Daniel, who brought it to me in Chicago via Seattle. Pours a beautiful medium-amber with nice head retention. Pine and citrus in the nose, slightly dank. Medium full mouth-feel, lots of floral and citrus notes in the palate. Finishes with a pleasant slight-bitterness. In a blind taste test here in the Midwest, it wouldnt be surprising for this one to be mistaken for a Three Floyds brew. 5 Stars and thanks bro!
bottle. Smells great, nice aromatics. Smells very piney, spruce, herbal, slight caramel notes. Tastes, bitter, strong, full flavor. smooth and creamy. Piney, resin, sooo nice. Very, very good beer.

Sometimes a beer is so good its almost hard to explain the taste. Pliny the Younger is not what I would consider a "complex" palate in the traditional manner, but the tastes that are there are so strong and so delectable its an absolutely joy from the first sip to the last drop.

I poured a 500ml bottle into a tulip glass

Appearance: A beautiful shade of light orange/dark yellow which is slightly hazy and also bubbly. It forms a bright white, frothy head which leaves generous lacing on the glass. 

Smell: The aroma is as appealing as a beer can smell. As soon as I popped the cap I could smell the rich floral and citrus notes. Its a mélange of tropical fruits and fresh flowers with a very "clean" scent overall. 

Taste: Much like the nose, the body is a mash of sweet tropical fruit juice made from orange, tangerine and grapefruit, with perhaps a bit of mango or papaya. Its tart, like a glass of freshly-squeezed lemonade but without the sugary notes. The hops make the palate very crisp, but just like the scent, they finish clean. 

Ive had other IPAs from around the country that are so highly hopped and bitter they tend to tear up my palate like eating and entire box of Sour Patch Kids. While Pliny the Elder is noticeably bitter throughout, the aftertaste is surprisingly gentle and quite refreshing. 

Drinkability: The caveat to strong-tasting beers is they tend to be difficult to drink or their palate overall is simply an acquired taste. I dont think thats true of Pliny The Elder since the citrus flavor is something any beer drinker is used to, combined with the fact its not heavy or rough in the mouth. This beer goes down very smooth and the aftertaste lingers without wearing on the tongue.

Im not usually a fan of imperial or even "bigger" beers, but when brewed correctly the alcohol is almost irrelevant. If I didnt know Pliny The Elder was 8% ABV I never wouldve guessed this since there is zero booze present in the nose or the body. I only felt a slight buzz after I drank the beer, although this could be due to the fact it was so good I drank it rather quickly.

Being from santa rosa, it was only natural that I start my beer journey with this highly regarded double ipa. Right off the bat, the aroma of the beer is very floral and sweetly pleasant. The color is copper with minimal head. Good overall taste. Very refreshing but with a medium to high bitterness level.

My first draft pour upon arriving in the promised land that is Portland, Oregon.... Bright clear yellow with ok head.  Aroma is loud grapefruit, pine, resin, cedar.  Basically a perfectly rounded hop aroma.  Taste is pure grapefruit chronic.  Bod is light/medium, oily mouthfeel, long clean hoppy finish.  Overall, lives up to the hype.  Basically a perfect beer.

On tap 03/24/12 @ the Brew Pub: Pours a clear golden amber with a medium frothy off-white head that is fully lasting. Hoppy citrus aroma is floral and piney. Flavor has hints of a grapefruit and a tingling pine. Creamy texture with a refreshing bitter finish. Very fresh taste and well-balanced!

Crystal clear copper colour. Fruity hops. Pineapple, peach and grapefruit. Dangerously drinkable. Smooth texture. Rich malts without being sweet. Nicely balanced. Alcohol not at all noticeable. An excellent beer.

On tap at the Grad. It might be because it is Friday happy hour but I can't think of a reason to not give this beer a perfect rating. Perfect beer for the moment.


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled 3/7/12. Appearance: clear golden amber color, big white frothy head with decent retention and some alcohol legs. Aroma: beautiful grapefruit, floral/honeysuckle, some pine needle, touch of bready/caramel malt. Taste: oh so very smooth!  Nice grapefruity citrus burst at the front, with the bitter citrus pith coming in the middle lasting throughout, finishing with nice floral sweetness lingering a bit then lingering with that long, wonderful bitterness. Mouthfeel: fairly thin, oily, with a dryness. Overall: well, this is the one that I wondered when Id ever get to try it.  It really is an amazing DIPA that is understandably the root of all west coast IPAs.  I love many others that have their specific strong hop characteristics that stand out, but this one is just a perfectly smooth version that just kind of tastes like its an original that all others have grown from.  Its just a pure version of the style.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2013 Draft at Monks in April 2012. Rich golden amber with a thick white head. Lots of lace. Complex hoppy taste. Smooth at the start and middle then a bitter punch as it falls down the throat. Great mix of hops. More bite in the Elder, but not quite as perfect as the Younger. Update: Having the 2013 draft at Eulogy. Feels notably smoother this year. Still strong and complex. Just less bite at the end.

Great Dipa, slightly over rated tho...

This elixir pours golden amber with fluffy straw head. Aroma is big with honey, pine, grapefruit and lemon rind  perfectly melded together. this one attacks your tongue with hops (both flowery and piney), citrus shows through but not sappy, malts on the back with a herbal hop finish. Near perfect!

Poured an nice amber color with a smooth hoppy nose.  Dull yellow head with a bold start and a pleasing finish.  Its hard to have another IPA after this one. Great job!

one of my all time favorites I just hadnt rated. Bottled on 3/19/12 and opened on 3/28/12. Pours a perfect orange, with a full three fingers of foamy head. Tons of hop bitterness and citrus aroma, with almost an apricot like fruity hop aroma. So smooth and balanced. Tons of hops, but nicely balanced with the malt. One of the easiest drinking double IPAs on the planet.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2013 Nice golden pour...very clear..floral and slightly piney aroma, citrus and hoppy, a tinge of grapefruit on the flavor.  It is a wonderful DIPA.  I thoroughly enjoy this style and this is up there with some of the best.

Clear golden amber color with tiny rising bubbles. The off-white head is thin and frothy. Aroma is explosion of citrus and pine. Piney hops come through right up front followed by an awesome creamy bitterness.  Very nice.

Got a bottle from a friend who had traveled to Cali...thanks Peter Q.!  Amazing aroma, nice golden color, 2 finger head.  Taste of hops but not too bitter or hoppy.  Reminds me of Hopslam...only better!

Bottle from a trade with mashmaster. Floral grapefruit hops, white grape malt aroma. Clear golden with a small white head. Flavor much like the aroma with floral grapefruit hops very well balanced by light sweet malt. Very nice!

Strong, hoppy aroma has a strong overtone of grapefruit. Very grapefruit-y. It pours a clear amber with a respectable white head that leaves some good lacing. Flavor is - WOW! A good DIPA, but I am not sure that it lives up to the gigantic hype. It has a great resinous hop aroma, but is not particularly bitter or hoppy on the palate. It is good, but I wonder if all the fame has gone to its (or its brewers) head.
The perfect beer in every way.  Gorgeous light orange color, pillowy, two-finger head, intense tropical aromas, pine.  Smooth as hell.

Bottle thanks to csteele2144, thanks Chris!  Pours a bright clear golden with a thick white head,  aroma has a good amount of grapefruit and dank wet hops, the flavor has a ton of tropical fruit with a bitter finish, the mouthfeel is smooth as silk, I enjoyed this very much, but I think if I had the choice side by side I would still go with Hopslam, call me a homer if you will.

From notes.
Pours a crystal clear golden orange that sent up a nice creamy white one finger head that fell down to a film that leaves a nice sticky lacing all the way down the beer.
Wow, what a nose. Hops, big time. Lots of tropical fruit, tangerine, orange, pineapple. Its sweet but smells like you just stuck your face in a bag of hops.
It hits the tounge with lots of sweetness, fruit and sweet malt, but then quickly changes to a nice hoppy kick of bitterness, citrus, hop and orange rine, leaving a sweet flavor on the front of the tounge and a nice tingeling bitter sensation on the back.
Mouth feel is nice. Big carbonation, a pretty full body, a nice oily hop resin coating, lots of stuff going on after the swallow with flavors sticking around.

On tap at Local 44.  Poured a clean light golden color with decent head and good lacing.  Nose of pineapple with hints of pine and citrus.  Taste of pineapple and citrus with some sweet malt and pine.

Gold pour with a fast dissipating head. Smell of grapefruit and pine. Taste is hoppy up front with malt sweetness to it. Finish is clean and bitter. Very easy drinking for a dipa. Not sure it lived up to the hype for me but still a great brew.

Amazing.  Truely amazing.  Best IPA Ive had, just a beautiful all-around presentation.  On tap at the Monks Cafe in Philly, during an event where I got to try about 5 world-class brews including this, the Younger, Blind Pig, and a bunch of sours.  This one pours golden amber with a medium head retention, bright hoppy aroma and crisp hoppy attack.  A smooth transition through the middle, just bright hoppy balance with a subtle malt, and clean hoppy finish.  

W O W.  What a joy!

Poured out of a bottle into a tulip glass, large head which pretty quickly comes down to a light one covering the surface, look is reddish gold, hoppy aroma with the sip being relatively crisp medium carbonation and the bitterness following, light warmth going down. A lot of hype fer this here brew, and shes a beaut, to be sure.  Pours a very clear yellow with citrus and floral nose.  Great floral hops and a very smooth, maybe too smooth, imperial ipa experience.  Palate clears quickly.

Poored an orange copper color.  Nice aroma with a bit of citrus.  The taste was mild with some good hop flavor.  The alcohol his hidden well, but it just didnt have an overwhelming flavor like I was expecting.  Overall, this is a very good IPA that everyone should try at least once, but a Heady-Topper it is not.

Poured from a bottle into a tulip glass. Appearance is translucent yellow with a thick white head of foam. Aroma is heavily citrus influenced by the hops. Mouthfeel is slightly bubbly and chewy. I like how the beer sticks to the inside of the mouth. Long bitter and sweet finish. Too bad the bottom of the glass came as soon as it did. From notes, reviewed on 6/3/11. On tap into pint glass. Pours a pale orange/golden, soft lacing. Smells sweet and bready, covered in grapefruit, limes, pine. After a swirl, more lemon and coriander come through. Taste is sweet with oranges and grapefruits over a bready backbone, differently laid out than the aroma. Piney bitterness on the roof and in finish with lingering grapefruit. Feels smooth and light, slightly astringent in the middle. Refreshing, crisp, clean, fruity, very well balanced.

Appearance is a clear orange with a  medium white head.  Smells citrusy. Taste is very very hoppy with some citrus notes. Finishes with extreme bitterness. The alchohol is very well hidden.

For us people on the east coast it reminds me alot of Dogfish head
90 minute IPA, very hoppy. If you like hoppy beers this is for you. 

I would like to add that I would highly recommend everyone trying this beer, with so many good reviews I am sure I am in the minority. I am just not a big hop fan. I have tried russian river Temptation and found it a very good beer and would still like to try Pliny the Younger if I ever get the chance.

Bottle 66 cl thanks to Tim. And here we are again: my third Pliny. First was really fresh and, due to my poor knowledge and free from the impact of the REAL WC-IPA, I stated as one of the best beer ever had before. Second wasnt so fresh. Third was even freshier than the first, but now I reach a better level of the style knowledge and more able to judge. So what? Well, aroma and taste are difficult to describe. You should have. And after, astonished from a so complex but perfectly balanced profile: hops arent the classic punch in your nose that of DIPAs in general, but rich and complete: grapes, citrus, grapefruit, resin, green apple, pineapple. Taste is incredibly crisp, fresh and satisfactory. A medium body that fills mouth between bitterness and fruit. And you dont believe its a DIPA: probabiy its the heaven and hell, lacks something strong (not aggressive. *Strong*), and the reason for which isnt the *best* DIPA ever for me. But surely in the top three, a step under the Mongo I think. Apart from that, Pliny the Elder has something thatll never bore you. Alcohol? Haha. Juice drinkability, and embodies the concept of a simple and extraordinary beer. Having a 24-crate its a must.

Fantastic!  Delivers on the bitter piny citrus hops but doesnt linger. Very well balanced with just enough malts.

Had PtY earlier today and happy I found this bottle of PtE. Pours neon orange with foamy head with great lacing. Aroma is massive peach and grapefruit and pine.
Hopped perfection. Slightly murky light orange coloration. Grassy aroma, slight citrus. Medium body with a slimy bitter taste. Not at all abrasive.

From notes.  First reviewed 7/10/2010.  As an IPA lover (in all forms - DIPA, IIPA included), this was THE one I have been waiting for. Poured from a 500 mL bottle into a tulip. Freshness date 6/21/10.

Pliny is great looking right from the start. A slightly hazy orange amber color with a tight fluffy white head, with a few large errant bubbles on top. Some resplendent carbonation rises from the bottom of the glass. Pretty good retention, and there are rings of lacing down the glass.

There is an elegant aroma, extremely hoppy but oh so balanced on the nose. Pineapple, grapefruit, a bit of orange, and tons of pine overwhelm my olfactory system. 

The taste starts out and stays strongly hoppy the whole way through. Such a wide range of flavors that all work well together. Pine is the single strongest noticeable flavor, but orange, pineapple, grapefruit, and a bit of herbal goodness are present throughout each sip. The malt is not of the same strength as the hops, but it does not let me down like in some pure hop bombs. Some soft sweetness and a little spicy flavor keeps me interested. Lingering bitterness after the sip, but I do not mind it.

There is not a way to make this smoother while keeping the great crisp feel. The carbonation is not overdone, but it is a smooth operator, bringing a great pop to the taste.

This beer keeps getting better and better. There was absolutely no way it could have met my expectations, but it came pretty close. It would be a treat to have this available more often.
Clear gold with white head.  Resin, pine, grapefruit, sharp bitter hops. Well balanced by honey sweetness. Lively carbonation, with lasting tingly tongue feeling. Among the best in the world.
A perfect beer when fresh.  The citrus jumps out of the glass and punches you in the nose.  The hops linger on your tongue and dance a salsa.  The flavors blend together and produce an amazing beer.

Pours a clear golden color with a frothy head and lacing.  The aroma is amazing, really sprucy with some grapefruit.  The taste is hoppy and very refreshing with hints of fruit.  Great palate with a nice mouthfeel and just the right amount of carbonation, with a nice crisp finish.  Overall, one of my favorite IPAs out there and always enjoy it when I can find it.
Hops aroma is mouthwatering. It is as good as it smells. Good body, citrus and pine flavors in the hops are great.

Glad Ive tried it now. Pliny has a nice light clear appearance with a great ammonia and grapefruit nose. Very light mouthfeel that finishes clean with a bit of linger from the 8%. Overall a very pleasing experience.

Reviewed from notes.  Poured from a bottle into a CBS snifter.

A.  Pours a cherry orange, nice one finger head, rests at some nice bubbles and a thick ring, very nice lacing on the glass.

S.  Smells of sweet orange, pine and light grape fruit, and some white grapes.  Very sweet smelling.

T.  Tastes of smooth citrus, mild grapefruit, a warm tangy finish that I cant quite describe.

M.  Medium heavy body, large feeling, a little creamy, medium carbonation, slightly dry finish.

O.  A pretty good beer.  Sweet with some nice flavors, a bigger feeling IPA.  I think this is much over hyped.  Just not the mind blowing beer all the ratings pitch it to be.  A great beer for the $6 you pay for it on the West coast, but not worth trading a fortune for.  Glad I tried it, but I wont  likely search it out in the future.
Best DIPA Ive ever had. So balanced it tastes and feels like an IPA. Recently had one 5 days after the bottling date. Cant go wrong with Elder!

a PaulUnwin share.. 500ml bottle poured into a snifter. pinky up on every sip. bright translucent pale copper color with a thin off white head. very robust hop aroma of grapefruit, citrus and pine. HOPS! from the first sip down to the after taste although well balanced with some slight malt sweetness. the 8% abv is present but not overpowering. a must try for any hophead! thanks for sharing Paul!

Pours a clear light copper with a white head and nice lacing. Aroma is citrusy (grapefruit) and piney. Has a perfectly hoppy front end, and a nice linger.  Its got a terrific bitter finish. Its not too carbonated, drinks easily, and is very enjoyable.

Pour deep copper, with a one-finger sized dense white head. 
Aroma is nice and complex. Pine, grapfruit, citrus. Some sort of tropical fruit in the aftertaste. Makes the sips last nice and long. Also caramel and some bready notes in here. Obviously a lot of hops going on, but very well balanced, which only tickles a little bit.

Medium body, with a fizzy carb.

pours clear golden brown with small amount of white head  nose is piney anf floral, maybe centennial hops? taste is more towards bitter then balanced, toast and pine on the palate. nice mouthfeel, not overly syrupy. no cloying sweetness, very good double ipa!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2014 Bottled drank 5 weeks old purchase at the PTY release at the brew pub.  In an IPA glass pours crystal clear golden with tiny carbonation, a big lasting soft off white head, and remarkable lace. The aroma is floral and of not ripe orange with hints of grain. When I get into it that turns into light caramel and pine. The taste is at first sweet and biscuity with some citrus hops then turns into intense, distinct, all-over grapefruit; finally pith, pine, and and spice. The feel is at first velvety; then frothy, full, and alive, and finally all over mouthwatering and partially astringent with a little warmth. It is both forward and restrained. Each part is distinct but works together. I consider this to be one of the few true archetypes the style.
Great hoppy nose, very fresh and vibrant. Light and almost too easy to drink. Firm bitterness. Fruity and tasty. I like it.
The most awesome beer ever made. It is one of my all time favorites but it is so hard to find.  Hoppy and so smooth I could drink a bottle in a minute.  If I ever get the chance to get more I will.
BIT-TER!  Honey colored with a reasonable foam. Grassy and hop folled aroma.  Good herbal hop flavor with a solid, balancing malt ass.  Tasty but leaves me underwhelmed.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2014 50cl, Bottled on September 30th 2014, American brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex bitter brew, malty/floral and slightly woody/sweet, easy to drink, very balanced, clear, good head, very good brew, yet expensive!

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2013 "My 50th Review!
Thanks to bcook582 for sending me 4 of these in exchange for 4 Heady Toppers.
Poured into a Harpoon Tulip at 55 Degrees F. Bottled on January 8th so its about 2 weeks old.
A - Poured aggressively and produced a 4 finger head. The golden haze reminds me of a lighter 120 Minute IPA with a lot more tiny particles floating around like its going out of style. Head subsided to 1 finger after 5 minutes.
S - HOPS! So much hop and bitterness, its remarkable. Heady Topper, Hopslam and 120 Minute got together and had a baby.Pine, vanilla, cream, citrus all in unison singing loud to the heavens.
T - On fire! Theres so much going on here. Citrus and some candy notes like candy corn or lemonheads are in here. Its such a fulfilling taste that I dont even know what to say. I love the aftertaste of malt that just lingers on and on!
M - This is a deep but still medium beer with a load of carbonation that isnt overpowering. Its so drinkable! 
O - To be so strong and full of flavors, I can gulp this beer and its no problem...if only Pliny grew on trees. This beer is something everyone on BA should try. Search after this one and drink it carefully because its not so easy to find for most east coasters."
Great piney citrus aroma, slight off white head and deep golden color.  Well balanced for a IIPA.The best beer Ive tasted to date.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2013 Draft.  First taste ever.  And while I had been drinking pretty much all day up to this point, I was able to jot down some notes as I am pretty sure it will be a while before I get to taste again.  Pours a bright orange that is just slightly unclear.  Smell was every kind of hop smell thrown togehter - pine, resin, grapefruit, sweet tropical fruits. Good ol Pliny. Sweet and floral on the nose. Taste is little bit piny with a just a hint of citrus. Next comes an explosion of hops. Finishes a perfect balance between bitter and smooth.

pours a gold color with a medium white fizz. Aroma is pine, floral and citrusy.
Very balanced flavor, it touches tropical, bitter and sweet! they could sll this beer for alot more than they do! Amazing!

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2012 Lighter colored than the HUB Abominable I had right before. This was from a batch that was about 6 weeks old. Aromatics are extremely powerful and come in layers. Fresh and clean, but tons of power. I absolutely love this stuff, but need to continue to experiment with drinking windows to find my apogee.

Light orange pour with an inch of head,some lacing.Slight yeast haze,if i hadnt poured it all im shure it would have been clear.
Nice mellow fruit/floral/spice nose,with hints of vanilla candy and carmel candy and marshmellow.Cotton candy.
 Good mouth feel mellowly  lightly creamy, with a hoppy candied flavor,really nice mouthfeel with a slight dryness,nice sustaining hop bittering,medium bodied,pine and grapefruit come out as it warms with a grassy  chewyness,like chewing hops but drinkchewing them,if i had this 5$ beer around id be drinking it every week, this is like a very good laguntas,two hearted ale and something of a gumballhead from 3floydes.As excellent as its reputation,although lagunitas is a good standby and maybe a two hearted.Great beer.Deserves its reputation.

Overall: This was a surprise appearance for the night, but I couldnt let it go another day in order to enjoy as fresh as possible. Of course I was more than happy to enjoy this much talked about brew, and enjoy it I did! I cant say this is hands down the best IPA Ive ever had, but its right up there with my favorites in the style. Despite being on the higher end in ABV, this is a brew I could drink all night.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2015 Poured a beautiful golden orange, with a big frothy white head. Aroma is huge citrus, pine, grass, weed, lemony, and oranges in the aroma. Taste is huge pine, grass, and resin, yet enough malt to make it perfectly balanced. Big hop presence, yet remains refreshing, with a huge bitter finish that seems to linger for days. Mouthfeel is sticky with lively carbonation. Overall, the one of the best IPAs I have ever tasted. Crisp and clean enough for summer, yet enough alcohol warmth for winter. Amazing.

Bottle 50 cl, bierkonig. Pours clear amber with an off white head leaving nice lace. Aroma is very intense hopoy, fruitu, piny, citric, fruity; just great. Flavor as great, enjoying every sip of it in my hotel room in Amsterdam. Finishes longlived malty, bitter, fruity and grapefruit.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2016 Bottle at Petrol Stations bottle share. Pours a cloudy copper with small of white head. The aroma is floral hops and caramel malt. Medium mouthfeel with a good balance of sweet hop and rich malt and nice light bitter finish.

500 ml bottle thx Heather and Frank. bottling date 11.17.11 A: citrusy, piney. App: clear light copper with lasting white head and excellent lacing T/P : med body. The bitter finish come in two phases. First come a light bite with some warmness from the alcohol than your stroke with a great bite of bitterness. Carbonation is on the soft side. O: Its excellent but would like to drink a fresher bottle the aromatic were not "in your face" has I tought it would have been.
UPDATED: FEB 24, 2016 Had on tap at russian river brew pub. Great aroma. Smells like loads of hops. Taste fresh. Perfectly balanced beer. One of the best around.
UPDATED: FEB 15, 2012 Not sure if there will ever be a better IPA.  Orange color, pine and citrus aroma, it really taste like your drinking hops, fantastic

500 ml bottle purchased at Uber in Seattle, WA.  Pours an awesome amber color with a white head.  Aroma:  Bold hops and grapefruit.  Flavor:  Same as the aroma, with a hint of orange peel.  Such a great beer.
bottle. pours orange with perfect white head. aroma of pine and citrus. taste is like sucking on a hop fricking amazing

Bottle ---> Tulip. Fresh bottle from a trade. Thanks Vince! Pour was a light copper color with a voluminous head. Nose had some incredibly floral notes and grassy hops with the typical pine/citrus aroma. Everything worked well here. Some notes of tropical fruits rounded this one out. I love the ones that have aromas that remind me of the outdoors. Taste was well rounded and easy to drink. Nice and malty backbone with a good ol grapefruit hop presence. A great IPA for sure.

Thanks to OmegaX - Ive finally gotten a taste of this stuff. The aroma was rich of pine and zest with delicate floral notes. Among most double IPAs, the hops arent as robust and bitter, but rather sweet and compliment the malt background quite well. The finish was light and refreshing - well rounded indeed.

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2016 Finally!  Fresh bottle, Amber pour, 2 fingers of head.  Loads of hops in the aroma - Piney, Citrus fruit cocktail, grapefruit.  floral - aroma fills the room.  Pine, Grapefruit, floral taste, pale malts, grassy, fairly sweet - Fantastic.  Medium body, carbonation is right there.  Big thanks to my brother for the gift.

Bottle @ Bir & Fud Bottega. I had this one many times so far, but i think im still not able to describe in words WHY the Pliny is THE beer. It is not even such a complex beer, all is straight and simple but damned good and balanced. Golden color, white rich head, good lacing. Aroma of Pine (classic american IPA trademark), Citrus (tangerine and orange mostly), pale malt, flowers. Taste of malt, hops, pine, a little bit of resin and a perfectly mixed caramel malt note. Medium body, round mouth feel quite bitter, crisp but you can get some sweetness too. Alcohol: is there any alcohol in this beer? Drinkable? They had to invent this word just for this beer i suppose. Ive more problem to finish a galass of water. Brewed where the only matter is making damned good beers; not asking themselves if is a good idea to filter or use hops pellets.  A masterpiece. <=period

HOLY MOTHERFUCKING SHIT THIS IS THE BEST IIPA IVE EVER HAD.  It tastes like a buttload of awesomeness cumming endless sprites of HAWPED out botanical bodaciousness!!!  you can read some bougiegaylord description about this beer, or you can GO DRINK ONE!!!  you cant fuck up that way.

Poured from a bottle.
Aroma: pine, citrus, flora, hint of caramel in the background
Taste: resin, spicy, citrus, caramel sweetness
Overall: A very nice IIPA.
delicious hoppy nose, citrus and pine flavors, complex and delightful to drink

Hazy amber/gold color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of pine hops, rich floral, fruit, & citrus; Flavor of slight sweet malt, caramel/toffee, pine hops, some pineapple, and citrus (notably tangerine & grapefruit); Finish is bitter and dry; The alcohol is well hidden; Nicely balanced & complex; Overall, awesome IPA (not over the top) - the gold standard of the style.
Had this beer many times and every time I am still impressed. Defintley something you have to drink fresh and if in bottles be sure to drink within 3 months... Great job Vinny!

On tap at Monks Cafe. This was a great example of this style brew. Poured a cloudy golden color with a small oragish hue. Lots of citrus on the nose. Flavor was hoppy, citrus and bitter.A nice well rounded balance of flavors. Finished off with a slight hop bitterness.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2014 Impossible to find in Europe so was privileged to share a few bottles that were brought back to the London recently. Sustained smoothness of the finish on this beer in something else.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
user_location: The big bad LDN, Greater London, ENGLAND

text: Simply the best beer Ive ever had.  the hops, citrus and touch of gold is perfect every time.  i continue to drink more and more different beers but none stack up.

Nose is citrus hops, bright and pungent. Hint of cat pee. Touch of caramel malt. Taste is very bitter, green. Pretty unimpressive. Maybe one of the most overrated beers Ive had. Bottle was 2 weeks old.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2012 
Draught @ Apex, Portland.
Aroma is a bit stuffier compared to bottle. Same thing with the flavor. The hops are a bit crispier though.
50 cl bottle @ Home.
Originally rated on 20110804.
Pours clear golden colour with a light head, leaves some nice lacing. Aroma of mandarin, orange, apricot, light grass notes, mild sweet syrup and floral hops. Flavour has orange, pine needles, distant notes citrus and honey. Palate is smooth and slick, turns bitter and dry towards the end leaving a sweetish syrupy aftertaste. Definitely one of the best double IPAs Ive tasted. Well balanced and enjoyable brew.
4516

I really liked this, the aroma and the awesome grassy botanicals up front, then a light fruitiness, and a long warming finish.  A beer that really has phases. And showing that a double IPA does not just have to taste like a bunch of extra hops. This shows they can be combined to achieve something different.
Nice floral aroma of pine, lavender and pear. Nice gold colour with next to no head and only a little white lacing. Taste of citrus, pine  and alcohol. This is a nice beer, like it alot

Shared bottle @RBNAG-11. Finally! Body is bright golden orange with slight haze. Low blond bubble head.  Big hop aroma. Grass and evergreen at first, then the fruits: peach, apricot, grapefruit and pinapple. Sweet, solid malt baody. And for sure, enough bittering hops to balance it. Tongue-numbing oily, resinous and piny bitterness. Fruity hop flavor emerge after a while.  Smooth and creamy in the mouth. Body is more than medium full. Lingering bitterness in a lasting finish.  A very good one, must be awesome fresh from the brewery...

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2012 Bottle from Chucks into my Duvel Tulip. 12/02/11 batch. Pours somewhat murky golden orange with three fingers of white head. Smells of pine, grapefruit, hops, resin. Its not intrusively bitter, but you can sense the hop presence. Smooth, crisp, refreshing front. Grapefruit citrus middle. Pine finish. Remarkably complex, and sits on the palate very well. Very well done IPA, certainly up there among my favorite. Its an experience to say the least.

Picked a few bottles of this up at Beaumont Market and split all three with the wife today in a pair of twelve ounce tulips I picked up at the Dollar store. The glasses are an awesome value and highly recommended. The Plinys were bottled on 05/26/2010. Ive reviewed this on tap once before but wanted to review the fresh bottle form now as well. On to the review!

The appearance is quite good. The body is a lite yellow gold in color and is very clear with minimal unfiltered sediment goodness in suspension. A few fingers of ivory soapy head hang over the top of the liquid and slowly recedes to a thin cap. Lacing remains where the head formed but doesnt continue down the glass. 

Smell is piney, fresh oily hop, tropical citrusy goodness! Some honey exists as well lending to the wonderful bouquet. It may be the highlight of the drink. 

The taste is mainly oily bitter pine. Sweet tangelos add to the light malt backbone that exists only to embrace that wonderful fresh hop goodness. Some alcohol shows up to lend some warmth to the end of the drink but is in no way unwelcome. 

Is this 8 percent? You couldve fooled me. We plowed through 3 half liters like it was nobodys business and wanted more. The appropriate carbonation helps this go down oh so smooth. I will be looking for this next time it comes to Portland and recommend anybody who sees this available to buy a bottle or three! They can be hard to find so dont pass them up!

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2012 from a bottle that was bottled on 9/2/11. Pours a solid gold color with a small head.

very good aromas with good depth. Nice balance of hops with fresh citrus, oranges, hops, and some floral aromas. Doesnt really jump out, but blends together.

Good medium/full body, but lacks a bit on the finish and mid-palate. Very good attack with flavors of oranges, florals and hops.

This is a really good double IPA. It isnt the blow away beer that I expected, but I do wonder if expectations could be met. I know it wasnt the freshest bottle, but it still is a quality beer.

the cap came off and I was treated to what I can only describe as heaven in a bottle. No other beer has ever had such a wonderful aroma to me as Pliny. I poured this magnificent brew into a sniffer glass and was rewarded with a medium golden colored brew that gave a fingers worth of fluffy white head and good lacing. The well balanced aromas of citrus, grass and pine pleasantly greet your nose. The taste is amazing, the crispness of citrus was perfectly balanced with a strong malt backbone that left a slightly sharp aftertaste on the tongue. Despite having a relatively high IBU count and above average ABV, this beer is extremely drinkable. I cant help but think, this is the perfect DIPA!
On tap.  A golden beer with a medium off-white head.  Aroma of hops, citrus, and some berries.  Taste is sweet and very bitter, and ends with a very dry finish.  Perfect medium body and carbonation.

This beer does not disappoint at all as the best IPA (of any category IPA, IIPA, etc) out there, and Im not a huge IPA kind of guy.  The hops are there, but nice and not over powering.  It has a nice smooth taste to it, and I felt like I could have drank more and more and not get tired of it.

Bottle shared with a friend in new York.
Thin white head.  Clear golden pour.  Lovely citrus aftertaste.  Great beer

Poured a golden color similar to honey. Smells and tastes of pine and citrus, but is light bodied.  Has a grassy finish. This is my favorite IPA; hope to get some Pliny the Younger at some point to do a comparison.

Draught. Pours a clear golden with a white head. Smells strongly of fresh grapefruit and hops. Taste is citrus (grapefruit) and refreshing hops with a strong bitterness. Finishes a long bitter. Light bodied. Medium carbonation. Quite tasty.

From trade with nbutler11. This 38 days old Pliny pours clear amber with a beige head. Aroma is quite as i expected - Straight forward west coast IPA with lots of crispy juicy hops, bright citrus fruits, weak pine, mango, pineapple, grapefruit, also a very weak bready feel to it, sweeter peach and just a touch of malts in the backbone. Taste is just so balanced and suttle. Juicy hops, pine, grapefruit, some crispy hop forward thing going on, bright citrus fruits, orange peel, some tropical notes aswell leading to a dry bitter end. This is just so clean in its style. I kinda understand the hype behind this! Drinkable? - Yes!

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2012 Visual: fairly bright, straw gold, frothy white head.

Nose: medium pine and citrus aroma.

Palate: Like the nose, pine and citrus, fairly malty sweet, however the malts are rather uninteresting (unlike a Union Jack!).

Conclusion: This is a solid double IPA, but it is rather pedestrian. It has been hyped up over the years and  that is the mystique behind it. I certainly wouldnt turn down a pint of it, but there are certainly better double ipss out there such as Boneyards hop Venom, Firestone Walkers Double jack, or Old Schoolhouses Imperial IPA.
15.10.2011. 0,5l Bottle. Golden yellow colour with white head. Aroma of malt and refreshing hops. Very good flavours of piny aromatic hops with notes of spices and herbs.

Bottle. The pour was a medium clear yellow with a slight amber hue and a large (2-3 finger) white frothy head that lasted throughout and had good lacing that  spottily stuck to the glass.

The aroma gets you right away with strong grassy and citrus hops, grain malts and a moldy cobweb scented yeast with notes of orange peel and lemon zest.

The taste was ever so nicely bitter-sweet and slightly malty with a touch of lemon at first then had a nice hoppy bitterness come through with a nice does of orange peel at the end. The flavor lasted a good long time allowing for the hops and citrus to blend really well leaving a wonderful lingering aftertaste.

Mouthfeel was light to medium in body with a nice dry texture and a soft carbonation.

Overall an extremely good tasting IPA with all factions (hops, malts and citrus) blending together to form a very unique tasting experience. I can see now why it is referred to as the pinnacle of IPAs.

Have had it on tap and bottle.  Dark gold pour with some head that is gone in a flash.  Besides the onslaught of hops the nose is big on grapefruit and other Citrus fruits and possibly some pineapple.  Taste follows with a ton of upfront and backhand hoppy bitterness.  There is quite a substantial malt backbone here as well.  Really good stuff from an otherwise not huge fan of the overtly hoppy goodness.

nice little surprise from Chucks. pours clear deep golden, frothy cream colored one finger head, sticky lacing. fair amount of carbonation bubbling from the base of my Duvel glass. cinnamon, spicy, ginger, citrus and grapefruit hop notes on the nose. acidic, bitter aftertaste that lingers. pillowy, light mouthfeel, the beer evaporates on the palate. awesome and up to the hype. Need to get more...

Bottle. Citrus  and pine aroma. Golden amber pour. Big off white head. Good head retention. Excellent balanced beer. Very smooth and almost creamy with hops bursting through finish. Citrusy piney hops with the right amount if sweetness. Deliscious as always.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2013 Draft. Pours golden with a finger of white head and lacing. The aroma has pine, grapefruit, more pine, some floral notes. The taste is medium bitter with a big citrus kick. The next step is an aggressive dry hop note.
Pours an orange color with an off white head. Huge aroma of pine trees, pine needles, resin and sap. Amazing. Taste is extremely bitter. Large blasts of everything I could smell plus a bit of citrus.

Bottle from Johns in Portland.

Honestly, I guess there isnt much to say.  Its amazing. Light hazy colour Hoppy, Bitter, Fruity, Sweet, everything in balance.

Constant supply from Blackwells in San Francisco.  This brew has surpassed my expectations from the genesis of my indulgence.  Great citrus aroma and high powered hop formula outlasts the best of them.  Goes great with a late meal or can substitute as a meal itself.  Super clean and high powered ABV keeps my chippy close.  A+ (plus)   just sayin
On tap at Oskar Blues home made liquid and solids. Pours amber with little head. Nice honeyed hop aroma, medium bodied with tons of hops, but not too much bitterness.
Not overly bitter, smooth hop flavor and excellent aroma. I just wish it was easier to find!

Amazing bottle sent from phaleslu, thank you!! Shared into two snifters. Pours a golden straw with no haze and a thinnish dissipating white head. Aroma is good hop, citrus, light straw. Flavor is beautiful, good hop characteristic followed with a light sweetness that lingers, light orange peel, citrus, crisp and bitter. Body is light to medium, and super smooth. Overall, this is my third chance at this one. First was a let down, but luckily two and three came through. Thanks again Peter!

12 oz bottle from Belmont Station in Portland....bottled on 10/14; drunk on 11/21....pours a rich orange with moderate head...now it gets good!  Hoppy nose with moderating malts....taste is also moderated...great hops with smoothing malts...damn, this stuff is good...

Golden yellow pour. Citrus, caramel, alcohol, a light sulfur, sour cherry, smoke, and wood... lots of wood. The bottle I tried didnt seem all that fresh (perhaps shipping wasnt kind to it) so Ill re-rate next chance I get. Medium body and quite dry. Exceptionally well balanced for a double IPA.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2014 On tap in a shaker.  Pours amber with a lacy, off-white head.  Aroma strong of citrusy and piney hops and caramel malts.  One of the hoppiest beers Ive tasted, and even the strong malts cant balance out the bitterness of the hops.  Smooth texture.  A great beer.  Edit: 6/1/14. On tap at the brewery.  Awesome.

What can you say about this great beer that hasnt been said already. Like most hop forward brews the fresher the better, say less than a month old or so. I cant imagine what could be done to make this a better brew, IMO its the best DIPA on the market.

I only rate beers that my ratebeer brethren have raved about.  Why drink average beer when there are brilliant concoctions like this?  I am fortunate to have a bowling buddy with serious hops (aka: friends who bring him hard to get beers), and he brought this to bowling night.  I bowled poorly, probably from the distraction of this work of art.

From a bottle, poured a clear amber with just a little froth that didnt form a head. Right from the start I knew this was going to be exceptional. One sniff of that gorgeous aroma and I was sold. And it was just as aromatic on the last sip as the first. I dont even know how to describe it except to say its the best IPA Ive ever had aroma wise. The taste was pretty awesome too but I like to have another someday just to compare. Just makes me want to have a Younger that much more!!
Really good IPA. Comparable to Fort George Vortex IPA. Medium aroma, nice creamy head, minimal bitter finish. Golden amber.

On tap. Outstanding IIPA. Hops and malt are extremely well balanced. Very hoppy with nice citrus flavors. Strong but not over powering malty caramel in the background. Bitter but smooth finish. Lives up to the hype.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2012 Pours light golden with nice head an outstanding aroma. Taste is abundant hop, with a lot of bitterness but somehow its not harsh or overdone despite the intensity. Resin, citrus, and fruit tones, and the alcohol is not pronounced. Very hard to get in Washington state, and not actually worth the effort, so I opt for others.

Bottle from my buddy in Colorado- Thanks Brandon!
Smells like fresh grapefruit and hops. Bright light-orange color with a medium lacy foam. Tastes a little sweet at first, followed by tart citrus, and finishing with bitter hops. Very nice palate- very crisp and fresh tasting. Flavors of grapefruit, honey, and massive hops at the finish. I have now tasted the legend, and yes, I would love to try it again. Recommend trying Surly Abrasive for those who like Pliny.
Ive never had a better beer.  Perfect. Pours golden/amber with minimal head, decent carbonation, pine and floral nose, cant possibly be more of a smoother taste for this style/abv. Unreal good

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2013 Draught @ Russian River Brewing, Santa Rosa, CA
Pours clear deep golden with a white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, pine, citrus, orange, peach and pine. Taste is medium sweet and medium to heavy bitter with  a long piney, orange and peach finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Bottle 500ml @ RBNAG-11
Pours cloudy golden with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, pine, citrus and grassy hops. Taste is medium sweet and heavy bitter. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2012 A - Pours amber with very little white head. S - Has aromas of citrus fruits and floral piney hops, lightly grassy. Very standard ipa aromas. M - Medium carbonation with great mouth feel. Nice mellow, quite smooth for a double IPA. T - Has a nose of strong floral and spicy hops, with subtle citrus notes.On the palate the hops are grassy and piney, with some floral notes as well. Very smooth almost buttery middle, well balanced. Ends on a slightly spicy dry note. O - Great beer for the style( maybe thats why I didnt like it so much, so standard). Smooth, well rounded and subtle. 8-

The aroma of this beer isnt as strong as I thought it was going to be going into it with all of the hype.  The appearance was good, clean, crisp, good amount of carbonation.  The taste was what really brought it home.  For the number of IBUs that are in this beer it is remarkably smooth.  The fact that they were able to get the balance between the bitterness and the malt this amenable is commendable.

What a beer, everytime I have another one, I remember why I go through the trouble of getting one.  Slightly hazy gold in colour with a slight white head. Big, citrus and floral hop aromas with some caramel malts in support. Very easy drinking for the abv, with chewy, almost bready malts, apricot and tangerine fruit and a dry, slightly resinous, hoppy finish. A classic.
juicy, tropical citrus, grassy crisp hops, and solid malt sweetness balances perfectly.  I can not stress enough how well balanced this beer is.  Believe the hype!

Serving: bottle from Bushmat1.  Thanks Matt!  It pours a slightly hazy gold orange with a nice white head.  The nose is pleasantly piney with nice resin and citrus notes.  As you might imagine, the flavor is very strong on the hop side.  Lots of pine needles and resin with orange and grapefruit on the outskirts.  Medium body with average carbonation and a long, bitter finish.  Rather dry on the end.  Well rounded without being sweet or tongue rapingly bitter.  Damn good and worth the hype.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2016 Date: October 22, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Darkness Day. Full description not available as I sampled way too many beers during Darkness Day!Had this again October 31, 2011 - Bottle was less than one month old.  Translucent golden, large amount of head.  Aroma was hoppy, piney and fruity with consistent taste.  Medium bodied and smooth with very slight bitter finish.  Just amazing!

Here it is, one of the most talked-up beers on the planet.  For the DIPA style, I found it the most shining example.  It is nearly perfect in every aspect; it is beer zen in a glass.  I enjoyed a bottle which was not quite 1 month old so it was still appetizingly fresh.  On the nose, I was picking up scents of juicy pineapple, citrus rind, bready pungent hops, candied grapefruit, sappy pine (herbal and intense) and a touch of grassy bitterness.  The palate was a rich and well-blended dose of fresh hop, citrus zest, exotic bitter fruit and melon.  The beer has a beautiful amberish color with a 1 finger head that leaves intricate lacing down the glass.  This IPA is so complex and well-balanced that I am still surprised by it.  Drink it fresh.

Bottle... kindly shared by my friend hallinghansen and his wife Maria on a very pleasant day...Thx... It pours clear golden/orange with a large steady fluffy off white head.... the aroma is very fruity, grass, pine, citrus and hoppy.... the flavor is peach, citrus, pine, grapefruit and hoppy... very tasteful full body....

Bottled. Pours clear and deep golden with a medium sized white head. Nose of citrus, pineapple, caramel and notes of pine. Lovely hoppy and sweet flavor with a solid malt base with caramel, pine and fruity elements, sutch as: grapefruit, lemon and peachy notes. Medium to full bodied, creamy to oily texture and soft carbonation. Ends up more dry with a nice bitterness. A wel balanced and great brew.

An awesome pale ale, but doesnt really come off as a double. Rich golden color, full white head, Citrusy hops, slight malt, champagne in the nose. Medium to light in body with a slightly hoppy finish. Im comparing to Dreadnaught, and Dreadnaught wins. By a hair. But this is a really outstanding beer.

Remarkably clear with a sticky beige head. The nose is full of grapefruit hops. Spicy hops at first followed by pineapple, pine, grapefruit, and a chalky finish. A lingering malt sweetness, as well.

The balance and complexity are outstanding. And while its only 8% ABV, it sneaks up on you.

Its not life-changing to me, but its pretty darn good.

Orange gold color. Large head. Aroma is floral hops, fruity and sweet. A medium to full bodied Imperial IPA. Malts are fruity and sweet. Hops are grapefruity, piney, floral and citrusy. A remarkably well-balanced IPA. Malts and hops clash and balance with every sip. Hoppy and bitter yet fruity and sweet. Great hop signature. Creamy full mouthfeel. NICE beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is bitter.

Pours a rich golden hue, topped with a firm white head. The aroma was nothing like I expected, seville oranges, floral notes, a sticky resiny thing in the background, just a slight pine thing going on as well. Tastewise, again big on sweet orange, like hopped up marmelade in a glass, smooth and sweet without being syrupy. Medium-full bodied and certainly very nice.

Bottle. Pours a dark yellow color with an orange tinge to it with a white head. Aroma is of grapefruit, lots og the sweeter citrus fruits like orange and tangerine, light tropical fruits, hop juice and some subtle sweet malt notes. Flavor is quite hoppy, with a very good balance between the hop flavors and bitterness, I get loads of grapefruit, orange and tangerine, some subtle pine and resin, and some tropical fruit, along with sweet and light caramel malt backbone. The body is medium with a dry mouthfeel. Overall a really nice DIPA, but kind of dissapointed in it tbh.

50cl bottle. Orange colour with a medium big white head. Aroma is hops. Tropical fruits and some malts. Flavour is bitter, but laden with sweet malts. Hops and tropical fruits are present but the sweet malts and caramel is blended in nicely. Medium long aftertaste.

Sample @ RBNAG 11 (live rating). Light hazy orange body, medium white head. Peachy, apricot caramel double IPA niceness, hints of peaches, strawberry and grassy hops. Citric, dry grapey hints, peaches and caramel malts. Extremely balanced. Solid stuff, but perhaps not deserving the greatness it has been bestowed.

Pliny lives up to its reputation in every way as one of the most reknowed beers in the world. An Imperial IPA loaded with hops balanced out by generous amount of hops makes for one of best tasting beers out there.
Aroma of hoppy bliss.  Grapefruit, pine, lemon zest and clove.  Pours orange with a huge foamy head.  Taste is bitter with pine and strong grapefruit peel.  this is really good.

Ported from BA.

Appearance: 
Clear and golden orange with bubbles popping up. A foamy white head developed up to about 2 1/2 fingers, at which point I had to start pouring. Medium retention and some lots of lace.

Smell:
Sweet and soft with lots of citrus smells and some piney undertones. Makes me think of grapefruit and fresh apricot.

Taste:
Pine and dry grapefruit dominates, and the fresh (but not sweet) apricot aroma comes through even more. Sweet malt on the backend with low-medium bitterness, making for a pleasant balance. After a bit, most of the flavors peel off of your tongue, with the exception of the pine and pale malt.

Mouthfeel:
Medium bodied, medium but very soft carbonation. Bubbles arent at all harsh on the tongue.

Overall:
This is a really solid IPA. It isnt really overpowering in any one flavor category, and certainly tastes delicious in all of them. What youve got here is one solid beverage that I could see myself enjoying regardless of the weather. Still, bonus if a hammock is involved.

gotta thank Andrew for this one. So happy I finally got to try it. Huge grapefruity hop aroma. first sip was awesome, citrus, grapefruit, piney and grassy hops. amazing bitter after taste with an exceptionally long finish. I dont see how a Double IPA can get any better than this.

0.5l bottle from CrackedKettle web shop. What a treat! This classic, and dare I say, "king of DIPAs" pours a clouded and heavy heavy unfiltered glowing golden orange body with a nice light fluffy and slowly fading medium sized beige head. The aroma is just as expected; really hopy and grassy with lots of fruity both peach, apricot, strawberries and gooseberries. It actually can remind me a bit of that fantastic shampoo my girlfriend is using a.t.m. Flavors: Really nice! My god! This has to bee the smoothest beer Ive ever tasted. It has a average carbonation level and a mild and extremely smooth and almost creamy mouthfeel! This is truly one of those beers thats just melting on the tongue! Flavors are not to extreme at all. They just blend so nicely together with the strong and powerful bitterness from the hops and that smooth and sweet malt-base. Its leaving the mouth bitter with citrus, slightly dry and just crying out for more! What a guy and what beer!
Golden, Orange color with creamy head. Strong taste of pine needles with a hoppy, fruity taste.  Overall A great Double IPA

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2016 Bottle at CPK shared with Ed and Paul. Paul brought this - thank you! What a legend. Pours clear gold with a sturdy, white foam head. Bit of cat pee in the nose, some grass and pine. Flavor is quite multi-layered. Medium sweet. Some earthy bitterness, grass. Medium bodied with fine to average carbonation. Great finish. Keeps you thinking. So drinkable. Good pine and earth. It is just pretty flawless on most levels.

An excellent IPA. Pours a hazy, golden-yellow with a mid-sized head that dissipates rather quickly, leaving a goodly amount of lacing on the glass. Pine notes are obvious in the aroma and very present in the hoppy flavor. The beer isnt as super-bitter as some IPAs--theres a sweet underpinning that helps to balance things out somewhat, so theres a clean, refreshing finish to the beer. Some of the freshest bottled beer Ive had--tastes almost like a draft.

Being a hop lover this is one of my favourite beers, and Im lucky to be able to enjoy it all year long. The smell alone is fantastic, piney and intense. The taste is up there too, just an amazing beer. The only place I have ever had it on draught is Falling Rock in Denver.

Thanks Fred at Beverages 4 Less in Santee for this beer. It pours a orange with a yellow tinge and a half inch creamy white head. The beer laces the glass nicely as the head disappears. The aroma is wonderful. Its woody and piny and the malts add this smoky caramel smell that is sweet on the nose. The beer has a wonderful piny hop characteristic that is clean up front but finishes with a nice strong malt flavor that lingers on the palate. It doesnt taste like alcohol but has that strong bitter finish. Ultimately this hop style is not my favorite but this beer makes me want to reconsider that opinion.

Pliny hops can be immediately recognized. The lacing of this beer is present and the color in the glass transparent. The smell gives off a distinctness of pinyness. The taste seems to linger on the palate for quite some time. It is bitter in a great way. Great beer
Draught from russian river.  Shiny amber pour.   Nice hops aroma.  Earthy fruity complexity - a lovely beer.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2012 Brian the Beer Pimp is THA MAN!!!!  Pours a dark yellow, with a light head that holds around the edge.  Aroma is a very nice hoppy one.  It has a citrusy hop flavor, strong, but not overpowering.  Aftertaste leaves you begging for more!

Pours clear golden with a fair white head and some lace.  Aroma is of west coast hops, grapefruit, citrus and some floral notes.  West coast hops, citrus, very smooth, crisp and refreshing.  Light up front but a strong finish.

Bottle to snifter. Pours clear amber with a white foamy sudsey head that fades to a film and shows some lacing. Aroma is bright floral and citrus hops and caramel. Taste is resinous and bitter with florals and piney citrus hops and orange peel. Palate is medium and slick with a sticky dry finish. Awesome brew, will be keeping this a regular in the house!
Had at iron abbey beer dinner. Good bitter, hoppy ipa. Makes mouths happy.
At iron abbey beer dinner. Fruity, grapefruit, cascade, pear aroma... nice.   Taste is mango, Amarillo hops, minor bitter bite. Good, but overhyped. Reminds me of 3f dreadnought but not as good.
Had at Russian river beer dinner at iron abbey on September 21. Nice pungent odor. Creamy mouthfeel and sharp hoppy apricot flavor.

Pineapple and honey aroma with bits of whole grapefruit. Clear amber, thick, creamy cream colored head.  Surpising malt presence, with the flavor of hay dominating lesser hops of whole orange and grapefruit. Considerably less hoppy than expected. Orange peel finish, lasting but subtle. Solid, but unspectacular, especially given the hype surrounding it.

Bottle, bottled June 2011.  Poured a cloudy gold color with a thick white head.  Highly carbonated.  Aroma is bready, floral, and citrusy.  The taste is overpowered by high hop bitterness.  There is some orange flavor at the beginning but the hop  bitterness lingers throughout and actually even after I had drank the whole thing.  The balance seems a bit off though I should say that IPAs are not my favorite style.  Couldnt live up to the hype, just a good beer overall.

Sample from bottle at Dark Lord Day 12. Yes, Im still writing up notes from that event, and what better time to skip ahead a little and make this my 2300th Rating! Yep, God has put a bottle of this into view for me amid the chaos of DLD. "Bottled on Feb 24, 2011" Bright brown in my glass with very little foam, as Ive got the very end of this bottle. Smell has a nice American Pale Ale smell, Im claiming to detect Cascade and Centennial. Gets in to the orangey citrus hop territory. Taste is a little thin, but it could have gone a tough flat since the bottle was opened. Nicely hoppy. Goes down nicely, does not have the afterburn of some hops.

This beer is highly praised in the beer world. I think it is pretty good, but did not exceed expectations.  Mine was from a bottle. Poured golden with moderate head.  Strong hop front with little floral/citrusy aspects that I personally enjoy in my IPA. The amount of carbonation was ideal as it wasnt too effervescent nor too flat.  Good palate, not thin and not chewy. Very crisp finish making it an overall clean bear.

draft at falling rock $7 pt.  Pours a clear light orange gold, with nice off white froth.  Aroma is explosive, vibrant hops, some biscuit, alot of citrus and floral elements.  Flavor is very fresh hops, orange peel, very floral, with a lasting grapefruit bitterness coating the entire mouth.  There is some malt backbone but the hops predominate, as they should.  This one really has a kick and some character to it, although I dont know if its the end all be all of imp IPAs, depending on what kind of IPA you like you may think so, regardless everyone will enjoy this beer.

Very smooth for a double IPA, sweet hops, with a malty texture, medium bodied and a balanced finish. 
Great Beer!

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2011 Aroma - citrus and piney hops dominate, hefty malt in the background. Appearance - a beautiful orange, with a modest white foam, a beautiful beer. Taste - upfront is a delicious malty treat which is quickly followed by a symphony of the hops which were only hinted at in the aroma. Palate - surprisingly light and refreshing for the style of beer. Well crafted and honed. Overall - It took me awhile to get ahold of this brew and I must say the hype was well deserved. An amazing double IPA. Thanks to the fine people at Cal Heights on Orange and Bixby, an amazing little beer store in Long Beach.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2013 Bottle care of Mr Paul Unwin. Much appreciated! Pours pale orange. Nose is grapfruit citrous IPA character but with nice notes of eucalyptus, and orange blossom. Taste is grapefruit citrous, and distinctive apricot and tangerine notes. Refined and delicate for a double IPA. Very damn good.

Bottle brought to Bristol by Paul Unwin - thanks Paul! Slightly hazy gold in colour with a slight white head. Big, citrus and floral hop aromas with some caramel malts in support. Very easy drinking for the abv, with chewy, almost bready malts, apricot and tangerine fruit and a dry, slightly resinous, hoppy finish. A classic.

bottle bought from the brewery and opened in San Diego.  Hands down best DIPA i have ever had.  Everything is perfect about this beer.  Looks apricot orange with a white thick head.  Smells like a bag of whole citrus hops!  They had to have dry hopped the shit out of this beer.  Tastes perfect with a rich engulfing hoppiness that never ends.  An epic bitter bite that doesnt linger.  Enough malts to glorify the hops.  Still very drinkable.  Overall 10 of 10.
Tap.  Top notch double ipa.  Aroma of citrus and pine.  Nice resiny mouthfeel.  Well balanced.

Aroma is hoppy and sweet. Appearance is clear orange. With a small white head. Lighter and more clarified than expected. Taste is strong centennial and very earthy. It can be a bit grassy at times. This beer really succeeds in the very smooth and full mouth-feel. Doesnt dissapoint even after all the hype.

Im sure we all know about pliny by now. Aroma is citrusy hops with a hint of resin and spice. Appearance is kind of boring, clear/ yellow light head. Taste is bitter with a tiny hint of malt. Palate is moderate. Overall it is definitely a good beer.

On tap at Stone Brewery. Classic slightly dark amber pour with clean, slightly thick white head which leaves a solid opaque lacing. Aroma is understated hops in comparison to the palate, where the hops really come through. Not overpowering but tasty and kind of sparkling.good carbonation. Very good IPA - I could see liking this even if I were not huge on hoppy beers.

Pours clear gold with huge white head.  Good head retention. Aroma is citrus hops with tons of grapefruit.  Taste is a hop explosion in your mouth with a lot of upfront citrus flavors, good firm hop bitterness throughout, and has a nice malt backbone to balance.  One of the best beers out there for hopheads.

Snifter at the Collins Pub. Bitter sweet aroma. Big citrus, grapefruit mainly. Little caramel, orange. Hazed brownish orange color. Small head minor lace. Bitter flavor. Medium body, smooth oily mouthfeel bitterly finish. Good overall. Very east to drink,
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: 16.9 bottle shared with 3..beautiful aroms of citrus and piney hops. the orangish yellow beer with a white head that dissipates after several minutes. the flavor of the beer is no less than perfect. the bitterness of the hops is so subdued that you just drink its delicious goodness with the flavor of citrus and pine hops so well balanced. did i say this was great.

Big murky yellow and orange.  Full citrus, pine, and some malt sweetness.  Some nice, hard pine and citrus hop bitterness reinforced by a stiff malt backbone.  Plenty of lemon zest.  Nice full mouthfeel for a DIPA.  Residual pine.  Very, very nice.

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2011 Bottle in tulip glass. Strong aroma that you can smell billowing out of the bottle -  hops, citrus, mowed lawn, grass. Bitter citrus and hops flavour. Kind of cloudy orange colour. Nice bitter sweet flavour.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2014 500ml bottle from Cracked Kettle. Noticed they had only one bottle left so I just had to buy it, even though it was quite expensive (14,99)
Bottled on 06/29/11 - Pours orange with a small foamy and sticky head. Strong aroma of fruity hops and malts with notes of citrus. Taste is quite malty with loads of fresh, fruity hops and citrusy notes. Quite bitter, not as sweet as many American IIPAs. Finish is smooth and dry with a long lasting bitterness. Alcohol warms slightly but is quite well hidden. Excellent, extremely well balanced Imperial IPA. 8-4-9-4-16 = 4.1



Re-rated @ the brewpub 10.5.2014. Awesome fresh hoppy aroma, loads of citrus, resin and grass. Lovely fresh hoppy taste and a lingering bitter finish. Oh man, this is good.

Just outstanding.  Few things can live up the levels of hype this beer has surrounding it, but it is well deserved in this case.

The other 1500 reviews do a better job of describing the attributes of this beer than I could possibly hope to.  Ill just say its a fantastic, perfectly balanced beer.  If you like IPAs, its a must try.  If you dont like IPAs, this beer might change your mind.

Bottle. Nice light amber color with a light snowy head. Nose of mostly bitter hops with light grapefruit notes. Taste was quite sweet with a citrus burst in the middle and a long spicy bitter finish. Crisp and effervescent on the palate with a slight astringency.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2011 Poured into a pint glass from a draft at The San Diego Brewing Company in San Diego, Calif. Light head, maybe ½ inch. Lots of lacing that lasted the whole way. Same with the film on the side of the glasses. Really a good look. 

Lots of rich flavors on the nose. First smells that come to mind are citrus, pine and grapefruit. Lots of hops.

First taste was hops. Second was the grapefruit/pine combination, before giving way to a smooth alcohol bite/bitterness ending. 

A great balance and very smooth for just a hoppy beer. Very refreshing that had me looking forward to the next sip. 

I was psyched when I saw it on tap at SDBC, since we were there only five days before and it wasnt. This beer definitely lived up to the reputation. What a wonderful beer!

I am going to need to retry this beer from another location.  Ordered this on tap from the Taphouse in Seattle during IPA week August 12, 2011.  Pale hazy color but overly bitter.  I was unable to taste anything but the overpowering hoppiness.  Being rated in the top 10 leads me to believe that I was either served the wrong selection or it was skunked.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2013 After several fresh Plinys on both bottle and tap, I have to adjust my rating. This simply has to be the best and most balanced IPA out there! Body is golden, only slightly hazy, with fairly big and rich head. Aroma is hoppy goodness. Citrus, pine, herbs, tropical fruits (pineapple, passion fruit). Taste is equally hoppy, but what I really like about this beer is how it balances out towards the end. The finish is fairly rich but not overly long or bitter. Its got some malty sweetness to the end, but it never gets too much as it can with some DIPAs. In a way, I think more of this as a very balanced IPA rather than as a DIPA. Love the text on the label - theres no way youll miss the fact that this is supposed to be had fresh. :-D

Bottle. About one month old, but spent half of that time in the fridge. Big thanks to my good friend Greg for giving me a bottle on my visit back to California.

I really feel like my summer allergies are keeping me from enjoying this beer as much as I should. The aroma is a little weaker than expected. Full of those Northwestern hops we love so much, but not really dancing off the glass like a beer with this much hops should. Poured a crystal-clear true gold, which I suppose is apropos for this beer.

Flavor is a lot sweeter than expected. It really balances out the intense hops well. 8% ABV, 90-something IBU, and still very quaffable. This speaks to the mastercraft on display here.

Overall, I get what all the hype is about, but just. This beer didnt change my life and Im not going to quit my job, leave my fiancee and move to Santa Rosa, but this definitely vaults in to the upper echelon of IPAs and IIPas Ive had along with Three Floyds Alpha King, Boulevard Double Wide, and Racer 5.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2012 500 ml bottle at home, bottled 110802, so its 18 days old. Clear, golden liquid with medium, long persisting off-white head. Aroma is hoppy with notes of pine, spruce, fresh and herbal hops, lemongrass, grapefruit, tropical fruit, passionfruit, tangerine, mango and some light, sweet malt that helps balance it. Really well balanced. Taste is also hoppy with notes of pine, fresh hops, tangerine and grapefruit. Very light sweetness and high bitterness. Balanced. Medium bodied with nice carbonation. Really nice balance. 8/4/9/4/19 
Re-rating 2012-07-09. Draught at Blue Palms. Clear, deep golden liquid with medium, long lasting off-white head. Aroma of grapefruit, citrus, lemongrass, mango, passionfruit, biscujit, caramel malt and grass. Really nicely balanced. Taste is light sweet and medium bitter with grassy, citrusy notes and a nicely malty backbone. Medium bodied with medium carbonation and really smooth. Perfect for an IPA. Even better on tap. +1 on palate.

Finally found at Whole Foods in La Jolla.  Pours a beautiful straw color, small white head.   Aroma is very hoppy.  Flavor is slightly different from what I expected based on the aroma.  The hops have a more earthy flavor. The bitterness is there, but very nicely balanced. It is smooth, very enjoyable.

Galveston, TX -- Bottle

Still somewhat of a novice but I had a chance to try this hard-to-find treasure. Decent beer but I dont think I would seek it out personally.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2013 Served on-tap into a snifter at TJs 7th anniversary party. Not the first time I have had this one but still one of the best.


A - Pours deep, hazy, orange with a small cap of white head that stays strong throughout the entire glass leaving thick lacing down the glass.


S - Strong piney, citrus, hops hit you full blast. A bit of sweetness from the malt helps balance it out but once it begins to warm up, more and more hops keep coming out. Absolutely intoxicating.


T - Starts with a bit of pale malts giving way quickly to a massive onslaught of citrus hops. Finish is a bit sweet with lingering hop biternes. I have had this beer quite a few times now and it is still one of the best beers I have ever had. One of the best DIPAs out there.


M - Medium body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Tons of hop bitterness in the finish that lingers for some time. Very good but it could be a tiny bit better.


O - I think I could drink this every day for the rest of my life. With out a doubt one of the best DIPA on the market today. My personal favorite, thats for sure. I am so glad I live near philly.

It is as good as advertised IF it is consumed within 30 days. Anything older falls off at a rapid rate. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This obviously is a well regarded beer.  The only thing I could critique is the lack of a well developed aroma, but it could be since I had it from a glass as opposed to tap.  Appearance is beautifully golden orange, taste is distinct and refreshing.  If you are not in to Bitter than stay away but otherwise enjoy the journey for this well made vintage.

The long hyped Pliny. This is a really good beer, and really one of the best examples of a great West-coast style IPA, and by West-Coast i mean has alot of Pine flavors in the hop profile. There is a good amount of Citrus and tropical flavors hidden down in there too, but they need to climb over some sticky sap resin to get out from under the covers.

Thanks to my good friend Stan in San Diego for sending this my way!  Poured beautiful yellow-orange color with lacy white head.  Some citrus and a little bit of pine at first, which grew in intensity as I let this warm up a little bit.  Amazing balance and very smooth.  Really nice hop flavor, nice aftertaste that lingered just the right amount of time.  Delicious and I wish I had another.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2012 500 ml bottle. Happy IPA day 4.8.2011!
Pours a beautiful golden colour with a slightly off-white head. Strong aroma of fresh, floral hops, citrus and exotic fruits. Rich flavour of crispy floral hops, exotic fruits such as pineapple and passion fruits, lemon and a malty backbone. Long, crispy, bitter finish with exotic fruits. Extremely high drinkable despite the 8% ABV. Almost my favourite DIPA. 9-4-9-4-16 4.2
Draught @ the brewpub, Santa Rosa. Rated on 20.10.2012.
Pours a rich copper golden colour with a strong lacy head. Aroma is really intense with peachy floral hops, caramel and grapefruit. Flavour is full-on massively bitter with floral hops, grapefruit, juicy peach and alcohol. Full bodied, oily mouthfeel and a very rich, bitter, lingering and also warming finish. A top notch hop juice like no other.

Bottled (~1 month old). Slightly cloudy orange color, thin but lacy white head. Aroma loaded with hops: lots of citrusfuits, herbal resins, mango, strawberry and honeyish floral notes. Dryish, slightly biscuity maltines with a touch of light caramel. Drier than your average DIPA. Intense bitterness throughout, resiny and woody hop bite in the finish with sweeter fruitiness. Medium to full bodied, very smooth and soft palate. Dangerously drinkable beer.
Ive had a few pints on tap and a few bottles. One of the freshest tasting beers Ive ever had on tap! Aromas of pine and hops. This was the beer that opened me up to wonderful world of IPAs!

Una gran doble ipa!!Muy balanceada en todos los aspectos,muy buena aroma, a mucho dry hopping centennial,simcoe....muy buena a todas horas.recomiendo beberla lo mas fresca posible!!en tirador espectacular!!

Bottle at home. Pours orange-yellow with a  golden haze. Carbonation is medium and the mouthfeel is pleasant with a caramel sweetness and a a lot of hop-related flavors. Lots of grapefruit, lots of piney. The bitterness is present, but well backed by the sweetness. Very good.

50 cl bottle. Rated on 27.02.2010
Very much resin in the aroma, also some citrus and exotic fruits. Not too sweet taste with lots of hops. Flavour has some grassy citrus and exotic fruits. Rather complex beer with a very great balance!

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2011 On tap at Brouwers for Hopfest, pours a pale cloudy copper with a thick creamy head. Aroma of citrus fruits, piney hops and resin. Flavour has lots of pine, resin, lots of malt backing, with a little butterscotch. Amazingly full-bodied and complex. Incredible.

I like bitter beers but this one was truly exceptional. One American who was visiting Belgium had one in his backpack and while talking about triples and IPAs he suggested to open a bottle of Pliny. Wonderful experience. I was truly surprised by the freshness of this beer.

The key to this beer is that it is balanced.  Great notes of citrus up fron and on the palate that drives to a nice agressive but yet nuanced blend of hops and malt.  it also provides a nice long finish.

Got a bottle at a convinience store in Dublin, Northern California. Brought it with me to the Philippines to let our beer club try one of the highest rated imperial ipas online. Appearance:Golden Orange Color with very nice thick head with nice lacing. Smell: Citrusy orange peel, floral hops with subtle hints of pine. Taste: Initial hoppy taste with grapefruit taste then balanced with sweet malts until it ends with a very bitter-hoppy finish. The most well balanced taste of bitter hops and sweet malt with very smooth finish I tried.
Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied, Very smooth, Crisp and well-carbonated. Drinkability: The best Imperial IPA I tried bought at a very affordable price. If this beer was available, Ill buy and consume it everyday of my life.
Pours beautifully out of the glass. I was pleasantly surprised that it was not too overwhelming in the aroma and the finish was exquisite. A well balanced and complete beer.

pours clear amber with a lasting white head and plenty of lacing.  Complex aroma of citrus, pine and maple.  body is full with low carbonation.  Taste is very hoppy but well balanced against caramel notes.  Finish is bitter and slightly warming.  a lovely, near perfect beer.

It pours a clean copper color with a decent sized off-white head that leaves some great lacing throughout the glass. Oh my God this smells amazing! Theres a smell of cirtus, floral and piney hops a great grapefruit scent with some pineapple and other tropical fruits and even a little bit of peach, theres even some sweet maltiness that sneaks in, they need to make a cologne and perfume that smells like this beer! The taste is equally amazing, the big combination of citrus, floral and piney hops come in beautifully with the tropical fruits theres a slight malty sweetness that combines with the sweetness of the tropical fruit that balances perfectly with the hoppiness. The mouthfeel is amazing, its sticky its thick and satisfying yet its smooth and refreshing the alcohol is nearly nonexistant except for a slight warmth. Overall this beer is amazing and I cannot find a single flaw about this beer.

Amber color with lots of lacing. Offwhite head. Aroma of hops and fruit: mango and lychee. Taste is bitter, fruity hoppy, some sweetness, bitter aftertaste. Creamy medium thick mouthfeel, medium carbonation.
Excellent! This is just the kind of beer I like.

On tap at Toronado. Pale yellow and off white head. Giant fresh hops, grass, and pine. Amazing creamy mouthfeel, nice carbonation, supremely balanced, huge hops without overwhelming bitterness which is hard to achieve, so smooth, huge depth and finish that makes you smack your lips. Could not get over the balance - what a great beer.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2017 Re-rate 170218
Pours clear golden with medium high white head
Aromas brilliantly hoppy of pineapples, citrus, mango, pine, resin caramel
Taste has hoppy notes of pineapples, mango, citrus, hints of passionfruit, stonefruits, caramel, resin, pine.
Mouthfeel is lingering, medium bodied, well hidden alcohol, medium bitter ending. The perfect DIPA

---

This is by far the best IPA Ive had. Hard in words to explain the wonderfulness of this. It has the perfect palate balance. Wonderful hoppyness and marvellous aromas
whoa. the most beautiful smelling beer i ever had. stinks of candied citrus. taste of deep and refined pine. how do they make this beer? just breathtakingly amazing.

So, we finally meet.  From a really, really fresh bottle courtesy of wunderbeer (of an unnamed website).  I had high expectations and high wariness of this beer, but I soon found out... the hype is real.  Best IPA, double IPA, whatever, that Ive tasted, and Im not an IPA guy.  But I really liked this one.  Oh well, a very special treat!
