Natürlich hopfiger Antrunk. Deutlich fruchtig, vollmundig, außerordentlich aromatisch. Die Bitterkeit hält sich auch im Abgang eher zurück, ist aber natürlich dennoch reichlich vorhanden. /12/12/12/9/12

Bottle. Pours a nice "this-is-an-IPA-worth-drinking" gold. Complex hop aromas are to die for. The balance on this guy is baffling - so perfect - drinkable yet complex, hoppy and malty, bitter yet fruity. How is this 8%? Utterly dangerous. Words are ill-equipped to describe the joys this beer brings. I am no beer guru, so 18/20 is all this will get for now, but as time passes I would not be surprised if I concede that the best has just been had.

Medium offwhite head. Yellow body with strong carbonation. Grassy apricot and pineapple aroma with citric spicy notes. Sweet-dry apricot, mango, and grass taste with pineapple and alcohol notes. Fullish body. Soft, mild mouthfeel. Bitter pineapple and peaches aftertaste with resiny citrus notes. Excellent. Full of flavour, yet highly drinkable. (0.5l bottle at Beer Revolution, Oakland.)

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2013 4/XI/13 - 1Pt. 1.25 Fl. Oz. bottle @ home - bottled: X/14/13 (2013-xxx) Thanks to Dieter for sharing the bottle!
Note: a re-rating, just because I can! :p
Clear dark orange beer, big creamy irregular white head, little stable, adhesive, leaving a nice lacing in the glass. Aroma: very piny, citrus, lots of pineapple, bit floral, zesty, grapefruit. MF: ok carbon, medium body. Taste: lots of citrus, floral notes, grapefruit, zesty, citrus, floral notes, grapefruit, zesty, lemony, piny bitterness, resinous hops, pineapple, bit of passion fruits. Aftertaste: bit sourish, citrus, zesty, lemon, very bitter, resinous, bit soapy, minty touch in the end.

13/06/2011 1pint bottle @ Klaas place - bottled: 15/04/11 (2011-261)  Thanks to Klaas for sharing the bottle!
Pretty clear orange beer, small white creamy head. Aroma: marijuana upon opening the bottle, then very fruity, passion fruits, pineapple, pine trees. MF: ok carbon, full body, creamy texture. Taste: very fruity, some citrus, passion fruits, bit sweet. Aftertaste: bitter, turning a bit dry, still very fruity, bit of wood.

The generous hoping gives this beer a musky-floral aroma. Beautiful amber color. The taste begins with a malty creamyness, leads into an earthy hop character, and finishes with a citrus note.  Even with all of the hype, this beer did not disappoint.

Big thanks to Trappistlover for this one! Reviewed from notes.

A: Very nice golden honey color.

S: Wonderful pine even some honeycomb in there. Pretty hoppy to me.

T: Dirty and dank. Big let down. This was a fresh bottle and I wanted to love this beer based off of the ratings but just didnt care for the dirty hop flavor. Enjoyed the Blind Pig way more.

M: Nice, good carbonation and body but the taste was something I never want to endure again.

O: Not my cup of tea but to each his/her own. I would seek out Blind Pig before Pliny the Elder, but Ive heard great things about the Younger :)

Just an excellent beer. If I was trapped on a desert island and could only bring one beer with me for the rest of my life, this would probably have to be it. Easy to drink, tastes great. Great hops, but not too hoppy.
Bottle shared -A yellow orange pour -white head -aroma and taste of pine,citrus, perfect balance of taste and has a smooth finish

Pours a golden color with a hint of orange, white head with little lacing, and fairly clear, maybe hazy.  Wonderful aroma of grapefruit and lemon notes.  Hops just oozing from the aroma.   Taste is a delicious balance between the malts and hops.  Not too sweet and with some bitterness but not a biting taste.   The palate is almost creamy it is so smooth, with a long dry finish.  Overall, this is one really good beer.  It is so smooth and the flavors blend so well.  No alcohol taste at all and it goes down so easily.

On tap at Isaac Newtons. Strong lemon aroma with piney undertones especially as it warms. Bitterness quite pronounced but this is an amazingly well controlled beer, and so much flavor in 8 percent. Although I like a more balanced beer than what Id tasted, I certainly enjoyed this beer thoroughly.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2012 Great IPA.  The taste was amazingly smooth with strong citrusy hop flavors.  Outrageously drinkable with the perfect clean finish.  If I could easily get this stuff it would always be in my fridge/cellar.  Fantastic.
Thanks Gatorgay for the share.  Certainly too hoppy for me.  This was a few months old, was told this really drops off after a month.  Nice DIPA thou, just not my thing.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2011 500ml bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  Bottled on 3/29/11.
Dull orange brew with a sticky off white head.  Smells exactly like a DIPA should - pineapple, resin, and pine trees.   Wonderful balance of oily hop bitterness and malt sweetness with a very chewy mouthfeel.  Wasnt sure if this would stand up to all its hype but it very much does.

nose is mellow, bittersour hops, weak grape and hay and a round sweet fruit finish, feel is quite broad and velvety, carb is mediumlow, taste is balanced, heavy hops bite with a warm round alcohol and green apple freshness. finish is weak barnyard

It has a crisp hoppy taste. Wonderful aroma of full hops, great lacings. This beer had a cloudy haze. It was great, but to be fair we didnt quite drink it as fresh as we could - I hear its better when its consumed as soon as possible.

Poured from the pint bottle into a etched pint glass. Pours really clear, nice white head with great lacing. The aroma is pleasant, I would say pine, and grass and very fresh. Flavour is not as bitter as I would Imagine. Ive heard Russian River estimates this beer @ 200 IBU. But its definitely not there, Sierra Nevadas Hoptimum is hoppier. Very smooth for 8% and being a Double IPA. Mouth feel is medium bodied, and wet up front, then finishes bitter and slightly dry. I think this is a very well balanced IPA that is quite enjoyable.

A little cloudy but only a tiny bit, bright tiger orange and a creamy, lasting head. The nose is fresh with a dusty English hop character on the nose with a little asparagus pee. Its smooth and beautiful, puffy and light. The malt character is sweet and mingles well with the dry and spiky hops. The hop herbiness lasts, long and peppery. So drinkable, weird for 8%. Perfectly balanced.
the quintessential double ipa. Vinnie knows how to make beer. resinous, piney citrus. a great beer that should be enjoyed fresh. this bottle is nine days old.  yeah i got lucky and found some.

The only beer I like better than HopSlam!!
All descriptions are like HopSlam with one major exception that causes PtE to stand out: The lack of any honey. The fruit smell and taste stands out completely and makes this wonderful!!
I have 12 new April bottles on their way here to enjoy!! I totally recommend Pliny, right up there with my other favs HopSlam and Bud Chelada (seriously)

I cant believe I have never rated this beer. On tap at Monks. Pours a beautiful golden straw color with slight head that dissipates quickly. The nose is beautiful with floral hops. First sip is perfection with slight piney, cannabis, and bitternes balanced well with the exact right amount of malt. Finish is clean and make you want more and more. Hall of fame wo

16.9oz bottle c/o thome50, bottled 3.29.11 and enjoyed shortly thereafter.  Pours clear, light orange and gold-colored, with a 2-finger fluffy off-white head.  The aroma is sweet pine needles, sap, sugar-coated citrus peel, and bready malt.  Very nice.  The flavor is bitter grapefruit peel and pine, lightly sweet orange and orange seeds, and bitter piney hops in the finish.  Pine and citrus lend toward a lingering bitter aftertaste.  Medium carbonation and body, verging on creamy, and insanely drinkable.  This is a really good beer, I would drink this every day if given the chance.  Thanks Justin!  [683]

Bottle.  Though Ive had the opportunity to taste this on tap, I didnt rate it.  From what I can remember the tap version was a bit nicer.  Anyway. Two-fingers of slightly off-white head.  Dank hoppiness with grapefruits, citrus and herbal aromas devoid of sweetness. Flavor is a bit more balanced than the aroma and on top of the aggressive hoppiness, there is an undercutting slight sweetness that rounds it out before a really nicely dry finish. Thinner to medium body and a little slick. Wish I had access to this regularly, and am jealous of those who do.

Bottle. Pours amber with an off white head. Aroma is grapefruit and simcoe hops. Flavor is alot of piney simcoe up front and fading into a more bitter grapefruity citrus flavor...not a huge hop bite. Medium body with good heat for an ipa.

This has to be one of the best beers Ive ever had. It pours from tap golden with an inch of foam and leaves some lacing. Nose smells like a pine forest. Full citrus hop flavor on the tongue without any bitterness. Ive never had a double IPA that was so easy to drink. It has some linger to it. Fantastic!

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2013 Original rating:
Orange golden colour, firm off-white head.
Very pronounced hoppy aroma. Floral and grapefruit. Cascade, citra and Amarillo? Very pleasant to say the least. Nice malty touch.
Some malt sweetness, but mostly very pronounced hops in the taste, though surprisingly restrained. The overkill of hops definitely helps the aroma. The smell is brilliant, it circulates through your mouth. Pine, grapefruit, tree blossoms. Finish is very hoppy and very long lasting. Here the sheer amount of hops is really noticeable, for quite a while it even overshadows everything you eat or drink after it.
(from 0,5L bottle, thanks for sharing to RM and to Pete Slosberg and Californian friends who we met at DDvdK. Btw, if you ever encounter Petes beer malt chocolates, dont hesitate and taste them ;)
Update: 21 May 2011:
Tasting 2nd bottle I stand by my first notes, but wonder how I can have missed the pronounced lychee in both smell and flavour.

Update: 12 May 2013:
Compared in a tasting of three fresh double IPAs, head to head with fresh Borg Úlfur Úlfur and De Dochter van de Korenaar Extase, all bottled in April 2013. Pliny was the most bitter one, though not by a great margin. I am surprised to say there is no clear winner. I was maybe expecting the Pliny blowing the competition away, but the other two stood their ground and shone brilliantly.  That, or my tastebuds are getting used to being bombarded with hop oils. Great beers, nice tasting!
OVERRATED. lacking in body and mouthfeel. this is a top 10 beer? not in my book.

Pours a golden color with the absolute perfect head.  This is pretty much what I measure every other DIPA against for color.  The aroma is almost overpowering when fresh and has tons of pine and hops for that almost fresh cut grass smell.  The taste is a nice hop smash to the taste buds and lets you know it is there with pine, citrus and a great bitter finish.  A great medium body that stays just long enough.  This is not the be all and end all of beer as many would have you believe but it is damned good.  The only time Ive ever been let down with this is after having a glass of PtY and thinking, "wow, something made PtE come back to earth."
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: 1 pint bottle.  Pours a beautiful golden amber color, pearly white head, great lacing too.  Aroma is piney hops.  Flavor is outstanding, probably the freshest hop flavor Ive tasted.  Fresh hops up front, with a nice malty backside.  Palate is perfect for an IPA, on the heavier side, but it suits this perfectly.  Overall an incredible beer.  Thanks to my friend Eddy from Santa Rosa for this one!

Rating #600, thanks to zdk for sharing. Pours clear gold with one finger of foamy beige head that laces nicely. Outstanding hop aroma, lots of pine and resin along with some herbal notes and a hint of grapefruit. Also a bit of malt and caramel, but the hops drown them out for the most part. Flavor is still more bitter, resinous, hops, with a very faint malt component. Long, bitter, hoppy finish. I will admit that I was a little bit disappointed by this beer, but only because my expectations were so high. Its still an outstanding DIPA, just wasnt quite as earth-shattering as I expected. I would love to try it fresh and see if my opinion changes.

Very good, but not epic. I liked this beer for its lovely piney aroma and well balanced flavors. It makes sense that this appeals to a wide range of beer lovers and has received such good marks across the board. However, I was really expecting more due to the hype. Theres nothing really over-the-top about this beer. The Pliny E. seems to do everything well, but nothing really off the charts, according to my palate.  I drank it with a friend who was equally nonplussed. In all fairness we both enjoy massive beers that go out on a limb to impress at the risk of offending a more sensible taste. Still, not too shabby a beer.

Bottle, pours pristine gold w/ thick creamy head, HUGE bouquet of floral hops, pineapple, and light vanilla, flavor is crackery, nutty malt followed by massive hoppiness without destroying the palate, pleasant lasting warmth, an incredible DIPA, truly worthy of the acclaim

500 mL bottle courtesy of Chris, tasted side-by-side with Great Divide Hercules Double IPA at a tasting with Chris and Dan. Served in a goblet. Pours clear golden with a small white head. The head slowly fades, leaving behind a small amount of fine lace. The nose has a beautiful lemon-citrus aroma, with huge flowers, perfume, grape and apple. The flavour is dry and bitter with a big floral quality, fruit and citrus. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a smooth, creamy texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a beautiful double IPA. It has the nicest nose I have ever encountered in the style and is very subtle and complex. Amazing! 2011-04-16
Had this at the brewery.  Very hoppy and yet smooth and dry.  I love this one.

Yes, perfect score.  I cant find a single thing wrong with this beer.  It poured a beautiful golden brown with a nice fluffy head.  Smells stongly of a variety of hops and tastes just fantastic.  The hype around this beer is definitely true.

Pours golden yellow with little head. Smells of wonderful pine, grapefruit, tangarine, and some honey. Wow fresh grapefruit, mango, pine and some caramel. What a nice bitter hoppy explosion. Mouthfeel is oily and thick! The finish is quite long and bitter but very easy to drink. This definitely lives up to all the hype!
hops, pine, grapefruit. gold color with light head. hops, grapes, pine oak. palate was a little weak.

The gold standard.
Until someone improves upon perfection, this beer stands alone as the single greatest beer ever made on the west coast.  Bold statement, but in my opinion no one comes close to this marvel.
Perfect in every way as long as you get it fresh and those who handled it, did so with care and cold.
The younger is great but not totally drinkable over any period of time.  Blind Pig is fantastic in every way but just cant deliver the punch that Pliny does.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2013 Have had this from the bottle 3 times and on draft once. Every time was very different. Pale golden pour with a thin off-white head. Aroma is hoppy, grapefruit, pine, floral, grassy, very clean and just a touch wheaty. Taste is pine, wheat, grapefruit; very earthy, crisp and clean. Beautiful lacing. Medium carbonation. Full mouth feel. Fantastic as an archetypal IPA. But in a world filled with IPAs, I feel like this is over-hyped. Still good.
Pours a solid golden orange with a thick white head. Aroma is grapefruit, pineapple, peach, white oak. Taste is much of the same. Not so better in the backend. Overall an excellent ipa

Bottle thanks to Scrizzz. Pours a golden color with a small white head. Nose is full of pine, hops, citrus with a touch of sweetness. Flavors are nice and floral hoppy flavors, citrus, little bit bitterness, get a hint of lychee as well, with a bit of sweetness coming out in the end and the flavors linger for a while. Also nice and dry. Great DIPA.

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2013 Had at The Monks private tasting. Stoked they opened this one. Cant thank them enough. Has a clear yellow pour with a thin white head around the rim. Aroma was akin to a pine forest with hops all over the ground. Very woody and piney with lots of bitterness. Leaves were there as well. Very distinct nose. Again, this massive pine comes to play in the taste. Pine and big citrus go on and on. Taste of freshly cut grapefruit and citrus fruits with hop resin and tangerines lingering. Too easy to drink at 8%. Mouth feel was a little thin unfortunately. Great beer to have had though

This is a beer that Ive heard so much about and finally had the opportunity to taste. Quite a pale colour, the aroma is chock full of great hop aroma and character. With this much hop aroma the hops start to take on different characteristics and added layers of flavour and aroma. There is no doubt that this is a special beer and a priviledge to drink it.

What can I say that hasnt been said?

This beauty has all the citric, strawberry, and piny esters in exquisite balance like the other top echelon DIPAs, but its the incredibly floral (geranial) quality of the hops that really sets it apart. Absolutely sublime.

Serving type: bottle

Split a 500ml bottle with a friend today, bottle dated 3-21-11

The aroma hops are the star of this show.  Highly aromatic, with the main character being a citrusy, piny hop blast.

Not overbearingly bitter for the true hopaholic, but quite bitter nonetheless and even against a robust malt profile, the bitterness takes over quite a bit.

For the style, it has everything a double IPa should have.  A robust malt profile to take the edge off the extreme hoppiness, a full mouthfeel owing to the high gravity and a beautiful white head with great retention owing to the high gravity and heavy hopping.  

Alcohol is barely detectable.  A great beer to drink a small glass of, or eat a meal with, but it does wreak some havoc on the palate if you drink too much.  

If you like double IPAs, youll love this beer.  And if you like IPAs but find the doubles to be overbearing, this beer is somewhere between the two styles so it shouldnt be too much to handle if you like hoppy pale ales or IPAs.  If youre not big on hops however, stay away.  This brew isnt as over the top as many IIPAs, but it remains a resinous, syrupy hop blast.

For 200th review I wanted a good and I found it. Thanks to Wavers1 for the super fresh bottle. Pour was golden orange with off white head see through in glass with outstanding lacing. Aroma resiny hops, grapefruit, pine, tangerine, and a touch of sweetness. Taste was like getting hit in the face with a 50 lbs bag of hops. Outstandingly bitter, pine, floral, citrus, resiny hops, grapefruit, pineapple, tangerine. With a quaffability like no other DIPA I have ever had this beer is at a whole different level. MF was medium sticky and chewy with full mouth coating bitter greatness and had a fine fizzy carb. Overall is this beer a hype or something that others have said is good so everyone just agrees? No this beer absolutely is the real deal. I could drink swim or shower in this 365 days a year. It is my absolute pleasure to score this beer without flaw something that I havent done before and may never do again. Cheers to the best Russian River you guys rock!!!

Beer poured a bottle dated 10/08/09, so its a month old. Pretty good for a trade (THANKS!). Beer served in a goblet. Beer is yellow and hazy, carbonation is mild to moderate. A white head of medium sized bubbles formed but the head collapsed. There is some lacing left on the glass, even after the head collapses. Head gravitates toward the walls of the glass.

Beer has that sweet pine smell of hops. This is a double IPA but I dont smell any malt really. Not any alcohol either.

This beer tastes wonderful. The hops are obvious but the beer overall is so smooth, its amazing. Some of these hop bombs leave an acidic taste in the back of the mouth. Finishes cleanly but the beer in general leaves a film all over you mouth. Second taste, its almost as if it finishes dry but starts wet. The beer isnt dry at all, but its finish is so nice.

Mouthfeel is great. There is plenty of flavor to connect some (the tiny amount) of sweetness at the front with the hop bitterness and flavor. Its so good. Medium body, cant taste the alcohol at all. Drinkability very high. This is one of the best DIPAs Ive ever had in my life. I wish this were sold locally. If you cant get it locally, set up a trade to get this beer.

Serving type: bottle

Sampled at Nashville Beer Summit 1.22.11 - I heard some people state that the bottle wasnt totally freshy fresh. Still very very good but not at peak when its really fresh. Anyway, this beer still was very good and supremely drinkable. I enjoyed it immensely and could drink a case at a sitting. Again I disgress. Yellow transparent in color. Lighter than I would have expected. Spicy hops on the nose. Clean spicy. Refreshing. Soap and citrus. Love those 2 together. Tasty beer.

A-pours a hazy golden color with a thick two and a half fingers of white head that has solid retention and leaves a nice lacing on the glass

S-the nose is a little on the light side but provides a great subtle hop presence of grapefruit and bitterness with a touch of caramel sweetness.  the aromas are well balanced and nice, nothing that isnt perfectly integrated.

T-the taste is so well integrated and smooth.  the flavors really just play together and nothing seems out of touch at all.  the hops are strong, lots of grapefruit and notes of pine.  hints of malt underneath with a touch of sweet caramel but this is a minor presence to present the perfect balance for a hop lover.

M-lighter body but still full feel, not thin, soft on the palate with a creamy note up front and lively carbonation in the back.  hint of driness and very crisp clean finish.

D-the hop flavors are in perfect proportion, nothing stands out and creates an unpleasant hop flavor.  the grapefruit is so smooth and the malt is light but just present enough to allow this to be extremely drinkable.  this is a world class beer, one of the best around.

This beauty pours a pale dark gold, Id say almost peach in color with a nice white head that disapears quickly. Lacing is ok, not special.

It smells like a typical IPA, citrusy, and hoppy. The hoppy seems sweeter than normal and notes of apricots. 

The taste is very smooth and the bitter IPA ending is the best and most memorable Ive had. It begs you have more and experience it again and again. Its so resfreshing and rewarding, simply one of the best Ive had.

Wow, was this ever worth the effort to get this fresh up to Canada!  Im a big fan of Central City Red Racer IPA, but this had a little something extra.  Almost a candy like grapefruit aroma and taste to it.  Is this really 8%?  It doesnt taste like it, but I do have that alcohol contentness!  I cant get over the aroma.  Maybe the best Ive had.  Not sure if I would pay this much for one of these again, but I do look forward to tracking one down in the near future.  Cheers!

resiney hop  aroma with some sweet floral hops in there as well slight grass the most delicious sweet caramel malt flavor as well appearance is an amber golden the hop flavor starts off slightly  bitter then goes to the sweet malt flavor, yet the hop bitterness stays prevelant throughout the entire taste and the sweet malt leaves and leaves you with a citrus piney refreshing hop bitterness that is perfectly balanced with the malt, amazing beer

Pours a golden color with aroma a floral aroma and hoppy smell.  Taste is bitter with lasting aftertaste of hops and grass.  After all the hype I had heard from this beer, I am not impressed.  To me, this beer was not impressive.
Gold pour with medium white head. Aroma is floral and citrus hops. Very hoppy. Flavor is sweet floral and grassy-crisp hops. Full nice mouthfeel, bitter finish. Great but not earth shattering.

Growler courtesy of NorCalgrowler. Pours a brilliant gold, with a nice lasting white head that leaves plenty of lacing. Aroma is huge citrusy hops, with a little malt sweetness behind it. Body is light, and crisp. Flavor is incredibly bitter, but not sticky or resiny. Huge citrusy hops, with a little pineapple. Nice crisp malt sweeetness behind it all. Had a few bottles of this that left me wondering why all the hype. Fresh from RR tap, fantastic! Hype well deserved.

[500ml bottle courtesy of cgarvieuk] Clear golden pour with a fluffy white head. Aromas of strong pine hop and a touch of tropical fruit with some grapefruit as well. Slightly sweet on the palate before the pine hop bitterness arrives, but neither overwhelms the other. Incredibly well balanced for an 8%er  so many times the hop dominates, but this one is tremendously drinkable  I think on a blind taste Id give it an abv around the 6% mark. Not punishing at all, just very very nice and really moreish for a double [12032011]

bottle at cgarvieuk - 12 Mar 2011

bright yellow, clear, no bubbles with a very frothy head
great grapefruit citrus nose. ive had more aggressive and stronger hop noses
med/thin body and slightly fizzy. softly syrupy
soft, unassuming ipa. i wouldnt call it a double or imperial ipa, just an ipa.
that said, this is great. it is perfectly balanced and super easy to drink. id never guess it was 8%. 
finish is slightly hoppy but not bitter. and there is a little more malt in the finish.

Bouteille de 500 ml, vieille denviron 3 semaines. Arômes intenses de houblon rappelant les fruits tropicaux (fruit de la passion, mangue). Robe cuivrée et limpide, effervescence moyenne et légère dentelle. Bien que très aromatique, cette bière se démarque surtout par son bel équilibre entre le houblon fruité (pêches, mangues, pamplemousse) et un malt biscuité, pas trop sucré. Lalcool apporte une délicate touche réchauffante en fin de bouche. Belle finale sèche présentant une forte amertume. Excellent !

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Got a glass from someone, dont remember who but thanks. Very nice but not exceptional Double IPA. Or DIPA? Is it? At least not as aggressive as many American DIPAs. Very sparkling and refreshing. Its almost like a Belgian Strong Ale (blond). Most resembling Duvel IMO.

On tap. Poured a nice dark golden color with a whispy white head that held up very well. Smells of pine and bitter hops with some sweet malt too. It is very hoppy at first but has a strong malt backbone. Smooth ipa with a decently bitter hop profile.

tried both out of the bottle several times & tried on tap @ falling rock tap house. pours a hazey straw yellow with white head, excellent lacing. 

smell is of citrusy piney hops. very nice aroma, something I would sell everyday if possible. 

first taste is about the same, but tends to exhibit grapefruity mid flavors. usually it always finishes smooth out of the bottle, but I have noticed out of the tap really showcases a strong bitter finish. that seems to be the only  real difference between tap and bottle. overall, one of my favorite IIPAs.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2011 Very very clean fresh crisp IPA, but a little one dimensional to really make this an all-star. Just drank 2 month old and one month old vertical of pliny to see what all the wah wah was about. The 2 month old tasted like a 4.3 beer and the one month old was a 3.9. The fresher was way too unbalanced. Seems that batch variation trumps freshness aging. WOW! lol.

Im tired of typing admiration for Russian River. They seem to be one of these few breweries that knock it out of the park every time. This is right up there with FFF dreadnaught. Balanced malty and bitter. A ton of malts in this....and youd never guess its 100 IBUs. Beautiful pour. Gold and clear. Perfect carbonation. Outstanding mouthfeel. One of the best.
Sample at ACBF 11, via the Struise stand. Nice hops, very refreshing. Citrus throughout.

Tasting at Pauls house.  A cornucopia of hops on the nose, earhy, musty, citrus.  The flavor is exactly the same, the earthy and musty flavors take the lead.  The appearance is much like any other IIPA, clear red/gold, white head.  The finish is earthy, slighly metal.  The beer is medium in body, the carbonation very noticeable.  Solid IIPA, but it just doesnt live up to its hype.  Maybe this wasnt as fresh as it should have been.

Poured into a pint glass. Amber colored with a lacy head. The aromas of grapefruit and citrusy in the back olfactory sinuses :). Taste was well balanced, and the thing that stood out to me most is that the beer is very well balanced. Its not like heavy in hops and over powering in bitterness. Memorable.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2012 First Double IPA I ever fell in love with! Pours burnt orange/golden with a thin, sticky off-white head. Pretty light lacing around the glass. Aroma is heavy citrus and floral notes, pine, and hops hops hops! One of the hoppiest beers Ive ever smelled! Mouthfeel is crisp; very drinkable, especially in the summertime! Medium to high carbonation. Floral and citrus flavors on the forefront of the palate; perfect balance of sweet and bitter, then gently moves into a resiny, piney hop flavor smoothed out by huge malt characters in the finish. Leaves a lingering aftertaste that begs for more! Well-balanced and crisp! One of the best double IPAs Ive ever had. Top 3 for sure!
On tap at Najas Place.  Simply an amazing brew.  This one definitely stands out among the many IPAs out there.  Not an easy beer to find, but if you do, you wont be disappointed.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2014 Bottle:
White head on top of a clear orange beer.
Smell hops, flowers, citrus, fruit, orange and lemon.
Taste is a good but bitter hoppy mix of fruits, grapefruit, red orange, bitter, dry, hops, light flowery, malts and spices.
Pretty long hoppy bitter dry herby aftertaste.
Low carbo, medium body and soft tingly mouthfeel.
Expected a bit more of this one, maybe not really fresh (though not older than half a year).
------ Rerate: 3 weeks young: Aroma and flavour more like a fresh IPA and the bitterness is well balanced with the hop flowers (and hop fruits). Still I prefer Heady but this comes very close. 4.2 combined 4.1
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Happy I could try this beer here in europe. Smell is fantastic, full of hops, pine, citrus, grapefruit and passionfruit. Taste is very bitter, but the beer is extremely balanced. However, for me it makes the tongue a bit too dry, so have to drink water the whole time in between. Still, great beer, bit overrated maybe

Pours a golden straw/amber color with a small white head that doesnt last long. Little lacing, but not much.
Hops. Sweetness in the back, but overpowered by hops. Nice hop aroma.
Hoppy and bitter. A little malt comes through. A bit of a citrus note. 
Bitterness. The hops stick to the mouth for a long time. A bit overpowering in the bitterness long after swallowing. But very good.
Fairly drinkable. The hops would definitely get old very fast. The bitterness is kind of tiring on the palate. Overall a decent beer that seems to get more praise than it should. Seems like a weak clone of Ruination.

How do you describe the perfect beer? Out here on the east coast we go crazy over Hopslam - but GD THIS is better! And year round???? Spoiled west coasters...
Beautiful hazy sunshine color, with a sticky foamy head...aroma is juicyness and bitterness - full on mango,peach,passion fruit and a wild floral smell. The flavor...nectar of the hop...Its like drinking a wild flower! Juicy, bitter, sweet, crisp, and supported by a nice tongue-saving maltiness. Glory to the hop!

500 mL bottle.  Pours a murky golden.  I was initially underwhelmed by the appearance of this, but when I started smelling the hops while my glass was still an arms length away, my expectations were restored.  Hoppy aroma is pine with some citrus/pineapple; I smell 420 in this, personally.  Whats amazing about this beer is that the aroma doesnt disappear as quickly as most beers; with most of the beer gone, the aroma is still almost the same as it was when I took my first whiff on top of the foamy head.  Perfectly balanced beer has lots of hops but finishes quite smooth.  Subtle malt perfectly compliments the bitterness that is trying everything it can take center stage.  Delicious.

Érdekes, hogy az amerikai IPA-őrület egyik központi söre a mainstreammel tökéletesen ellentétes irányba indul. Sötétsárga színét fehér, szépen csipkéződő hab koronázza. Az illata először intenzív sárgadinnye, vagy inkább sárgadinnye-rágó, majd lassan némi sajtos lábszag társul hozzá, ami a legkomolyabb IPA-k velejárója.
Az első korty aztán színesíti a képet valami nagyon határozott kenderes jelleggel. A sárgadinnye és a kender aromái együtt egy kifejezetten üdítő ízképet adnak ki. Noha ez egy 8%-os dupla IPA, a teste közepes, kifejezetten könnyen iható sör, nem is emlékeztet a dupla IPA-k fülledt exkluzivitására, olyan, mintha egy mindennapi ivásra szánt sört innánk, aminek gyönyörű és szokatlan ízei vannak.
A komlóképlet szintén az amerikai álom cáfolata. Határozottan európai földes komlók viszik a primet, melyek némi gyomnövényes ízen át a kenderhez is szépen idomulnak (vagy lehet, hogy a kenderesség is csak valamelyik komló tudománya?). Tehát egy sárgadinnyés, kenderes, férfiasan komlózott sör válik nagyon közérthetővé, elegánssá és egyszerűvé.

Bottle. Poured into my RR tulip. Deep copper with a fluffy white head and nice lacing. The aroma is citrus and floral with loads of hops. A well balanced and tangy DIPA.. Notes of pine, grapefruit,, hops and caramel. . Medium bodied with nice carbonation. Overall one my favorites, especially when fresh.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2013 Week old bottle.

From the moment you pry off the cap hop fumes fill your nostrils.

It pours a light orangeish gold, almost like a Helles lager with and orange tint. It is a pretty unique color. The head is bright white and compact, it leaves some decent lacing.

The smell is phenomenal on this one. A cornucopia of hoppage, with scents of citrus, pine, and a hint of sweetness.

The flavor is also amazing. A barrage of grapefruit, lemon, bitterness and pine hit you like a freight train. There is a subtle bit of malt that provides some sweetness and rounds out the taste, but dont let this fool you, this is hoppier than your average DIPA. It is a hop bomb to the fullest. The bitterness is overt but not offensive in the least. The mouthfeel is perfect, subtable for a massive hop delivery with a medium body and prickly, active, though not overt carbonation.

As far as a DIPA goes this is as drinkable as it gets, not only does it smell and taste like heavenly hop nectar, the alcohol is nonexistent. The bitterness is never tiring, but assuming you are a DIPA lover like me, you wont even think of it anyways.

This is one damn fine beer, it just edges out FFF Dreadnaught as my favorite in the category. It may not be as epic as people tout it to be but as far as DIPAs go it may just be the king.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-21-2009 22:55:48

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2012 500ml bottle from Cracked Kettle. It pours a hazy golden yellow with a thin foamy head. It smells like a tropical fruit explosion! The nose is pineapple, peach, orange, nectarine, mango, sweet tangerine and some pine. The taste is initially fruity (peach, pineapple, red apple and some banana), leading to a more savoury finish of pine, resin, varnish, biscuit and hay. The finish is enjoyably long and bitter. Its crisp, refreshing and very easy to drink for 8%. Top notch DIPA action.
This is very balanced to almost siding on the hop side. Appears on the yellow side with superb froth retention. Medium full nectar with good carbonation. Very fresh tasting.

One of the most pungent aromas ive ever encountered. Almost tangy bitterness. Lots of pine. Very one sided on hops. Could use a little malt balance. At only 8% its a pretty accesible iipa. I think it wad $4.99 at fred meyer

Bottle from CrackedKettle. Poured with a golden yellow color, and an off-white, lacing head. Delicious aroma with spices, thyme, sativa, rosemary, pine, citrus, tons of hops. Medium body and carbonation, bitter aftertaste. Outstanding!
On draft at Falling Rock Tap House in Denver. Perfect beer. Absolutely delicious in every way.
Elder is a magical experience. I was spoiled to find it so easily but I enjoy every drop.

Acquired via trade, bottle dated 011211.  Poured into a tulip glass aggressively and resulted in minimal head and some lacing.  Aroma is hops and pine.  Color is pale golden.  Taste doesnt start bitter but finishes that way.  Light bodies with a slightly creamy texture.  There is minimal carbonation.  What else can I say that hasnt already been said?  Im really glad I was able to acquire this and it has left me wanting more!

On tap at the brewery.  Pours medium amber with orange tint, moderate amount of orange tinged white head that laces moderately. Aroma is big citrus and pine hops with a bit of straw malt.  More malt comes through in the taste, which is a good thing because the hops are huge.  A nice toast and caramel sweetness matches up well against the typical northwest hop flavor profile - big grapfruit and resinous hop notes, finishing up with a moderately bitter and nicely dry finish.  Very good.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2011 Bottle ordered from Cracked Kettle. Rated on 29/2/2011 Lightly hazy honey color with a tiny white head. Piney, grapey and fruity, but with less power in the hops than expected from a DIPA. Light to medium body, clean dry malts. Medium bitterness. Way below expectation, we were speculating if it was badly handled or frozen somewhere along the way. 8/4/7/4/14

Bottle brought by a friends friend. Bottling date 10/2/2011, rating date 31/3/2011. Much more power in the hops in this one compared to the one above, despite being older. Otherwise mostly the same. 8/4/8/4/17

0,5 l bottle, CrackedKettel, Amsterdam, courtesy of Balazs, thanks!
Pours opalescent amber/copper with an off white, two-finger head, some laces. Aroma is a lively, biting hop with pine, grapefruit/citrus and straw. Some sweetness gives the base for this bitterness. Taste follows the aroma. Bit of hop bitterness with a base on malts sweetness, tropical fruit flavor from the hop. Smooth mouthfeel with biscuit and caramel, some honey but in the finish rules a dry piney hop.

Bottle shared with friends. Pours orange with moderate head. A good malt base and lots of hops in both nose and mouth. Medium sweetness and bitterness - a perfect blend. Lots of citrus here. A fantastic double IPA.

I was extremely excited to try this beer, i had to bribe a co-worker to bring it back from CA for me. Drank it on 01/07/11, bottled on 12/17/10 so the hops were there in full force. For the build up to trying this, I was some what let down. The hops were bright and powerful, but I felt it lacked a malt backbone. I do enjoy west coast IPAs, but I just felt the beer wasnt balanced enough for all of the hype. I know that is sacrilege on here, but thats how I feel, personally I prefer a more malt balanced DIPA, like a DFH 90 min or Lagunitas Hop Stoopid. Overall it was a good beer, but not at the level I had been reading.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2013 Draft. Pours orange with a nice white head which leaves good lacing. Aroma is intense citrus hops with pine, resin. Flavor is dry, very hoppy but not overpowering, with some sugary sweetness in the malt. Surprisingly light for a DIPA. Another Russian River success.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2011 Tap at Tonys Darts.  Aroma: citrus, lots of pine, very floral, some background malt notes, slight resin note, great fresh hop character all around.  Pours slightly clear golden color with lots of white head that lingers for a while then dissipates to a thin layer, spotty lacing.  Flavor: again lots of pine, a big punch of citrus hop flavor, and a light bready malt undertone.  Smooth on the palate, medium body and carbonation.  Very tasty DIPA, could drink this for hours on end.

I had this beer at a little place in lake tahoe in camp richardson or something like that. Such an unassuming place but had such great craft beers. They also had morimotos beer, which was a great light bodied beer for drinking a cooking. But overall, there isnt much to be said about pliny except that for IPA lovers it is one of the best choices.

Bottle. enjoyed two weeks after bottling.  amber in color with plenty of fluffy white head.  smells like fruit, but more of a west coast ipa taste with the spruce/pine.  Hops are great, tons of flavor but not overpowering.  A very enjoyable beer.
Nothing exciting. Great aroma but taste a little disappointing. Well balanced palate and great color.
Piney the Elder as far as im concerned. Great nose, but rather one note on the taste.

Bottle. An honour to be making your acquaintance, Mr. Pliny! Clear amber pour, quite light-looking. Small, entirely white head. Aroma is of course dominated by hops but not just the usual resinous and grassy stuff but real thoroughbred hoppy goodness. It feels like sniffing pure hop-pellets which I find to be a very enjoyable practice, by the way. Simcoe dominates with lemon and lime. It has grass and pine as well as exotic fruits, while remaining sophisticated and complex with a nice burnt caramel/sugar balance. Pure west-coast hoppiness with a mild sugary presence. Taste is quite dry, the dry-hopping stands out. Lime, citrus, pineapple and grass provide the fresh fruitiness, while a strong, albeit well-managed bitterness seals the deal on this almost perfect IIPA. Nizzle!

UPDATED: APR 4, 2012 RE-RATED:  Its really the best Imperial IPA on the planet.

This is my yardstick for a good IPA.  The nose is easily the best of any beer I have ever experienced.  There is no way of calculating the depths of hoppy, herby, spicy aromas that come of this beer.  The taste lives up to the aroma, deep, diverse hoppy herby flavors, and a perfect amount of sweet malt to round everything out.

Pours a translucent amber/copper with a white, two-finger head.  Some sticky lace, but it doesnt coat the glass.

Aroma is a lively, biting hop.  Pineapple, pine, grapefruit/citrus.  The hops aroma is as sweet as it is bitter but it packs a fragrant, pungent punch.  Beautiful.  Hop aroma flies out of the glass.

Taste follows the aroma.  Big pinch of hop bitterness with an equal dose of sweet, tropical fruit flavor from the hop.  And so smooth.  It bites and makes you want more.  Buttery biscuit malt follows but the finish is a dry piney hop.  Mildy sticky.

This beer is not in competition to be the biggest beer or the most hops.  Rather, it presents a manifestly smooth but powerful hop.  Lush tropical fruity hops dominate.  Its like hop juice distilled to the perfect point.

Received in trade from RickSawyer, Thanks for the opportunity.

Pours a slightly cloudy deep golden color with a stingy off white head that disappears quickly. Nose is hops, lovely piny resinous grapefruity hops. Leans more towards the pine than to the citrus side. Taste is pretty much a citrus and pine explosion that leaves the mouth coated with bitter hop oils. I cant find any malt here, but Im okay with it. Finish is dry, but the taste lingers begging you to take another sip. Well Ive wanted to try this forever and finally got a chance, now I want more!! Great hop bomb.

A trip to Monks in Philly rewarded me with another success in the ongoing Quest for the Hole Ales! Right off the tap, this one pours with a divine glow through a rich deep amber filter supporting a medium tall dusky beige rocky head with enough velvety lacing to satisfy Sean Penns appetite for privacy.  The aroma is that of a pine forest canopy (if pine forests had canopies) and a grapefruit orchard.  An aggressive but still carefully balanced grapefruity, spruce hop bomb explodes as you take your first few sips.  The hops are unrelenting but amazingly well restrained at the same time due to a solid malty, bready backbone.  Rich, creamy mouthfeel and a lasting finish thats both bracingly bitter and sultry smooth at the same time.  Theres a reason this is a world class standard.

Bottle from Nugget Market. Poured into my trusty tulip glass. When I first opened the bottle, the immediate smell of the hops came wafting out and filled my senses with the grassy mellowness. The color as I poured was a hazy golden-pale with a very active head, showing off just how frothy this guy is. The aroma was then more abundant with the smell of roasted malts hiding in the back. In the front, the very grassy floral scent was welcoming with a side of citrus fruits. Tasting it, the sudden bitterness from the hops was there, but it didnt take over like I thought it would. Med. bitterness with very minimal sweetness. The carbonation helps tone it down as it finishes abruptly. Light bodied but still creamy. Ok, so Im usually not down for IPAs at all (I pretty much steer away) but just the reputation alone had me try this. I have to say Im pretty damn pleased with it! This is a great one and you need to try it....that is, if you enjoy drinking exquisite beers...

This is the Imperial IPA that many a beer aficionado thinks of when discussing world class offerings in this style. Golden orange in color, Pliny The Elder has big notes of grapefruit up front, highlighting the array of citrusy hops. The hoppiness is complimented by roasted malt and caramel with a crisp, clean finish. It never fails to amaze me how this ale can have such a sizable hoppy presence, yet be so surprisingly smooth to drink.

My first beer i get to rate and its something quite special. Especially because were in Ohio. Its delicious on all levels. Poured out of a growler and into my mouth. I love how the finish is so clean and bright I wont have to take a shower tonight.

Bottle courtesy of wavers. Pours a golden color with white head. Nose is citrus and grapefruit. Flavors is citrus, pine, and hop goodness. This beer is light crisp and dry on the finish with a taste that lingers in all the right ways. This is how Imperial IPAs should be done. Fan-fucking-tastic!

UPDATED: APR 30, 2011 Dark gold pour with a thick white head. Tons of citrus and pine in the nose. Faint doughy sweetness can also be found. Flavor is a burst of hops. Loads of citrus and pine, a subtle floral taste, and a pretty strong malt backbone. Palate is an excellent medium body. Awesome beer, though I found it to be slightly overrated. I actually prefer Blind Pig.

Re-rating this. After trying it fresh and on a clean tap line, its definitely worth the hype. Incredibly balanced, with a smooth citrusy malt profile and a sharp hop bite on the finish. Really awesome.

Pours clear orange with a white head. Aroma is just hop pellets, simcoe pine and grape, exotic fruits, esp passion fruit. Elegantly crisp hops. Taste is just insane hops, the same notes, just as ellegant. This tastes so good, I could drink this all day.

Bottle, as pictured, from Sebowski from TBS/FBG.  Awesome.  This is a superb beer, really what an IPA should be.  Might be the best looking beer Ive ever seen....a dark yellow with a ton of little floaties and long-lasting "island" head.  Smells strong of grapefruit with some pine/spruce.  Taste is similar, very hoppy throughout with a surprisingly smooth finish.

Aroma is filled with a strong grapefruit note that is followed by hops and pine. The appearance is golden and what I expect in a near perfect imperial IPA. Taste is what I appreciate most about this beer. It envelops the mouth with hops that trail off so that at the finish they linger on the tongue. Overall I consider this to be one of my favorite beers.

Slightly hazy, pale orange body with short head. Fruity aroma with pine notes as well. Hop flavour and bitterness in the taste is very enjoyable (for me it was though not my partner), medium body, well balanced with the malt a good backbone. Easy to drink and dont notice the alcohol so would love to drink plenty of these.
UPDATED: MAY 21, 2014 Poured from bottle.  Pours straw yellow with thick white head.  Aroma is pine and citrus.  Taste is fresh hops, citrus and a bit of pine resin.  Love this stuff.

Poured from a 4 week old bottle. Aroma is of lovely fresh hops, and citrus goodness.It doesnt smell as prominent or overpowering as I would have thought.  It pours with a great white head froathy head and it laces the glass very well. Taste is of floral hops, peaches, mangos and a slight hit of malt on the back end. There isnt very much malt, but the right amount to not overpower the sweet goodness of the hops. Just the right amount of bitterness to sweetness to make this an exceptionally balanced DIPA. Overall, this is in the top 3 of the style Ive had the pleasure of tasting. I just wish I could get it more readily.

Bottle for rating #3100: &nbsp Fiery golden, fairly clear with the exception of fine sediment, large frothy off-white head, sticky lacing. &nbsp Floral hoppiness on the nose. &nbsp Certainly smells good. &nbsp Not getting much malt presense tho, so I am guessing its not going to be as malty as I prefer. &nbsp Certainly hoppy on the tongue, floral, but the malts dont back it up as much as I prefer. &nbsp Its almost there, but this to me is much more of a 1½ IPA, and a good one at that. &nbsp Not biting, but quite flavorful. &nbsp Exit is clean, very clean. &nbsp Well crafted. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate to full. &nbsp Could stand to be maltier, in my opinion. Lingering citrus peel type bitterness, but again, not biting &nbsp I was really looking to this one, quite a bit, but its missing a hefty malt base to really balance it out. &nbsp  Damnit!

500mL bottle poured into a snifter. Received from a trade with jamesm7485. Bottled 01/05/09.

4.0 A: Hazy dark orange color. Two fingers of frothy head with average retention and tons of lacing.

4.5 S: Aroma is very similar to NN actually. Lots of grapefruit, but also some pine and some floral. Very good.

4.5 T: Tons of hop flavor, which Im totally down with. Citrusy grapefruit, lemon, perhaps orange some pine as well. Malts are biscuity and caramel, and there is also a yeastiness to it.

4.0 M: Medium-heavy body. A little undercarbonated, but very smooth.

4.5 D: This truly is a great brew, but I think it is a little overrated. Very drinkable.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-22-2009 02:32:21

S - fruity, flowey and citrusy, with a little scent of hop there too. 
A - golden orange, whittish head, 
T - HOP! right away the hop. but its the hop that you will like and appreciate in a great brew. Citrus, caramel, and malty. 
M - very smooth, medium to full bodied. no aftertaste, for me.
D - oh so drinkable, one of the great beers out there.

The cleanest, hoppiest beer I can think of. Citrus and floral aroma is extremely pleasing, and appearance is a nice golden orange yellow. Hops hit you immediately upon tasting, and the bitterness is incredibly strong yet enjoyable. Never overpowers the palate and remains easily drinkable the whole way through. Carbonation is perfectly balance with the hops and citrus to leave a tingle on the tongue to go with the hops. I want some of this right now, gimme (its affordable too).

Bottle dated 11.22.2010. Enjoyed on 01.07.11. Generously received from BA HoldensHomebrew.

Pours a slightly cloudy persimmon orange with a foamy, one-finger white head. Settles down to a ring of head and one straggling group of bubbles, with thick-bubbled lacing.

The combination of pine, citrus, grapefruit, and floral hoppiness is not unique to Pliny the Elder, but the complexity here is deeper; this is a case where clarity through words is hard to come by. The pine is sweetened through what smells like caramelized sugar; imagine sugared grapefruit for breakfast and youre close. 

Lots of citrus and resinous flavor without imparting too much lingering bitterness. Theres more caramel backing than I expect or remember (the bottle may be just a week or two "older" than perfect), but its really driven by the grapefruit and citrus bitterness. As I get further in, I pick up on some orange and just a hint of sweeter tropical fruit notes - this is my favorite part of the beer, coming in mid-to-late palate and only as I get further through the glass. 

Medium-full bodied without medium carbonation. Somewhat sticky without distracting.

The standard for a style I dont always appreciate. Drinking this now, it brings back memories of sub-par DIPAs of the past, really putting them to shame. Other DIPAs roam the earth, ghostlike, growing ever staler and hoping to be like Pliny. Vinnie does no wrong.

Bottle from Cracked Kettle chared with a friend @ home cons 2011-01-09 Göteborg
AR: fresh apricots, pineapple, pine oil
AP: hazy honey, fluffy high thick 4 cm high lively head that leaves lovely curtains
F. great bitterness,  fresh apricots, pineapple, pine oil

On tap at monks in Philadelphia. Thrilled to finally get to try this one. Didnt disappoint. Great citrus and hop scent. Bitter hop finish. Wish I could try it again, but this one is probably once in a blue moon. Great DIPA.
On tap at the falling rock tap house. Gold with quarter inch head. Nice floral, citrus and pine aroma. Flavor is perfectly balanced pine and citrus hops. Incredible beer thats worth the hype.

One of the best beers out there. Pliny is aromatic with overwhelming notes of pine citrus hops and just a little bit of alcohol. Golden in color, clear, perfect bubbles and a beautiful lacing. It has a full mouth feel and the flavors are perfectly balanced. Its sticky with a taste a feel that lasts.

On draft at Najas. I dont know how fresh this was but it was simply outstanding. Has a good amount of hops and malts in the aroma, but what really impressed me was the balanced and how easy it was to drink. The flavors were earthy and piney but incredibly smooth. This is a must for any hop head.
Coriander, honey, flowers and hop aroma. The bitter hop taste is very nicely compensated with the sweet round honey and apricot aftertaste. Well balanced beer.

Bottled 12/17/10. Shared with Matt at 3R6P. Sampled from a 16 oz brown bottle this beer poured a hazy golden color with a medium sized yellow-white foamy head that left good lacing. The aroma was strong hops - floral, grassy and fruity though a bit heavy in tangy sourness and a touch rough. The flavor was very tangy/sour caramel with very strong pine and light notes of grapefruit, catbox and perfume. The hops were fairly rough and clinged to the tongue refusing to leave. The intense tangy, rough and piney hops were a bit much and unrefined and made the brew a bit of a chore to finish. Thick and full bodied. An interesting beer but there are many in the style that I prefer.

My first Pliny...and I was not dissapointed.  Sent to me as a gift by a former employee.  The beer pours a nice copper with a white head that is just beautiful.  The aroma is floral and citrus, and loads of fragrance.  The taste is straight up, full on West Coast IPA....everything you would expect.  Notes of grapefruit, floral hops, and piney resin.  Palate is medium body with medium carbonation....excellent mouthfeel.  True to style in every, wonderful way.  Overall one of the best DIPAs out there.
Copper with an off white cover.  The aroma is just juicy hops, sweet malt, caramel.  Taste is more citrus, hoppy, balanced sweetness with bitter finish.  A nice IPA.
Orange coloured, medium head but should hold some longer. Smell is very fruity, caramel, citrus, spices, sweet. And good. Taste is good balanced between bitter sweet and orange. Fruity, nice brew.

Bottle courtesy of James from CA. he got it for me for letting him use luggage and it was the best deal for me. This was my first beer of the New Year, had just after midnight and it was amazing. Pour was a really nice slightly hazed orange with little head. Aroma was full of really fresh hops and wild fruits. Some mild sweet malts lingered in the flavor to nicely balance the hops. The balance of this beer is nearly unmatched. Delicious in every way. Thank you James.

Superfresh bottle received with secret santa, thanks Maltzilla!
Aroma is huge piney and fruity hops, hint of blue cheese. Subtle malt and caramel. Flavour is deep earthy, cheese and piney fruity hops. Strong bitterness, light sweet malt note. Hint of spices. Awesome balance between bitterness and sweetness, also great balance between the different hop flavours. Nice palate. Long finish with slowly fading hops from fruity and piney to cheesy and earthy. Very good stuff, shame I probably will never drink this so fresh again.

Bottle at home, thanks Santa! Cloudy orange pour, thin white head. Aroma is full of fresh hops, pine, grapefruit, a hint of blue cheese and some other sweet fruits. The flavor is a perfect balance between sweet and bitter. The hops being present mostly at first in a nice rich spectrum of flavors, and then the thicker malt flavors bring forth a sweet fruity body. Long lingering bitter hoppy finish again. Perfect harmony. Great brew.

On tap from Beachwood BBQ. Pale golden color with an aroma of hops and citrus. Taste is a boatload of grass with a mixture of wild weeds, pine and other earthy notes. Very unique flavor but I was able to quickly adapt. Smooth finish.

Gift of good friend Paul B. Hop bomb. Poured with a small off white head that lasts and lots of lace. Color is a slightly hazy amber. Aroma is firstly and foremost hops, then some malt and butter. Flavor follows nose, just much more massive. Body is good and so is carbonation. Finish is like flavor and long. Little overmuch for my taste.
Decadent!!!  A seriously strong blasting wop of aroma in classic double IPA style.....

Bottle; Pour is light golden; frothy white head on this one. Nose is juicy grassy floral hops - sweet malts are present as well.  Side by side with the dreadnaught, the malt profile is heavier on this one and while the juiciness is nice, I guess I prefer the dreadnaught in comparison. Resins, Orange, Grapefruit, caramel malts, floral and grassy hops all intermix well. This is truly excellent, but I why do I yearn for Pliny the Younger?

On Draught, Toronado, San Francisco. Been looking forward to trying this for some time, and it was duly a great way to kick start the trip. Attractive looking clear amber in the glass with a small white head and some lace in the house too. Stunning piney aroma with oodles of resinous hop and citrus that set the stage perfectly. Couldnt stop sniffing this bad boy. Supremely well balanced with the sweet malts riding in perfect unison with the fat sack of hops. Crisp and smooth, and just a joy to devour. The finish was spot on with perfectly judged levels of bitterness. This is well worthy of its high ranking and I dont think I enjoyed a beer more than pte during my visit to SF. Bravo !
pretty much the perfect light hoppy beer.  im into pine, and i got a good bit here.  earthy with mellow esters shining through.  really crisp and tight taste.  wish id bought more.
Pretty awesome.  Pours blond with lasting white head.  Tons of fruity hops, nice bitterness.  Id love to know the grain bill, it complements the hops perfectly.

Reviewing a fresh, less than 1 month old bottle.

Pours a nice big 1 finger white head. Body is a hazy golden yellow with tons of bubbles rising. Head retention is good and lacing is above average.

Aroma is of piny hops and grapefruit/bitter citrus. There is also a good amount of sweetness present from malts.

Taste is of sweet citrus fruits with a bitter finish. Malts add a nice amount of sweetness to balance the beer. Hops are somewhat earthy and floral, not overly bitter like alot of highly rated beers. For 8% abv, alcohol is almost undetectable.

Beer is very carbonated and light on the palate. Head adds some creaminess to the body which is always nice. 

Overall this is a great beer and one of the best in its style. Would not rank it as one of the best in the world as many other people and beer sites have though. Still very drinkable and almost sessionable, would recommend it to anyone whos a fan of Ipas

Floral Hop Scent Pours light gold with a thick off-white creamy head.  By the scent I would expect this beer to be all about intense hops.  It isnt.  While the citrus grapefruit hop flavor is present its certainly doesnt overpower the taste.  The center of the taste is filled with smooth malt flavor reminiscent of honey.  The finish is crisp and dry with a little bitterness but not unpleasant.  Im not an IPA fan, but I could drink this.  Cheers!

Poured a golden color.  Frothy head.  Lacing.  Aroma is full of fresh floral hops.  Tastes medium bitter.  Medium body.  Oily. Medium carbonation.  Smooth finish.  Kind of velvety.  Nice floral hop taste, some grassiness also.  Well done.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2011 Tap @ Parkway. Clear gold pour with a short white head leaving heavy lace. Floral and fruit nose with resinous, grassy hops all through. The finish is resinous, oily and long. The medium-heavy body is variably-balanced between bitter and umami with a touch of sweetness throughout the swallow. The malts are mostly present as body, but there is a definite sweetness that pokes out now and then - Id put it at caramel or butterscotch. The fresher the better, this IIPA is neck and neck with the greatest and it travels fairly well in a bottle.
Bottle: Appealing color, aroma was exceedingly hoppy with some citrus.  Taste was also initially hoppy then more citrus, perhaps grapefruit.  Excellent IPA, overall one of the most enjoyable.

Pours a beautiful clear golden color. Smells strongly of bitter citrusy hops. Initial flavor is very bitter followed by citrus notes and finishes with both. Hopy, flavorful with a good amount of body.

Pours a golden orange color with a Foamy white head. Aroma is a combination of Grapefruit and pine hops - I tasted lemon, grapefruit, and bits of other tropical fruits. There may be slight malt sweetness. Aroma, again, is an explosion of citrus with a wonderful pine hop finish at the end. Medium to Full body, Finish is surprisingly dry. Got this from my sister in Puyallup Washington. Some 2IPAs (Lake Erie Monster, 90 min.) have a lot of Malt Character, not this one.
Glad I got 3.

Pliny the Elder is a great IPA. It pours a golden yellow color with a white head and great retention. There isnt much lacing though, but that isnt that big of a deal. The aroma is very floral and perfumes of hops. You can tell that this is an IPA by the aroma and if you like IPAs youll appreciate it all the better. The flavor is kinda tricky to me cause Im not too accustomed to IPAs but it did start off with a good breadiness. The flavor kinda turns citrus-like and finished with a hoppy explosion that IPA lovers will rejoice in. This is way up there in my favorite IPA brews and is a great beer in and of itself. Wow
UPDATED: AUG 2, 2012 On tap @ Brouwers Cafe. This is the best imperial IPA. Full flavor and high alcohol but easy drinking and refreshing.

Tap @ Falling rock, Denver, Co. Pours hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma of big hops, pine, grapefruit, pinapple, floral. Taste is again with huge hops like aroma, solid malt backbone keeps a great balanced. Super bitter finish, medium body, high and easy drinkabillity, overall just a damn great beer.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2014 A gift from a colleague. Bottle tapped 7.August 2014 and enjoyed 30. August 2014. Very fresh hop aromas lifts the beer from a 3.8 Total score. Very enjoyable. A benchmark for the style.

Initial Rating Date: 12/4/2010 9:25:30 AM
Shared bottle courtesy of gunnar. Pours hazy golden with a white head/film. Alcohol, apricot, peach present on the nose. Sweet, alcoholic, acidic and bitter flavors. Dry finish. Medium to full body.
Bottle shared with friends, great lacing to the bottle. Citrus and grapefruit aroma, some great piney taste. Very little off flavors, well worthy of the hype.

16.9 oz. bottle. Consumed on 11-26-10. Bottled on 100610, which Im assuming means October 6, 2010. Picked up for me by my mom on a recent trip to California; thanks, Mom! Beautiful smell is floral and dry but not astringent. Apricot, pine, peach, and rose scents. Fantastic. Its hard to imagine a more lovely aroma. Pours a slightly hazy, highly effervescent, shiny, bright but deep orange-ish gold color. Moderate amount of uneven, moderately thick, off-white head. Extensive, long-lasting lacing. The flavor nicely matches the aroma. Perfectly balances the floral fruitiness of American hops with the floral fruitiness of English-style malts and an unyielding but wonderful dryness. Peach and apricot flavors with a hint of orange. Nice and spicy. A complex, totally inoffensive dryness in the finish. Very long, dry aftertaste. Oily, frothy, and lively in the palate. Medium to full body. Easy to drink yet begs to be savored. Russian River Pliny the Elder definitely is one of the best beers Ive ever had, and it is inarguably the most pleasant, like a stroll through a perfectly manicured garden in the English countryside. Superb and extremely well done.

On draft at Capones. Nice straw/amber pour with a lot of head. Juicy aromas are coming out of the glass. Very hoppy flavor of course, but also pretty malty for an IIPA. Aftertaste is very resiny and sticks to the palate. Really glad i got to try this.
On tap at capones on draft.  Nice aroma... Juicy fresh hop. Taste is aggressive, juicy hop, and ultra tasty.
UPDATED: MAR 17, 2016 Otroligt god doft, trevlig smak av mycket humle, gräsch och en välbalanserad fruktsmak med toner av mango, apelsin och grape. Underbar len eftersmak. Bland de bästa.

5oz pour from a flight.  Pour is clear gold with an inch of frothy white foam on top; this brew has decent retention and a moderate amount of lacing.  Nose is summer fruits, citrus, light bubble gum, and a nice bouquet of hops.  Taste comes off as a clean/refreshing hoppy bubblegum with a dry, lingering hop finish.  This is one of the better IPAs Ive had, and well worth the drive to Capones!

Pint for $5 at Falling Rock in Denver, CO. Hazy light orange in appearance. Pine, citrus, grapefruit. Heavy bitterness all the way through, a brief attempt to balance in the middle, but crushed. Medium bodied, average carbonation, sticky around the mouth. Way long bitter finish.
A very good IPA, but not as good as the hype.  I tasted it back to back with an Avery duganA and the Avery was superior.  A world class IPA for sure........but a bit overhyped.

Bottle from Total Wine $5.49 dated 11/11/2010 so super fresh. Poured a beautiful golden color with nice thick white head. Aroma is super floral and dank with some tropical fruit as well. Taste is semi sweet with a perfect hop bitterness and some nice malt backbone. Great carbonation. Overall in every aspect this beer is phenomenal. Glad I get this fresh all the time.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2012 Thanks to Jerk44 for this one.

A: Orange colored with a good head and plenty of lace.

S: Lots of hops, backed up by some nice citrus and tropical fruits.

T: Much like the smell, with the hoppiness taking over a little bit in a good way. 

M: Medium-bodied with a good amount of carbonation. The alcohol is barely present.

D: All around a very good beer. Absolutely cannot wait for August to get out to California and try this one on tap.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-27-2009

Courtesy of After4ever, thanks Tom. Its hazy, warm golden with a creamy, white head. The aroma is hoppy with notes of citrus, spruce, peach and other fruits. The flavour is sweet with notes of peach, citrus, spruce, caramel, and it has a nice dry bitterness with a lot of grapefruit in the finish.

Pliny is the king of IPAs in my opinion, replete with huge citrus, pine and tropical fruit aromas, it finishes boldly bitter with a nice assertive dryness that other IPAs and Imperial IPAs miss the mark on greatly.

My only lament is that I can only obtain this beer on trips to the pacific Northwest or at a rare beer event.  But in all honesty that is what keep it alluring too.

Straw Pour with medium white head.
Grapefruit nose with hint of candy malt
Light to Medium body. Extremely well balanced. Sweet Middle and crisp fresh finish.

Its a lovely beer but doesnt deserve the amount of hype it gets.

POurs a clear, dark yellow. Hay?  Pine resin and bright grapefruit up front.  Prickly mouthfeel with more citrus and a Jolly Rancher taste that make me wantto chug the thing. Dry finish with lingering bitterness that I like a lot. Not overly sweet as some IIPAs tend to be.  Very well made and one of my favorites.

Bottle 500 ml 
Aroma Big, rich , wholesome hop experience. Golden malt aroma with garden greens that smell so great after rain. Fruity hop sweets  pineapple , mango.9-
Appearance Mild haze on amber ale with medium light rocky top.  
 Taste/Body/Palate  Ambrosia , subtle yet rich  perfectly balanced mango hop with supportive malts and sprinkle of alcohol. Extremely drinkable . Mid end noted with fresh fruity character. Finishing with fruity bubblegum. Mild at such strength1 parameters of Double IPA with drinkability of malty English strong ale.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2011 My first pliny!
Unbelievable aroma of juicy citrus, grapefruit mostly. Some floral honey notes, and a touch of sweetness from the malts. The flavor is one hell of a hop kick! The finish is quite resinous and loaded with pine, and a touch of soapy spruce. The finish is intensely bitter, and ends with and incredible citrus taste. Long live pliny!!

Looks good, smells good, tastes good. Just not great; perhaps I was expecting too much. Drinkable, balanced and a lot of hops and pine and flowers for sure, just no overwelming flavour explosions. Can get a lot of ipas easier and cheaper thatll do the job just as well.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2017 Dry piney hop aroma.  Pours a clear golden color with lacing sudsy white head.  Smooth with that nice dry piney hoppiness.  Just a real solid IPA.

Notes: on tap at the brew pub, June 17

My first Pliny and worth the wait. Enjoyed on tap at Spinnerstown Hotel during RR flight promo with Jim and Brian. Amber honey color with lumpy lasting head. Hoppy but balanced and just delicious. Ive had many DIPAs and I cant think of one I would drink before this. At 8%, this beer could get me in some trouble, I mean I could drink it all day. Took a growler home for later and am enjoying it as I type. Really just happy to have had the chance to try this one as it is not readily available in my area. Thanks to John at Spinnerstown and thanks Brian for the home-brew.

Transcription of an old BA review from 04-02-2010, with scores adjusted to RB scale. Will re-rate....someday.

Bottling date: 1. February 2010 so lets open the bottle before the hops start to deteriorate.
The beer pours slightly hazed liquid-gold with orange to light coppery hue. Head quickly dissipates to a stable bubbly coating.
Aromas are rich and refreshing, like a night walk on the Mediterranean beach with an air filled by wind-carried scents of citruses (predominantly grapefruit), pines and cypresses, resin of coniferous trees and elder blossom. Besides citrusy hop character, another kind of fruitiness derived from either hops or fruity esters is evident and clean malty sweetness penetrates through the thick sheets of aromas. Excellent. Flavors showing less diversity then the nose suggested are of grapefruit and coniferous resins; semi-dry finish with lingering unharsh bitterness. The light-medium body is delicately carbonated. Finally, but not least important the eruption of finest hop qualities was crowned by nearly complete absence of perceivable alcohol.
Had this stuff out west at the brewery wish I could have brought more than a case back this stuffs a hopheads dream.Two words F#$&ing Delicious!pretty cool bottle too.

Pours a clear golden amber with a light head and very slight lace. Smells quite spicy, ruby red grapefruit, pine, zest and flowers. The taste is VERY spicy with a lovely malt alance. Some slight toffee and burnt toast coming through. Did I mention how perfect the balance is? Finishes very full and chewy with a linger that sticks around for some time. Shining example of the IIPA.

Pours golden with a fairly tiny head but it leaves nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is of pure hops - flowers, pine needles, grass, grapefruit. The taste is much like the smell and is dominated by the hoppiness but it has a keen sweet and malty flavor to it as well to balance it out. About as balanced a imperial ipa can get, very good.

Bottled a little more than 2-weeks ago and hand delivered from a friend.

Appearance: Poured a beautiful orange with a small creamy head

Aroma: Very powerful, full of wonderful pine and citrus notes

Taste: An explosion of hop goodness, a very strong, slightly bitter pine on the first sip that mellowed to a very delicious citrus/grapefruit  

Palate: Medium body with a sweet and sticky texture, the perfect amount of carbonation

Overall: A great beer, very solid, I would definitely drink this again, but I dont think Id go out of my way to trade for it.

Bottled on 9/21/10.  Nice gold color with little head, but nice lacing.  I didnt get the big fluffy white head I see most experienced with this beer, must have been a poor pour.  Really inviting smell.  Citrus, floral, hoppy, and piney.  Refreshing taste.  Very light for a double IPA, but the taste is phenomenal.  Hops hit the mouth first, malts smooth it out, and a nice dryness finishes it off.  Medium bodied, but lighter than I would have expected.  Extremely drinkable, if only I had access to it!

I expected BIG things from this Ale. TOTALLY OVER RATED!!! One dimensional with no sophistication . Tasted like a pine cone or kitty litter, take your pick, Very short after taste that finished like balsa wood. Cant figure out all the hype???

Maybe it was the shipping from California that did it in?  We sampled this at one of our Friday Beer Tastings.  The boss got it and shared one with us.  Underwhelming, honestly.....not what Id call a DIPA/IIPA.  Still, good,
On tap at the fathers office in Los Angeles. Unreal beer. Would love to vista the brewery one day

Bottle poured a golden amber brew with a thick head into  pint glass. Fragrant hoppy resinyaromas with hints of grapefruits. Amazing first sip which finished extremely smooth. I cant believe this has a ibu rating of100.I was expecting it to be similar to Stones Arrogant Bastard. I will definitely make a special trip to RRB to try this on tap.  Find this one no matter the trouble or costs!!!

(bottle thanks to thirdeye11) Super cloudy dark yellow fading into orange. Smell is super super hoppy- pine, sweet and bitter blood orange, caramel, lemon zest. Taste is equally hoppy- lemon lime, freshly cut pine wood with the sap running out. A bit like sucking on pine needles. Just the perfect amount of bitterness for the amount of flavor.

Bottle courtesy of Stefanje, thanks a million.  Ive been waiting for quite sometime to try this beer.  I must say it has lived up to its hype and beyond.  My highest rating to-date.  I look forward to additional RR brews.

Aroma is sweet and purfume. Some citrus. Major hops, but the maltyness still present. Appearance is orange brown with small head. Hazy. Taste is hops forward but still with malty sweetness. Does an excellent job of balancing out all the hops in this. Citrus, grapefruit, floral, pine, mango, pineapple. Sweetness is nice and pleasant but not complex. Alcohol is barely noticeable. Palate is medium +. Nice carbonation keeps this crisp. Overall a great beer. Very unique what has been done with the hops here. So many beers are completely overhopped and have no balance at all. This beer is perfectly balanced and a joy to drink.

Bottle, kindly shared by gunnar. Deep golden to orange colour, moderate white head. Very nice hoppy aroma, fruity and herbal notes. Intense hoppy flavour, but not too bitter. Fruity and spicy notes, well balanced.

perfectly balanced. Pours a white head. Bought a bottle and drank it as soon as possible. This beer is not to be aged. Love the balance of malt and hops. The aroma is a mix of citrus, fruit and hops. One of the better IPAs ive had.

Naven hooked me up with a fresh 500ml bottle of Piny.  Bottled 9.23.2010
Poured into large red wine glass.  Copper color with 1/2 finger white head that sticks to the glass.  Head fell and left small and bubbly  Super aroma dominated by flowery hops with some citrus.  Amazing flavor balanced with hops and malt.   This has to be the most drinkable double IPA ive tasted.  Simply awesome.

Great balance of hops/ malts followed by citrus fruit notes. Pliny delivers from beginning to end. Taste reminds me of fresh pine trees. Very refreshing. Although Pliny is not to be aged, we brought it along on our backpacking trip into the trinity alps to keep the morale high!
500 ml. bottle.  Pours a golden orange with a fluffy off-white head.  Aroma of piney hops, citrus and fruit.  Flavor balance is amazing, hops, citrus and malt.  Truly a great experience.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2010 Nice Golden color with decent 1" white head. Nice Smells of Piney Hops balanced nicely with smooth malts and a mild grapefruit zest and citrus sweetness. Tastes as good as it smells. Hops are balanced well with the malts and then you pick up the mild citrus and fruit goodness. Lite to medium body...hops and zesty carbonation hit your tongue first. Goes down easy leaving dry hops on the tongue and a mild alcohol warmth. An A-list beer for sure!

For mainstream beer drinkers, a balanced beer is midpoint between hoppy and malty with none of the distinguishing characteristics of either (read Bud etc.).  For beer enthusiasts, a well balanced beer expresses notes across the beer spectrum: malty without being syrupy, hoppy without being bitter, fruit notes without being fruity and full bodied without heaviness.  Pliny the Elder is a beer that I have heard about for some time.  Unfortunately (not really but for the sake of this post yes), I live on the East Coast in an area where the distributers are not interested in brining it in (read Philistines).  Luckily, Gary at Blackwells in San Fransico stocks Pliny along with a whole assortment of other treasures and he ships pretty much everywhere.  I got ahold of some Pliny recently and sampled it room temperature, slightly chilled and very cold.  I like my beer very cold but I find that it is worthwhile to try it at different temperatures to look for changes in tonal balance and see if different notes predominate.  Pliny was well balanced throughout.  Obviously, the notes were more muted when chilled but no particularly actor hogged the stage.
