I was (and still am) impressed by the mellifluous choice of hops, the grapefruit-like citrus quality and subtle malt, backing up the chorus like a smooth baritone.  In short, this s*#t rocks!  Dont wait for a friend or your parents to bring this back from summer vacation instead of a truly forgettable t-shirt.  Find a vendor and get it shipped!

Pours gold with a big foamy head.  Grapefruit, oranges, grass, and bread aromas.  The flavor was well balanced between sweet malt and hoppy citrus bitterness.  Grapefruit, oranges, and grass flavors.  Rich creamy mouthfeel with a bitter finish and a slightly sweet aftertaste.  Pliny the Elder was on my "bucket list" of beers and it did not disappoint.  I would like to thank my Mom and Dad for hunting it down for me on a recent trip to Colorado.

Very anticipated beer.  Finally got my hands on a bottle while down in San Diego.  Bold flavors.  Definite pine/citrus aroma.  Flavor holds up and even improves after multiple sips.  Probably even better on tap.

Ive had this beer enough times to know what Im going to rate it, but I am still amazed every single time I have a glass not by the pungent aroma from the moment the cap comes off the bottle (or the tap handle is pulled) but by the majestic beauty of this beer.  Im not a big believer in appearance being even half as important as smell or taste, but PtE is just a sticky monster that looks unbelievable.  Nose is dank, oily hops with a dominant focus on resinous pine scents but also citrusy and even slightly tropical flavors.  The taste follows perfectly behind the nose, a wave of layered fruits and forests with an ever so slight malt crispness to give the beer a perfect roundness and prevent an overwhelming bitterness.  Mouthfeel is full and sticky.  Drinkability is off the charts.  Pliny is the benchmark by which I measure all other beers, the beer which I would most like to have on tap at my local or stockpiled in my fridge.  It is beer nirvana, and it was the perfect beer to revisit for my 200th rating.  It started my obsession, and it will continue to be a part of my obsession for the rest of my life.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2011 From notes compiled on a recent trip to northern California: Rating Pliny the Elder provides me with insight into what it must be like to be a congregational minister. People have been expounding on the Christian scriptures for 2000 years. What, exactly, does any given minister on any given Sunday have to add to that voluminous commentary? All I can say is that this beer tastes like what god would drink on a visit to the Bay Area. The body is so satiny that you almost forget you are drinking anything at all, and the aroma and flavor blend so seamlessly that you forget that smell and taste are allegedly distinct senses. My only complaint is that I cant get this anywhere close to home.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2011 500ml bottle from Whole Foods in West Hollywood. Pours a murky orange amber with a decent and lasting head. Aroma is a powerful burst of herbal hops, with a wonderful balance of malts. Extremely smooth and wonderfully balanced. The carbonation is there, and it’s fairly thick, but almost feels as if nothing is in your mouth but a burst of flavour. Has yeasty notes of a Belgian saison-style ale, with (obviously) plenty of hops and the malts to counter. Also notes of grapefruit and light brown sugar. Truly great.

Bottle. Pours a deep orange golden color with an inch of fluffy white head. The aroma is an intoxicating blend of orange citrus, grapefruit, herbal hops and pine. The taste closely matches the aroma and begins with potent grapefruit and tangerine citrus flavors followed by bitter, resiny hops and pine resin. The malt backbone perfectly balances out the complex hops and citrus characteristics. The overall flavor effortlessly captures the essence and flavors of the hops in subtle ways without over-powering the taste buds. Its smooth, intensely hoppy and incredibly flavorful. Without a doubt the best Double IPA on the planet.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2014 Tasted on tap at Cafe Vino in Fort Collins, CO.  Served in a pint glass.  Pretty good sized pearl head head with a light yellow/yellow/orange appearance.  Piney, bushy hop bouquet in the head.  Incredibly smooth IPA with tons a flavor.  The hop flavor is delicious and leaves a piney bitterness on the tongue after the finish.  Full of delicious flavor and an amazing after taste.  Absolutely no hint of the 8% ABV.

Pours golden amber with one finger head and thin lace. Nose of pine, spice, pineapple and resin. Taste of walnut, oak, orange and bread. Full bodied and well balanced. 

Vinnie, we need this on the east coast. I could drink this every day!

Fantastic aroma of hops and malts. Not much on head, pretty good orangy colour. The flavour has so many layers! hops and sweet malts are perfectly balanced. The palate is also well balanced with bubbles, malt, hops. Very nice, this one is great!

Pint Bottle. Pours a nice golden color with slightly off white head that had a nice staying power. Hoppy aroma was quite evident, although some malty breadiness was also detected. Great hop taste mixed with pine, grapefruit, additional citrus as well, some honey?? Nice mouthy feel and a great finish. Excellent brew!

500 ml bottle.  Pours a golden amber with an inch tall white head that leaves a large amount of lacing on the glass.  Smell is strong of citrus and piney hops with a little bit of the malt coming through.  Taste is strong with citrus and pine hops  With just enough malt and a bit of bready yeast to balance it.  Very little trace of the 8% alcohol.  Medium mouthfeel. Light carbonation.  Fantastic beer.

Tried 4 bottles and one draft in San Diego.

A-Hop aroma is up front with grassy, citrus hops. Light malt. No alcohol or diacetyl.

Ap-Golden color. Medium head with great amazing lace.

F-Light malt with complex citrus, bitterness from hops. Nice balance with slight pleasant bitter aftertaste. 

M-medium body. Medium carbonation. Low alcohol

Overall: An amazing example of a double IPA. I wish more were shipped to Colorado!! One of my favorites.

Bottle courtesy of Hophead22. I love to share great brews, but this is one I selfishly wish I had kept to myself instead of splitting with 5 others at a tasting because it was so insanely good. I wanted to huddle with it in the corner muttering about "my precious". Very tropical sweetness with just an insane hop flavor that manages to keep bringing you back for more without insane bitterness. Just so good.

Bottle, bought at Cracked Kettle, thanks so much for selling this, two months aged so not as fresh as I had liked and the hops had definitely dried out a little which makes me feel REALLY bad for rating it, especially in the intoxicated state I was in after imperial stouts at the biere temple, Amsterdam.

Bottle, shared with Reakt . Wow. What an amazing appearance. This is BEER PORN. The appearance is perfect.  gold, excellent lacing, excellent clash of orange and gold, really awesome..Carbonation is perfect for an IPA.. The beer itself is very citric, felt pines, some oranges, fruit, a really nice blend and apart from slightly dry hops was amazing. Sooo sorry for this lame rate but Ill try and amend that. Please try and send a keg to the uk,

Pliny the Elder.  The word legendary comes to mind.  Russian Rivers famously hopped IPA has been out of reach for me, at least until now.  A recent excursion to Denver for the GABF yielded a surprisingly bountiful harvest, including a fresh bottle of the Elder.  To say Im excited about finally getting the opportunity to sample this beer would be an understatement.  In many respects, I feel like Ive been waiting my whole life to try this brew.  

Lets get out snifter for this one, it seems appropriate.  Pliny pours a dull gold, with a very nice head that immediately billow up before recedeing, like the tides on the beach.  Shockingly (or not) the nose is pretty much all hops.  Hops hops hops hops hops.  I get some spruce notes up front.  Its this big ass pine nose that is incredible.  It tears at my nostrils like a demon from hell, determined to drag me down.  

Holy cow, this beer is incredible, just based on scent alone.  

The first sip is an assault on the palate.  You arent prepared for this.  But its not bad.  Theres bitterness, but it is pleasant.  Luckily this bottle of Pliny is super-fresh, so I get that scratchy hop characteristic of a beer that was seemingly made yesterday.  The mouthfeel is great.  Its super thick, with this great malt sweetness backing it up.  But its never syrupy.  The light carbonation lends to the overall experience and actually makes it quite easy to drink.  The Elder strikes quite a nice balance.  

Its all about the hops though, and this beer is a hop chameleon.  It seemingly changes with every sip that I take.  I get spruce pine, followed by grass, then citrus, and then flowers.  And, just for good measure, Its generic, I know, but its what I get.  This thing is a hop grenade in your mouth.  Theres a number of hops just sucking you in and then trying to claw their way out of your mouth.  The only way to really appreciate it is by trying it yourself.  Whats incredible is that the malt profile backs it up.  

Wow.  

Its like someone beamed down from another planet with the perfect IPA, and Russian River was bestowed with the recipe.  All others pale in comparison.  Holy crap this thing is fn incredible.  I didnt think I would say this but its totally worth the hype.  Im going to be having dreams about this thing.  

Yes, its that good.  

The hop character draws you in.  I havent had a beer with this kind of amazing hop flavor.  Its so fresh and delicious.  Ridiculous.  But theres a great malty sweetness that backs everything up.  Trying to describe the malt profile is like hitting a moving target  the more you zero in on the sweetness the more the hops come back up and remind you that theyre there.  Man.  Theres simply nothing wrong with this beer.  And honestly, theres only one way to think of this.  

This is the best IPA that Ive ever had.

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2010 Sampled at Falling Rock Tap House in Denver on September 16, 2010, also via a bottle at our October 2010 club meeting.  This beer is pure hop heaven.  Medium-golden orange colored body, looks dense, with a fine white head.  This lovely beverage has a dark, spicy hop aroma to die for with a comfortable malt presence. Very well-balanced.  Hop-hop-hop fresh... doses and doses of hop divinity.  Wow... for how dense this beer lets on in the nose this is a very easy, very light-palated beer.  Yeah, this beer goes down easy... too easy.   Crazy, very smooth, non-offensive, totally awesome hop profile.  This beer almost defies words.  Yep, its one of those beers.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2014 Poured a gorgeous yellow with a white bubbly head.  Took me and my friends several minutes to catalogue the aromas: pine, grapefruit, banana, and fresh sweat on a clean t-shirt.  Flavor was intense and ponderous.  Was it intensely hoppy and full of pine?  Yes.  Was it that simple?  Goodness no.  This was the most complex and intriguing pine-hops flavour I ever encountered.  Of course it also featured some flowery and grapefruity tones, which Im sure helped the subtle complexities.  It was recognizable without being familiar.  For me, there wasnt enough of a malt balance.  The low carbonation and somewhat creamy mouthfeel were nice touches, but in the end, I felt it was too imbalanced.  Im super glad I had the fortune of trying one, but if I had the opportunity, I wouldnt buy another.------- RERATE------holy amazeballs this is a great beer.  Admittedly I only had a sip from a friends glass, but it blew my hair back.  I dont know if my first Pliny was a mediocre bottle or if I just didnt appreciate hops then, but...wow.  Sweet, floral bitter, gorgeous orange zest and caramel malts.  Really complex while still sweet and floral bitter.  And smelled like a charm.

Bottle from Cracked Kettle, Amsterdam. Pours unclear golden with a big frothy off-white head. Aroma of citrus and pine, also some light caramel. Taste is strong malty, dark caramels, but first and foremost , in the driver seat, The Hops, with its strong presence dominate this show, taste like a pineforest with some citrus in the background. Full bodied. Alcohol is well hidden amongst the hops. Dries up towards the end, a very good beer indeed-lovely.

On tap at Toronado. Golden blond with thin foggy head. Aroma is citrus, resin, flowery hops. Medium body with a low carbonation and a refreshing taste. In mouth its citrus, flowers and a small nice bitterness. Good But not excellent.

Piney aroma from the beer smoke when bottle first opened. Hazy straw gold body  no real cap. Aroma seems pretty standard sweet peach hops and a caramel hop presence. Taste is much of the same but seems watery but still very intense, a lingering bitter is destroying my face. I like the sweetness of the brew but thats all thats really standing out. I think Im missing something from this beer it was good but not great just kind of a average brew, not sure why it would be in the top 50 beers.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2011 First before you taste, youve got to sniff a beer like this and when you do pliny gives off an impressive aroma. Then you glass to lips and drink. When you do this you notice a very powerful flavour of hops but not overpowering. I agree with most that there is a pine like flavor to it. But as you drink more that flavour disapears and it becomes easier to drink. I want to have a couple more bottles before I really know what this beer is about.

Re:Rate. had this bad boy again and it is much more enjoyable now that my palet is improved. Very bitter, well well balanced. Great offering, Original :4, now 4.5

A: pours an opaque orange with some bright yellow hues. Nice frothy slightly off-white head. Outstanding head retention, seriously outstanding. Which leads to some of the most gorgeous lacing I have seen with a beer.

S: wonderful nose, great hoppy notes, mostly citrus, fresh grapefruit and solid pine resin notes. Outstanding sweet malt aromas.

T: I can see why it is so well talked about. This beer is exceptionally balanced. Wonderful hop flavors, mostly fresh, and I mean fresh citrus with a slight hint of pine. The malts make this beer, smooth and clean malt backbone, really separate this. Great flavors, very similar to Bells Two Hearted Ale.

M: clean and crisp. extremely well balanced. perfect carbonation level and just so well put together.

D: good...wait, great beer. damn near perfect, but not much gets the 5.0. Will definitely persue this beer again and again. ABV is a little high.

from old notes Hazy peach hue; white froth. Peach and cookie nose, baked apples, softly piny, sugary. Pleasingly subtle at first; then a smooth hop attack begins quickly transitioning into a strong, racy bitterness combined with a little alcohol heat. Slick texture, medium body, some alcohol thinness, full carbonation. Deliciously balanced, though perhaps lacking...something...oomph. 50 cl bottle.

i just cant.  i cant get into it - at all.  smells great-ish.  tastes strong...and hoppy.  cilantro and basil and pineapple and pine and spearmint and crayon paper. 
like a bad christmas. yeah. thats it.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2012 Location/Date:Bottle on April 29th, 2012.E
Appearance: Pours an orange clear. 
Aroma: Aroma is sweet citrus, some pine.
Taste: Medium bitterness, sweet citrus, balanced.
Palate:Medium body.
Summary: Excellent for the style, hoppy but very balanced. Thanks Dave for letting AV and I split this bottle!

It took me three years to get this beer.
Sunday afternoon I took a bus from LAX to within a mile and a half of beverage warehouse on culver blvd.  I got one of the last three bottles.  I also picked up Damnation.  A half week later I went to Hollingshead Deli in the OC where my cousin bought me a Pliny on draft.  Wow!  The ultimate IPA.  Later that evening with family I drank the bottle of Pliny.  Incredible
Poured nicely smelled very hoppy and grainy taste very hoppy with a great sticky hoppy aftertaste that stuck around

Slightly hazy bright apricot with a very light tan cap, sticky long lasting lacing in small quantities. Mmmmm... lemony, sweet grapefruit, oranges. Nice faint spice or is it spruce?, sweet caramel... a bit sweet overall a bit floral on long deep sniffs. Pretty fine tasting brew as well but nothing killer. Lemon rind mid taste, pine, tart solid bitterness, light citrus, light pepper and pretty good. Hella bitter, nice finish but did not live up to the reputation.

Thanks to my cousins for letting us try this.  Pours an amber color with a thin off-white head.  Aroma is sticky, piney hops, light caramel malts, and some earthiness.  Taste is much the same - quite chewy and earthy, and lacks some of the bright fruitiness I like to see in a DIPA.

Draught at Stone 14th Anniversary Celebration. A go-to DIPA. Aroma is a bit sweet, hoppy, pine.  Extremely bitter and dry taste that bursts with hops, grapefruit, pine again. Drinks like a single IPA but with the double IPA flavor, i.e. this beer will surprisingly not burn out your palate - its that smooth.  Astringent long-duration bitter finish. A classic.

Courtesy of dpjuart at his Thirty Beers for Thirty Years.  Pours a golden-orange with a thin off-white head that diminished quickly. Amazing aroma of grapefruit and pine. The initial flavor is an incredible taste of grapefruit, orange and pine. Well balanced by the biscuity sweetness of the malt. Very smooth.  Full bodied. Medium carbonation. Lingering grassy finish. Very nice. Thanks Mr. dpjuart !

Finally got to try this thanks to my cousins.  Pours a amber color with thin off-white, fizzy head.  Aroma is of of citrus and piney hops with a light note of caramel malt.  Taste is citrus and piney hops with some light lemon and big caramel malt backbone.  Alcohol is well hidden and the mouthfeel is clean and complex.  This was a big let down.  I really think the score on this one is mostly hype because I just didnt care for this at all.  If you want an DIPA done right, try Hopslam instead.

Golden pour with a finger-high white head that settled into a small layer that leaves some lacing. Aroma is powerful pine, with some citrus, but really a lot more balanced than I assumed it would be, with some malt sweetness pushing through. Same on the taste. Complex... pines and citrus, some sweet malt, a bit of alcohol. Pretty complex. Getting more pineapple as it warms.  Great big bitter on the finish.

Lives up to its reputation. This is one fine IPA. For those that have had Three Floyds Dreadnaught (or maybe even Moylans Hopsickle)... this is pretty similar. The guy at Midtown had told me that when he recommended the Hopsickle. Huh... I guess Ill have to give his opinions more stock than I have thus far...
Bottle, SF Embarcadero Market. An immediate huge hoppy aroma, oily and rich in both smell and taste. Beautifully smooth, full bodied and bags and bags of flavour. Outstanding.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2013  Of course It is well done, it has a great hops smell and a pretty nice bitterness. You can drink this very easily. But it lacks of madness. Too classic for me. It  just didnt blow my mind compare to others West Coast IPA which dont have Plinys reputation

Clear and just slightly orange-small white head. Nose is so nice and sweet with pineapples peaches, tangerines, and just rich hops. Taste is richeous,- taste is very balanced with just a little malt huge fruity, citrus hops. Some bitterness lasts through the finish. Very nice and my rating us not required to determine this. So balanced.

Not far behind the Younger. A little less alcohol but nearly equally amazing.  

Apparently more available than the Younger, although I havent noticed it.  Both went extremely quickly when they came to Philadelphia a few months ago.

Pours a cloudy golden orange with a thick white head. Heavy pine aroma with some wonderful floral and citrus notes. Tons of flavors. Grapefruit, lemon peel, lots of hops. Slightly bitter, but the malt balances the taste perfectly. Fresh, clean, just a joy to drink. Probably my favorite DIPA.

bottle, huge thanks to Allen! Clear, perhaps slightly hazy deep golden colour, large white head. Duperb aroma of fresh hops, incredible. Full-bodied with a perfect malty base and lots and lots of fresh hops with a citrusy-resiny character. Orange marmalade and lemon zesz come to my mind, as well as fresh grass. The carbonation is perfect and supports the flavours very well. An incredibly good beer! Thank you very much, Julian!
Citrus hop aroma. Amazing.  Balanced hop and malt with long lasting bitterness.  Awesome.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2011 This is my third dance with Pliny and Im still lovin this stuff.  Bottle 7/14/10, so its less than three weeks old.  That being said, this beer needs to enjoyed in the Bay Area, or better yet at RR.  The color is a clear golden yellow with a nice frothy white head.  The citrus and hops waft through the air and engage the senses.  The taste is fantastic, big piney, citrusy, hops explode on the palate with just enough of a malt backbone to keep scoliosis from setting in.  Great balance, huge hoppy characteristics, this is the mold for west coast DIPAs...........
Golden with a thin white head. Fantastic hop aromas, like youre smelling a handful of hops. Superb balance, very drinkable.  Great beer.
floral, citrus,  amber, clear, minimal head, medium bitterness, medium body, bitter,
Bottle. Golden colour with an off-white head. Aroma is grapefruit, malt, citrus, pine. Flavour is sweet, grapefruit, malt, peaches, pine , hop. Full body. Bitter finish. Nice beer.

Draught at the Whiskey Bar, Seattle. Pretty, wild, orange color with some copper and a fine head. Huge fruity aroma or citrus, pine, grass. Huge hop flavor. Almost sour, just from the hops! Lots of pine, grass, grapefruit, but not the tropical fruits I expected. Harsh-ass bitterness kicks in all the way. One of the hugest IIPAs around, for sure, with no subtlety. The huge bitterness is a bit overwhelming. Lovely in many ways, though did not quite live up to its billing.
a true hop juice with massive floral aroma of grapefruit.  hugely hoppy flavor with very gental finish, this brew contains maximum hop aroma and flavor without the biting bitterness.

light white head. honey orange color. at first nose is very hoppy then it evolves to citrus and floral notes. perfect balance of bitter hops and malt  from the front of the tongue all the way to the back of the palate.

THIS IS BY FAR THE BEST IPA AND BEST BEER THAT I HAVE EVER TASTED. THE SMOOTHEST IPA AROUND, GOOD CITRUS/GRASSY HOPPINESS ABOUT IT BUT SO SMOOTH AND REFINED. EVEN IF YOU ARE NOT AN IPA DRINKER YOU SHOULD STILL GIVE THIS BEER A GO. IF EVERYONE TASTED THE PLINY ELDER THEN EVERYONE WOULD BECOME IPA DRINKERS.

Bottle, thx a lot my friends. Its a clear, golden beer wtih an off-white head. Citrus and pine cones on the nose, quite low on malty scents. Theres some beefstocky malts in the flavor, a hint of caramel and loads of hops giving a pleasant bitterness and citrusy, resiny hops. Full-bodied, slightly warming and with a pleasant alcohol level. Quite dry in the end, with a lovely bitterness to match the dryness, and also a faint note of metal. A beer so lovely I almost forgot my notes. Pure pleasure in a bottle. 100409

Pours a nice slightly dark golden, thick frothy white head with good retention. Very strong floral hop aroma with some hints of the malt sweetness. Hop flavor and bitterness dominate the tongue, once again a decent hint of sweentess. Low carbonation that builds on the side of the tongue, slick, pretty bold body.

Bottled on 05/17/2010.  Served from bottle into a Duvel tulip.  Pours hazy golden orange with a three finger frothy white head that settles to one finger very slowly leaving nice lacing down the glass.  Maintains excellent lacing throughout.  The aroma is comprised of malt, hops, tangerines, and pineapples.  The flavor is of fruit, malt, with a nice subtle hoppy bite upon swallowing.  It is medium on the palate with high carbonation.  Overall the hype is to be believed.  This is an EXCELLENT brew all the way around.  The aroma and flavor of this one is epic.  I would love to drink this one super fresh for sure.

Bottle. Have been drinking this for years but never put down a rating. Pours hazy deep golden with dense small head, lots of lacing forming almost immediately. Nose is close to what I imagine the bouquet of the perfect beer being - highly fragrant - flowers, jasmine, lemon zest, orange zest-  but with a noticable piney hop resin depth and some strong nutty-caramel malt aromas back there as well. Flavor has enormous depth, lots of layers of hop resin emerge from start to finish- different pine, citrus fruit and mildly bitter orange peel. A toasty maltiness that gives it a nectar-like palate holds the whole thing together. A modicum of bitterness lingers, mingling with pleasant alcohol notes. Long live Pliny!
Great sweet fruity aroma, tastes of citrus and hops, apricot, well balanced malt/hops, perfect IPA2 body, fruity finish, perfect mouth feel.

Bottle thanks to Scott! Poured a clear gold with slight amber hue and a white head that dissipated rather quickly to the edges. Aroma was full of pine notes with a nice underlying sweet grain/bread. Flavor was similar with beautiful pine hops and a bit of grass with some sweeter grain notes coming in toward the finish. Great feel on the tongue.

Golden amber color with foamy white head which sticks around. Good lacing. Big citrus aroma with grapefruit, pineapple, maybe mango. Great body with good translation of the nose to the mouth. Very well balanced. Alcohol is present but situated well in the background. Malt is there but not sweet. Very good beer. Very good. Similar to Alesmith Yulesmith and Sculpin. Those three are clearly at the head of my class.

500ml Bottle via trade with gorditoabd (thanks Chris). Bottle date 6/30/10. Pours a crystal clear orangy golden color with minimal head and lacing. Superb aroma of nectar, tangerine, grapefruit and pine. Some of the breadiness from the yeast also blends in the aroma.  Body is smooth with soft carbonation and decidedly oily. Flavor is very balanced with sweetness from the hops, medium acidity and some caramel from the malts. Overall one of the best Ive had in this style.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text:
500 milliliters bottled on 5/26/2010, served into a 12 ounce brandy snifter, drank at 50 degrees and 55 degrees. Received via phone order from a California store.

Vision
Poured in low light in my front room. It appears at first to be an aged honey color with one finger of snowy white head. When held up to a light source it shifts to the color of movie theater butter while holding its virgin white head. The lacing is truly something to be admired in this brew. It defies gravity on the edges of the snifter and pleases me as I agitate for the bouquet. Long after it has been consumed, a lacing exists around the glass.

Bouquet
Upon first breath it holds a mysterious sweetness that is missing in most double IPAs Ive seen. It takes a second attempt to identify tangerines. The citrus is unique as of this date for my smelling pleasure. There are brief hints of pine but only when searching for more.

Flavor Profile
The smell was not misleading me. Citrus flavors explode initially on the palate and lead me to believe there is tangerines in my brew. They fade appropriately leaving a finish that starts hinting of pine, but quickly erupts into a mouth of tree branch.

The close is like walking through a winter forest looking off into the distance. Calm, quiet, clean. Everything is as it would seem. You notice the snow on the trees around you, but unfortunately you missed that tree branch that just rammed itself into your mouth. A quick punch of pine before it goes down the hatch making you wonder if it was really there as you continue staring at the scenery.

It is not a clean finish, but its damn close. The bitterness lingers pleasantly but does not overwhelm. I welcome it to play with my taste buds. All flavors blend well and play at their allotted times sip after sip. There is no one note, but a grand symphony.

Oral Sensations
When it comes to mouth feel I wasnt expecting the enjoyable body that Pliny has. It flows and lays its gentle head upon my tongue, but after swallowing it only lingers for a moment. The feel is exactly as it should be.

Closing
It is one of the most drinkable DIPAs as of date. No problem consuming the entire bottle solo, and would drink another if desired.

As a double IPA, it is most certainly a pleasant experience but not my favorite one. Bias and hype may have raised my hopes too much for this beer, but that does not mean it didnt come close to meeting some of them.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2016 Reviewed from notes (2007).

A:  Hazy orange-amber in appearance .. minimal head (note.. these were in small sampler glasses)

S:  Bold piney hops, hints of citrus and a nice malty caramel base can be made out.

T:: Mirrors the aroma profile rather perfectly.. the piney hops are delicious, with a bit of complexity and distinctive notes in there ... didnt get much of a sting from any alcohol which was a nice treat

M: Tingling on the tongue.. while this beer is in your mouth, you know it.. as soon as you swallow the taste crisply and cleanly fades.. leaving a very refreshing feel that makes you want more...

O:  Yeah... this beer is heavenly if you like good clean refreshing hops

Bottle from La Bodega in Riverside, CA.  Traveled in my suitcase back to Milwaukee.  Citrus aroma is a little lighter than expected, but excellent just the same.  Pours a crystal clear amber, with excellent lacing.  Light on the palate, and and excellent hop flavor.  This beer lives up to the hype in my opinion.

Appearance- Nice golden copper color with a descent size white, fluffy head. Lacing was present and stayed throughout the life of the beer.

Smell- Pine. Straight up pine trees. Also has notes of citrus(oranges and grapefruit) and a pleasing maltiness.

Taste- Imagine running through a forest, lets say your being chased by a monster or something(I know, just follow me here ok), and all of a sudden BAM you run right into a bushel of pine tree branches and it all gets into your mouth. Got it? Ok it tastes like that. A pine tree Mike Tyson punch to your mouth. Once you get past the pine tree extravaganza you get a nice hint of citrus and herbs.

Mouthfeel- A little lacking here. It was a bit thin and watery. The carbonation is medium which is nice.

Overall- As DIPAs go I would say this is one of the best Ive ever had. At 8% it makes for a very drinkable beer and Im extremely excited to have been able to try it. Big thanks go out to my boy Devon who brought this back from his trip to Napa.

Finally got to try one, thanks to the ELF for bringing it across country for me.  

Pours and unimpressive golden yellow, great huge hoppy aroma.  I think that the particular beauty in this one is that it has a big hoppy character, but is amazingly smooth to drink.  Wont obliterate your tastebuds like some huge west coasters...

Smells of hop, citrus, orange.  As you move in to the body it goes from hop to slightly sweet and full bodied.  Finishes very clean.

Impressive

Pours dark yellow with a white head.  Aroma of funk and citrus.  Taste is bitter with some sweetness.  Medium bodied and has a burn of alcohol on the tongue.  Excellent beer.  Hoppy, but out of balance.

This one is a home run for sure.  Golden pour from bottle with some head.  Taste and nose are bitter citrus with malty notes.  Pine and spices also linger as you finish.  One of the best IPAs available period.  The only problem is finding it if you live in certain areas.

16.9 oz bottle from Sudsy Maggie (thanks Maggie!).  Golden colored pour, big fluffy white head.  Wonderful citrus, hoppy aroma.  Flavor brings a bit more bite from the hops and also some pine notes but the citrus notes are still there.  Juicy mouthfeel.  The hops give this beer a nice bitter finish.  Awesome beer, I cant wait to try one a little fresher than this one (about 2 months old).

500ml bottle courtesy my sister from Seattle.  Bottled May 17, 2010, consumed a little over a month old.  Pours a hazy golden amber with a large fluffy off-white head that recedes nicely to a foamy island and ring.  Leaves thick clumpy rings of lacing.  Aroma is piney, citrus, grapefruit, tangerine, tropical fruits, some floral hops, caramel malt, yeast and bread.  Pretty fruity and sweet, almost sugary for a DIPA, but as it warms the pine and citrus rind really come into play.  Flavor is some nice juicy citrus, grapefruit, pineapple, pine and resinous hops, some spicy malt, a little sweetness, then an excellent lingering bitterness on the finish.  Not a whole lot of alcohol, which I like, glad this is at 8% ABV instead of 10%+ like some in the category.  Mouthfeel is pretty full, quite sticky, medium carbonation.  Ive been looking forward to finally cracking open a Pliny, and this was a real treat.  Really runs the gamut on flavors and evolves a lot as it warms.  Excellent stuff.

Bottle pour to tulip glass gives clear orange-yellow color with frothy medium white head.  Aroma pine and grapefruit.  Taste matches aroma, very hoppy but as others have said balanced well with sweet malts.  Finish surprisingly light though fairly long-lasting.  Palate a touch syrupy and bubbly.  Quite an amazing beer in its balance but not really my style.

This beer does not disappoint in the face of its high reputation.  Unlike a lot of other hop-bombs on the market, this beer has a very strong malt profile to complement the ~100 IBUs.  Additionally, this beer is very drinkable, and does not weigh heavily on the palate.  Definitely worth the effort to find this awesome brew.
Pours a murky gold with a white head.  The smell is sweet, citrusy hops.  The taste is outstanding as well with sweet, bitter hops all around.  A great beer for a nice sunny day.
Its been awhile since I have this beer but I remember being less impressed than my expectations.  I will have to rate this one again one day.

Nice golden color with a medium white head...great lacing and 
retention.  Aroma is smooth grapefruit with a hint of spice and a
touch of pineapple. Great flavor!  Sweet pineapple, touch of 
grass and maybe pils malt then loads of grapefruit and some
spice.  Lively mouthfeel and a lingering dry grapefruity finish.  
Everything it was billed to be...awesome!

I had a Pliny that was over four months old the other night and one that was less than two months old tonight. Let me tell you, when Vinnie says to drink this beer fresh hes not kidding! Im not saying that the older one was bad, as a matter of fact it was still better than a lot of fresh IIPAs. However, this beer is made to drink early as the label states. Aging doesnt do this beer justice. That being said, the citrus and floral hop aromas that creep out of this beer are tantalizing. Nice golden orange color, somewhat hazy with persistent white head and lacing. Hops over malts (bitterness over sweetness) for sure, but still a nice balance between the two. Medium body with a sticky sensation from the high alpha acids. Medium carbonation and a nice long and beautifully bitter finish. A benchmark if not THE benchmark IIPA to compare others to.

This has to be one of my favorite IPAs. On tap at Falling Rock Tap house in Denver. Have also had in bottle, must drink as fresh as possible. Very balanced IPA flavor not overpowering which makes it very drinkable. Sweetness over bitterness

Nice light beer with strong hoppy flavor, but not to the extent of an IPA. Nice aroma and finish. This beer is quite hard to find in my area and sells out quickly even with quantity limits. Definitely worth a try.
Had on tap at Lucky Baldwins. Clear looking and light gold in color. A lot of hoppy flavors to it. Very crisp and refreshing .Also, a little tangy flavor to it like grapefruit.

Sample at the brewclub meeting.   Pours beautiful amber orange with thick and firm white head.  Huge hop aroma, sweet fresh hops.  The hop aroma is so bold and aggressive that I braced for a bitter blast in the flavor but its not there.  Instead you get a silky smooth and honey sweet hop flavor.   Massive hop flavor but it goes down so easy and delicious the first sip is amazing.  Crafted to perfection for a IIPA.

Bottle/22oz. - Poured a beautiful hazy slightly orangish golden amber in color with a medium, bright white pillowy head that stuck around to produce some really excellent lacing on the glass.  Aroma was strongly hoppy, with plenty of citrus-grapefruit and pine resin flavors... and just a touch of the malts to fill in the background.  Flavor was an explosion of citrus hops, but clean and bright without some of the "soapy" taste you sometimes get with highly hopped beers.  Medium bitter and not harsh at all.  Just enough maltiness present to balance out this hoppy brew.  This beer is extremely well made and I would definitely classify this beer as "dangerously drinkable"... very tasty, goes down easy and not a hint of the hefty ABV.  As much as I liked it, given the warnings on the label about "best when fresh", I will look forward to sampling this beer from a tap and closer to the source.  A truly awesome beer!

Draft pour at Russian River Brewing. Gold-colored, clear, quarter-inch long-lasting head leaving great lacing. Citrus hops, grapefruit. Smooth, medium in body. Honey sweetness in the malt, not overly bitter - just right. Perfectly balanced. Made me smile. The perfect beer after a pretty crappy day.

On tap at Collins. Pours golden orange with a thin off-white head and a few clings. Alcohol, yeast, caramel and pine in the smell. Smooth palate. Has a lingering citrus finish but the bitterness is not overwhelming. Excellent example of a west coast IPA.

Bottle, 042910. Not quite as fresh as I was hoping, but its certainly not too bad, and its the only one I could find during a brief Colorado trip. A pleasant orange color, slightly hazy, with a nice fluffy white head and big lacing. I dont think I really have much to add regarding the aroma and flavor of this beer - its reputation stands before it. Well-balanced, although I have to imagine that its not quite at its full potential at 5.5 weeks old. Ill definitely have to stay on the lookout for a fresher one, because its been a lot of fun to finally get a chance to try this beer.

(Bottle, bottled on May 12 2010, drunk and rated on June 8 2010. Thanks Stig for bringing me this!)  Hop aroma filled my nose when I opened the bottle. Poured pale amber and lightly hazy. Head was medium sized and white. Aroma contained resin, pine, citricness, grain and malts. Palate was close to full bodied, warming and dry with medium carbonation. Flavours were hops, grass, resin, pine, citricness, malts, sweetness and bitterness. Mouth-filling taste lasted very long and was really balanced. Aftertaste was hoppy and bitter. The brewery doesn’t lie: this beer should be drank as fresh as possible.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2011 Rerate.  Bottle dated 11/17/11.  Pours a golden, slightly amber yellow with a large and thick white head which leaves chunks of foam as it laces its way down the sides of the glass.  Aroma is hops (both clean bitter and light floral), citrus, and bone dry bready malt.  Taste is balanced hop bitterness with citrus and an extremely clean and dry malt backbone (although I do get a small amount of sweetness but its more like honey than malt).  Perfect palate for the style.  There are still other IIPAs that bring the "wow" factor more than Pliny but the technical perfection of this beer makes it a marvel of the beer world.
Perfect Beer!  Make & export to Arizona, hate driving to San Diego for this!

Poured copper in color, with thin head that left a little bit of lacing down the glass.  Aroma is both hoppy and sweet at the same time. Taste is an initial caramel/fruit sweetness on the tongue and then subsides into a nice fruity bitterness: grapefruit, lemon and orange.  Great balance for an IPA, but still delivers the IPA punch. Well done.

aroma is fresh hops--just exactly like a bag full of fresh leaf hops, bursting with pine resin and pear, pineapple, mango, lots of passion fruit, and some dark muskiness and a hint of malty sweetness.
almost clear, golden orange, rocky head and nice white lacing.
flavor is, again, like biting into a handful of hop leaves--more fresh sweet hoppiness than bitterness, though the bite is there also. theres some honey, foresty sweetness, and a bit of citrus to round it out.
medium body, maybe a touch thin for an iipa, but very smooth, with a bitter hoppy finish that lasts forever.

Received this from a generous california trader. Surly Furious for PtE = happy times all around.
Pours a beautiful golden hued color with a nice big, fat white head. Slight haze. Color is a little lighter than expected but good.
Smells of cirus and pine.
Very aggressive hop profile throughout the whole experience. Excellent mouthfeel.
Bottle is coverd with DO NOT AGE warnings and I think it best to heed this warning. I get much more hop from this and less malt flavor compared to most other IIPA and dont think that letting the hop profile decrease with age would be very good.

Had on tap in a tulip glass. One of the times a beer truly lives up to the hype. Massive hops in the aroma and taste, as they completely coat your mouth.  Despite the relatively high alcohol and hop content, this goes down way easy. Truly one of the best beers on the planet. Hopheads owe it to themselves to have this one every chance they get!

Pour is light amber-copper with small white ringed hear around edge of glass.  Aroma is spruce, resin, pine, citrus, orange rind, and green hops. Flavor has a sharp hop bite with forest green flavors and citrusy rinds. Pretty clean finish and dry on the palate. Drinkability is dangerously high and extremely food friendly. Dear Vinnie, please expand distribution to the great old Midwest.

Growler from Capones.  Pours a slightly hazy golden amber with a pillowy white head.  Aroma is the closest thing to just rubbing hops between my hands that ive ever smelled in a beer.  Smells like pure pinecone hops with a bit of citrus.  Taste is dry and clean, with almost no sweetness, alcohol, or malt.  A great mix of overwhelming floral piney hops and hoppy bitterness, with some gentle citrus peel lingering in the background.  The floral pinecones fading and the bitterness growing the longer its held in the mouth.  The best IPA.

On tap at Capones.  It was great to finally get to try a glass of this much praised and very high rated beer.  I am glad to say that Russian River did not let me down - this is a superb IPA!  Dark gold pour with a sticky head.  Great aroma of freshly cut pine and grass.  Lots of complex hop flavor - grapefruit, pine, and something a little savory, like olive oil.  Not very malty or sweet, and reminded me a bit of the Mikkeller IPAs I sampled recently, only better.  Excellent.

A little bit fruit and some pine-yness - just your typical west coast IIPA nose. Bottled on 5/12 this is about as fresh as I could get. The hops hit you up front with freshness but the malt nicely balances out in the end. Just a really smooth drinking beer with incredible balance considering the hop bill on it.

West coast all of the way!! I wish this was more readily available in my part of the country. Resin, pine, fresh cut grass, herbs, some citrus grapefruit rind. Bitter, but in a pleasing way that a lot of big IBU bombs cant muster. Surprised to get as much malt in the aroma and flavor as I do. The light color has tricked me. Finishes clean and refreshing. Amazing...

Bottle from trade, 3 weeks old. 

Pours a classic light-amber color, clear, with a big porous head. 

Nose is huge, with honey-suckle, jasmine, peach, pine-needles, a hint of caramel.

Taste is wonderfully balanced, grapefruit and resin hops over fleshy fruit and a hint of toasty as well. 

Palate is clean, crisp, and alcohol and carbonation are perfectly balanced.

A great beer, one I would love to drink with frequency... alas....

Thank you DeadGirl!  I guess I will go ahead and be redundant and rate this as everyone else has.  The aroma of a Pliny is like an explosion of hops.  Pineapple, citrus and resin.  Its medium bodied, not overpowering but somewhat like chewing hops.  The subtle bitterness lets the hops really come through and be the center piece.  This stuff is heavenly.

Pours a clear amber in the glass. Nose is mostly citrus, some floral hops. Taste is mostly citrus with a dry hop finish. Some spices on the palate. I detect pepper and cumin or fennel seed. Good beer, but overhyped in my opinion.

Bottle. Hazy fizzy orange. Fat white head that dies a bit. Lots of hops in the nose here. Lots of grapefruit. Just pure bitter goodness. Flavor is a kick in the mouth of bitterness. Tons of fruits and pine. This is near perfect.

Pours a slightly hazy orange/golden colour with a big frothy white head that dissipates a bit. Aroma is full of hops; floral, resin and fruit; grapefruit, peach, apricot, lemon and orange peel, there are malty undertones as well. Taste is sweet and fruity up front, noticeably grapefruit but then the hops take over and it becomes quite bitter, very nice. Full body, lively carbonation and a smooth almost oily mouth feel. Overall this is an excellent beer, easily in my top three.

Appearance: pale gold to light orange depending on your room lighting. Not much lacing but lots of head retention!

Smell: Just a beautiful bouquet of floral hops, a slight grapefruit hop smell, pine, perfume, and the faintest hint of orange. Well done!

Taste: Im getting some grapefruit up front with the pine and floral qualities coming next. Finally another wave of grapefruit hits as the floral qualities subside. This is a tasty west coast IPA for sure! Really loving it. Especially because there isnt a sweet malt profile to detract from it.

Mouthfeel: Creamy, decent carbonation, with fruit sweetness from the hops balancing everything in the absence of a sweet malt profile.

Drinkability: Wonderful despite the 8% abv

Please Note: Pliny changes quite a bit as it ages and really is best enjoyed as fresh as possible. Ive sampled bottles that were 2-3 weeks old and they have extra bitterness about them that opens up in the 4-6 week age range. By about 10-12 weeks old this beer seems really degraded in my personal opinion.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-09-2008

Bottle. 

Deep golden color with a sticky off-white head that leaves nice lacings.

The aroma very intense with a big punch of exotic fruits - grapefruit, pineapple, mango, you name it. Grassy and resiny hop aromas as well, and hints of tobacco. Crisp malts underneath provides a lovely balance. 

The flavor is fairly sweet with a nice crisp maltiness of caramel beneath an abundance of hops. Hops, hops and more hops. Great juicy fruit aromas and notes of pine-needles. The finish is bitter and resiny with lingering fresh hop notes. 

Big body, smooth mouthfeel with a nice semi-dry finish. 

As far as Double IPAs goes, it doesnt get much better than this. Easy to drink is an understatement for this one.

Got this in a 500mL bottle at the horses mouth (i.e., RR brewpub).  Bottled date is a little more than a week ago.  Pliny has an incredibly natural quality about it.  The pour is beautiful, a hazy golden color.  A nice one finger head takes forever to dissipate and leaves some outstanding lacing.  Taste is very earthy with exceptional bitterness that lingers nicely.

Sharing a bottle with my wife courtesy of a trade with mobz24. Freshness date indicates bottled on 042310. Served in a large Belgian style tulip glass. Clear golden color, lots of bubbles rising up from the bottom, good sized creamy white head with some lacing. Wonderful piney and pineapple aroma truly makes this beer.  A bit average bready cracker-like taste up front that turns into more of a citrus flavor. The beer wows you at the end with a burst of intense hoppiness in the finish. Somewhat piney and grapefruity, the taste lingers in the mouth for a long time. Very nicely carbonated and medium bodied. Very smooth and refreshing -- 8% ABV is well hidden. Going to need to round up some more Southern Tier to ship to CA -- I can get used to drinking this. Its not overpowering like a Hopslam or Nugget Nectar -- but rather crisp and smooth.

500ml.  Poured into a little beer taster.  ZOMG the aroma is amazing.  Its like a hoppy pineapple.  The flavor is perfectly light and sweet and citrusy and hoppy.  Its a good medium body, not too syrupy.  This beer is wonderful.

Bottle from the Cracked Kettle, Amsterdam. Been looking forward to this one. Hazy golden-orange pour with a white head. Aromas of pineapple, oranges, tangerines, pine. Flavours of baked apple, lime, pineapple, lemon peel, peaches. Very sharp hop kick. Pleasant underlying sweetness. Lingering bittersweet mouthfeel. Very well balanced. Full on hoppy, bittersweet finish. Exceedingly refreshing. 
 Very impressed, worthy of its world class tag.

Nice golden orange color with a billowy white head. Great nose of grapefruit and other citrus.
Hops jump out of this beer with nice malt backbone. Palate follows through with continued grapefruit.

On tap at Falling Rock Taphouse.  Fresh lemon and pilsener malt on the nose.  Citric acids are the first and last impressions.  Starts lemony with sliding saltine-cracker malts and some dark grain in the middle, ending with a rush of bitterness and more citrus, both of which linger long on the tongue.  The overall impression is that this is incredibly well made, but it doesnt wow in any way.  And thats not really a complaint considering how overall good it is.

(Bottled 12.8.2009) Hazy golden with a medium head and some lace. Lemony-grapegruity-piney nose. Strongly hoppy, strongly aromatic flavor with zesty lemon, some pine needles, grapefruit, a touch of woody bitterness. Medium body, surprisingly refreshing and dangerously drinkable for the ABV. Maybe slightly harsh bitterness for my taste, and maybe not at its freshest after 9 months. Still a great, balanced summer drink, like Liberty Ale squared.

Wow!  I had my brother send me a bottle of this from Colorado!  I had been reading about this beer and wondering about it.  I was very surprised by it, it is very, very good.  I know they dump about every hop you can find by the boatload into this beer but it turns out to be very nicely balanced, very good.  It pours like liquid sunshine, with a nice touch of head.  A hop forward attack, that warms to a nice hoppy and bitter finish.  Overall a wonderful beer if you can find it.

From a bottle.  Pours a hazy orange/copper.  Tons of citrus hops in the aroma with some pine, too.  Orange, grapefruit, pine, some caramel, too.  Flavor is full of the same, some caramel sweetness, and a nice bitterness.  Nice and dry finish.

Success! Ive wanted to try this shit for years and one has finally found its way to the cornfields via my man on the spot in Seattle... Pours opaque gold with a dense bulbous white head. Nose is awesome grapefruit-citrus, not that prominent but smells great. Pretty heavy mouthfeel for an IPA, something about this brew strikes me as almost saison-like, and I think its the mouth  Flavor is major citrus as well, the hops are very subdued but noticeable. Its fairly straightforward, robust and of the highest quality. Probably a top-5 IPA. Thank you Wes, you have made my day.

This may be my favorite beer of all time. I first had it at a brewfest years ago and nothing has really ever compared. I found a liquor store right down the street that carries the 16.9oz bottles and I couldnt be more excited. Russian Rivers distributors do a wonderful job of ensuring the freshest possible product makes it to their customers and in the case of Pliny the Elder is makes a world of difference. This bottle is dated at 4/5/10 and was poured into a tulip glass. The color is a cloudy golden amber, reminiscent of a Belgian tripel. A rich foamy head arises and it retained with fine lacing. The smell is gloriously fresh and floral hops with enough of a citrus-like honey sweetness to again remind me somewhat of a tripel. The wonderfully bitter hops on the palate are balanced with an interestingly subtle malt that gives the taste an orange peel quality to it. The fresh and resiny hops linger through the finish so much so that its almost like Ive been chewing on a mouthful of them. The carbonation is spot on, giving it exceptional mouthfeel and allowing the full and glorious flavor of the beer to be spread broadly across the palate. Everything combines to make this a beer that beckons to be sipped deeply and savored. I really tried to think of a way this beer might be made better and the only thing I could come up with was if it was on tap fresh at the brewery. I may be somewhat biased because this is my favorite style but I have had enough regular and imperial IPAs to say this one clearly trumps them all.

Allright... FINALLY reviewing this one... sipping on a pour from a 4 day old growler hooked up from my new buddy baker (wavers1) out inn Cali (thanks again dude!!!)

Pours a very clear and  light golden color with a nice small fluffy white head.  The smell is VERY nice - slight sweetness with some pine and a hint of citrus.  the flavor matches the aroma nicely, but finishes with a very solid amount of bitterness.  Not TOO bitter mind you, but juuuust the right amount - very well balanced with none of the flavors overpowering the others.

This is an incredibly drinkable & tasty beer, but my own personal preference leans more towards DIPAs like Surly Abrasive and Bells Hopslam.  Not trying to knock this one at all, but the fruity & sweet aspects of those two definitely float my boat a bit more.

Nonetheless, this is undoubtedly an EXCELLENT beer and something I would definitely drink again.

Bottle. Pours a clear golden with a frothy white head. Aroma is pine hops on a malty background. Same flavour, but more heavy on the pine hops, and with a slight tart note. Nicely balanced. Bitter hop finish with (sweet) liquorice notes. Not a very complex beer, but well-balanced a very well made. Do want! 06-05-10.
wonderful citrus and hops fragrance grabs a hold of your nose and forces you to drink. Tight white head, leaves lacings on the glass.  Smooth mouthfeel and bitter bite that melts around your mouth.

500 mL bottle obtained in a trade at Dark Lord Day 2010. I enjoyed this bottle on 5/4 and the bottled date was 3/4 so it had been around for two months. I was extremely excited to try this one. I really enjoy a good IIPA and have heard wonderful things about this one. It pours a beautiful orange color with a one finger width white bubbly head that left awesome lacing on the side of the glass. The aroma was a wonderful mix of extremely fresh hops, coriander, pine, citrus, and flowers. The aroma was not as strong as Bells Hopslam but was very nice nonetheless. The taste consisted of a very well balanced mix of citrus, fresh hops, flowers, coriander and sweet malt. It left a wonderful bitter taste in my mouth after every sip that made me want more and more. It had a medium bodied mouth feel and was extremely refreshing. This was an amazing beer and I am really happy that I had a chance to try it! I still favor Hopslam, but this is exceptional in its own right.

Bottle shared by badnewsbeers. Hazy medium orange body, thick, puffy buff head. The nose was a delicious, potent medley of cut flowers, bubblegum, and tropical fruits, with banana, pineapple, guava, and sugared grapefruit rind. The beauty of the nose is matched by the bodys hefty punch, landing oily, resinous notes of pineapple, peach, apricot, bubblegum, and flowers with a blunt, raw, rindy, bitter finish. After reading and listening to Tylers glorious exaltations, this beer simply delivered. This is an outstanding imperial IPA.

On tap at Monks after spending 200 bucks on 2 tix for the Russian River with Vinny and his wife. The appearance is bright lemon yellow with a decent white head that dissipates quickly. The aroma of citrus hops is clear in the nose, so smooth and tempting. You get a clear smooth hop bitterness in the flavor that lingers on the tongue.
Perfect double IPA...great nose of floral hops and citrus...finish is bitter without being unbalanced...dry
Hazy orange of color with an off white head. An aroma of hops, fruits, orange, pineapple, grass and weak sweets. A flavor of grass, dry, bitter, citrus and hops - a very nice beer!!!

500 mL bottle. Acquired this beauty on DLD 2010 for a lot of other tasty beers that I had to give up, but from what I heard of Pliny, its worth it. Pours a gorgeous hazy copper color with a small half-finger high thick off-white head. Smells of an unbelievable amount of citrus, with a lot of fresh hops, some floral, and maybe some grassy smells too. For an IPA that Ive had, the only two that can compare in smell is Dreadnaught and Hopslam. So excited to finally taste this. Tastes of a lot of hops and some citrus (though not as much as I was expecting), and a nice light alcohol bite too. Not as impressive in taste as smell. Goes down smooth though, and definitely a terrific beer. Now if I can only get my hands on Pliny the Younger....

bottle into Duvel tulip
I have had this beer several times on-tap and I am anxious to see how the bottle version compares. A "Bottled on" date was the month before. Pours lemony orange with a large, fluffy, white head which settles . Lacing is elegant and lasting. Nose is pine, orange and grapefruit. Taste though, my goodness... so refreshing, so balanced. First the citrus and some bitterness hits you, but it quickly gives way to malt biscuity sweetness. The carbonation is perfect, influencing the appearance and the mouthfeel. I cant add much to the hundreds of reviews found here. This is just a GREAT beer, period

Growler from my man wavers1. Baker, thank you oh so kindly for this.  It is already one of my favorite beers, and my favorite of its style. By FAR! pours golden yellow with big buff white head. Aroma of pine, resinous hops, tropical citrus and massive fresh ruby red! A perfect harmony of florals accompanies this already massive nose. Like a bouquet of fresh fruit and flowers. Flavor is knock your socks off tropical fruit, grapefruit, florals, sugar, and sweet bread. Ridiculously fresh. Amazing job complementing the pine and bitterness with sweet malt. Everything meshes together in a perfect mouthfeel. A near perfect beer, and perhaps a perfect beer of its style. Outstanding. Superb. Brilliant.

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2014 Draft at Teresas in Wayne with Pat. Pours an orange golden body with nice crazy white lacing. Aroma is insanely delicious grapefruit. Palate is medium, with notes of citrus, grapefruit, piney hops. Of course very pine-forward.

rDev: +8.3%

Pours an amber color with a medium head that falls slowly and leaves plenty of lacing on the glass. The aroma is WOW. Hops then some hops. But there is an underlying sweetness that has a caramel character. Smells very nice. The flavor is surprisingly balanced. Lots of hop flavors, but also there is plenty of malt sweetness and caramel flavor. Im the opposite of a hop head, but this beer tastes great to me. The flavor hops arent over the top like most I2PAs. It just blends and adds the bitterness at the end. Very nice beer. The body is moderate and the drinkability is great for 8%.

Bottle-Pours radioactive translucent orange with lots of sediment and a huge frothy beige head. Aroma of delicious tropical citrus and bitter pine resin. Taste is sweet up front with a resinous background that projects forward at the finish. Perfect balance and harmony with the hops and malt. Medium body, soft carbonation. I could drink this every day especially for the price.

UPDATED: APR 24, 2010 500ml from blackwells online.  bottled 032210, drank 042110.  aroma is quite spirity lightning followed by resin and hot pine.  appearance is surprisingly pale for the style, nearly translucent gold with fine head and good lacing.  flavor is a hint spicy, big pine cone crunch and defined grapefruit and lemon burn.  big bitterness satisfies.  exactly the world class IIPA it is expected to be.

UPDATED: JUN 30, 2011 16oz draft from the Tap Room in SanDiego. Poured a golden orange color with an inch thick head. Aromas are citrus grapefruit and pine hops. The taste is pretty hop forward, just the way I like it. The malt is present but its quickly overwhelmed by the bitterness from the piney hops.This beer is an excellent IPA that pretty much lived up to the hype. I feel there are others that are better (cough Alpine Bad Boy cough) but there is no doubt this is a fantastic beer.

Bottle via trade with phaleslu, thanks alot Peter. Pours a somewhat hazy, orange-amber with a chunky, oily, slightly over 1 finger eggshell head that has decent retention. Aroma is huge on grapefruit, sweet citrus, toasty grain, light bready biscuit, nice floral notes, mixed tropical fruit, hints of toasted white bread and pot. Flavor is grapefruit, tangerine and orange citrus, sweet malt, light cereal grain, pine, some stanky pot, dusty dried grass, doughy yeast and a crisp limestone hard water note to the bitter citrus, yeast and sweet grain finish. Palate is medium to heavy bodied with a creamy entry, moderate carbonation with just enough sharpness and a still fairly creamy but drying finish. Really great IIPA, it didnt quite live up to my expectations, but I would gladly buy it if it were readily available to me.

Thanks to Dlucky for this one. My first Russian River experience. Poured into my snifter.

A-Body is a nearly crystal clear vibrant amber and some bubbles can be seen rising to the top. Pours with a one finger foamy white head that quickly subsides to a thin collar but amazingly it leaves traces of lacing all the way down the glass.

S- While the foam is still present the nose is dominated by juicy citrus (grapefruit) hops. When the foam subsides a more spicy hop can be detected.

T- Upfront is lots of almost sweet juicy citrus (mostly grapefruit). Underneath is a hint of malt. Piny hop flavors rise for the finish. It leaves a medium strength residual bitterness behind...which can be overwhelming at first...but as you sip more it becomes more of an underlying spicy compliment to the juicy citrus flavors upfront. Very well done.

P- Medium carbonation and a smooth, somewhat oily, yet light body.

O- This is an excellent DIPA. I have been dying to try Russian River beers ever since I joined BA and this is my first one. I am looking forward to their other brews. This was unfortunately gone too fast. Did I mention that the alcohol was completely hidden?

Note: This is the only beer in my top 50 I am below the rdev on.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-16-2008 21:56:46

500mL bottle courtesy of agl108.  Bottled on:  12/23/09.  A hazy, glowing orange/rust colored pour with a BIG and creamy antique white head that leaves big chunks of lacing behind.  A pungent aroma of grapefruits, pineapples, oranges, pine needles, some rye, vanilla, and a bit of caramel in the background.  A BIG syrupy body.  A good deal of sweet caramel and tangy oranges upfront taste-wise.  A touch of smooth vanilla in the middle.  Super resiny end with loads of grapefruits, rinds, and some rye.  A lingering dryness.  Mild alcohol warmth throughout.  Very nice.  Quite drinkable too.
UPDATED: NOV 23, 2010 Hazy orange color with a one finger fluffy white head.  Long lasting head with good lacing.  Evergreen and grass aroma.  Smooth palate.  Perfect blend of citrus and bitterness.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2010 (500ml bottle) Thanks to colonelforbin for this bottle! Pours a golden orange color with a nice fluffy off white head, with great lacing. Has a slightly sweet fruity/citrusy smell with mangos, grapefruit, and piny hops. Taste is lots of resiny, piny hops up front, then some light fruits, mangos, grapefruit, pears, and then ends with a nice hop bitterness. Very clean, and crisp with a light-medium mouthfeel. Overall, you cant ask for any more out of an DIPA.

Tasted from 500mL bottle, bottled on 3/26/10.  Pours a beautiful amber orange with a long lasting white head.  Nose is somewhat floral with honeysuckle, pine aroma, caramel malt, grapefruit hops.  The flavors are very clean and balanced.  There is nice grapefruit, pine resin, caramel malt, and a bitter hops finish.  The palate is nearly perfect.  Just enough coating with medium carbonation and a long, but very pleasant bitter finish.  Overall, this is an excellent IIPA.  Perhaps the best word to describe it is clean, and I will gladly drink this whenever I can get some fresh.

Bottle.

Pours a hazy orange color with a white head. The aroma was was really wonderful! Tropical fruits, citrus, hops and something sweet, wow! The taste was also very, very good! A lot of hops with some malt in the background, great balance. Wonderful palate.

Sometimes you take for granted the things in your backyard, and Pliny is one of them. You start trading and trading to see whats out there, and youre all, Hopslam is the best beer ever, then you have a Dreadnaught and your like..thats was awesome, but when its all said and done, Pliny the Elder is and will always be the benchmark for the big west coast IPA. Worthy of all the hype, this is one of the best beers in the US, and in my opinion, top ten in the world.

Bottle 50cl.Pours amber orange with a small white head.Aroma is fruity with a lot of grapefruit and citrus .Flavor is hoppy in all sorts of ways with grapefruit and citrus all over the place.A nice malty backbone.Medium body .Very very nice ipa :-)

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2012 500mL bottle, many times, pours a beautiful hazy golden with a sizable white head. Unbelievably amazing hoppy aroma, with loads of piney hops and some citrus. Flavour is omnipotent, with a perfect balance of flavours, bursting with loads of pine, balanced with loads of caramel malt. Alcohol is completely hidden and drinks like a 5% IPA. So rich and smooth. One of the best IPA/IIPAs in my books.
This was pretty satisfying. Nice hazy pour. Definitely got a strong hop character to it. Nice and bitter with pine, citrus, pear. Not the absolute best double IPA but its definitely close.
Courtesy mashmaster.  AWESOME!  This stuff really is fantastic.  Amazing balance, wonderful hops flavor and aroma. This is a stellar beer.

Tasted a 500ml bottle from Mesa Liquor & Wine in San Diego, CA.  VERY nice.  Pours a great hazy honey color; head was relatively thin on my pour, but it did maintain some medium lacing as I drank.  Everything about this beer is very bright and fresh.  A nice, grassy, fresh hop aroma, and the taste is similar, but more powerful--some slight citrus overtones on a wonderful hop flavor that has enough bitterness to be pronounced without becoming off-putting.  This beer seems medium-bodied for an IPA (maybe even has a slightly chewy feel?), but what strikes me the most is how sparkly and effervescent it feels in the mouth.  Overall, I think this is one of my favorite new IPAs, and I cant wait to try it again!

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2010 The beer looks incredible out of the bottle. Its bright and sunshiney with a giant soapy head, like a miniature carbonated bubble bath.  The smell is worth the price of admission. You know that Russian River has really bottled something special as soon as the huge floral scent hits you. Its piney, citrusy and very floral. Its just an incredible scent for a beer. Its somewhere between a dense pine forest and a field of wildflowers. The taste is similarly incredible. Its chock full of hops that taste fresh, like living on a hop farm fresh. You taste the pine and citrus and flowers that are in the nose, and theyve been translated into a great melding of beer flavor. The mouthfeel is great.  I have to hide this beer in the back of my fridge behind cartons of milk and carefully balanced glass jars, just so I wont drink it the same day that it comes home.
Bottle. Thanks to Erik och Filip. Very green mature hop aroma, herbs woody sweet grape citrus. Taste of fresch hops tropical fruits herbs pepper. Long hoppy aftertaste.

500mL bottle.  Pours a cloudy orange/light amber color with a white head.  Nose is fruity, hoppy, and sweet with lots of pine and some caramel in the background.  Palate: some initial sweetness and then big, strong hoppiness.  The hops are citrusy and powerful, but not overwhelming.  The finish is long, dry, and very bitter - but in a good way.  This beer does everything right.  There are loads of hops but they are there for a good reason and are well balanced by the sweetness and malts (unlike other double IPAs where they are just added to claim the most hoppy or highest IBUs).  A perfect beer for a hot afternoon.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2015 Pours a golden yellowish/orange with an off-white head that leaves moderate lacing. Aroma is almost perfect...orange peel, resin, pine, grapefruit and a bit of toffee. The taste is even better. I?m a huge fan of Green Flash?s IIPA, but Pliny the Elder perfects that distinct flavor profile. Too many DIPA?s have that almost syrup/cough medicine lingering affect on the palate, this one is does not. Overall, this might be the best beer I?ve ever had the opportunity to drink. Well done.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2010 Great Aroma. This is one of those beers that taste as delicious as its aroma. Pours cloudy light orange with a white head. Aromas are citrusy, piney, and grassy sweetness. Flavors are: grapefruit, orange, grassy, honey sweet and  bitter flavors perfectly balanced to perfection. Medium bodied clean and crisp taste with a sweet resiny lacing. Delicious hoppy lingering after taste. Definitely a DIPA to seek out. Awesome!

Smells like candy, cut grass, pineapple, banana, mango, sherbet. Amazing aroma. 
Flavours of green plants...? Lots of hops and fruity flavours. Delicious.
UPDATED: DEC 17, 2013 Tap. Holy crap - as of right now, this is the best DIPA I have ever had. Aroma of orange and grain. Medium mouthfeel. Taste is citrus, hop, malty backbone - just wow.

Sample @ EBF 10...What a beer.  Pours a golden orange color with a lacy white head.  Aroma is a combination of citrus and pine hops - I detected lemon, grapefruit, and bits of other tropical fruits.  Aroma is an explosion of citrus with a wonderful pine hop finish at the end.  Finish is surprisingly dry, and palate is sublimely smooth.  Incredible IPA thats equaled by AleSmith and only eclipsed by Pliny the Younger.

Bottles from bhensonb and one as a gift from a friend, cant believe I havent rated this before. Golden orange, huge rocky head, thick film coats the edges. Aroma has huge juicy citrus character, almost like the gum. Tons of apricot, mango, grapefruit and pine resin. Bready/biscuity malt background, hints of honey. Again big juicy fruit flavors, good amount of pine resin, some honey malt sweetness through the middle, decent amount of spiciness near the finish. Well attenuated, finishes fairly dry considering everything going on. Not really a hophead, and would most likely score higher if I was in a hoppy mood. Very solid, regardless.

Bottle.Shared by Owen. Pours a slightly hazy golden orange. Dense white head with some lacing. Huge fresh hop aromas of pine and grapefruit. Not much else but man this is about as good as it gets. Flavour is not quite as bitter as expected and there is some malt sweetness to balance the hops. Very dry finish with some resiny hop bitterness. Mouthfeel is just about spot on. Very easy to drink given the alcohol content. Great beer

Wow finally I am about to try Pliny the Elder.Thank you Tim(my bro) from Seattle.Pours a golden cloudy amber with a vibrant white head.Nose is piney citrus hops that are the same with the mouthfeel!This is a supreme IPA that deserves its legendary status...but not the "greatest ever" status.LOVE THIS BEER but its top 20 not top 10...Dont get me wrong though I am feeling this beer 4 real though!!

Draught. Hazy golden with a decent white head. Lovely floral hop aroma. Medium body, light carbonation. Nice balance of hops and fruitiness (pineapple, lychee) with a decent hoppy bitter finish. A very well balanced IPA.
Bottled 02-01-10. a very hoppy beer with some balance and depth. very easy to drink at 8% and 100 IBUs. a bit pricey and hard to come by but definitely worth it.

500ml bottle dated 3/4/10.  Had many bottles and pints of this, but I suppose its time to rate it.  This bottle pours a bit more hazy than others Ive had.  Deep golden with uniform white head and tons of great lacing.  Nose is right in my wheelhouse with tons of resin, citrus and light sweetness.  The haze on this batch is giving a bit more body feel compared to other batches Ive had...Im digging that.  Carb is tight and prickly as always.  Sweet honey and bitter citrus notes up front.  Sharp peppery and grassy bitterness in the mid palate...sweetness and bitter then both take turns popping out moving into a perfect amount of bittering to finish.  Doesnt rip the enamel off your teeth or just punish your palate, but let you know you are drinking a iipa.  Not much more to say that hasnt been said already.  I will just add that this is better than younger and that the huskies are going to beat marquette; know that!
its a grapefruit hop explosion. golden hue not yellow. do not let this beer go warm to cold after first chill completely diff beer.

Pre ZBF Brussels.

Didnt understand the hype around this. It is a not memorable dry and crisp beer. I guess european tastes and american ones makes the difference. This ones clearly not for me

Beautiful hoppy floral smell and amber cloudy color. Simply a fantastic work of art. Id recommend the elder above the younger simply because of the availability. At least you could conceivably order a second glass of the elder whereas its one younger for you sir!

Enjoyed from a 16.9oz bottle in a whiskey snifter.  The beer pours a slightly-darker-than-straw-colored yellow hue, with a small but long-lasting white head.  Strong and complex notes of west coast hops to the nose.  The palate is initially quite bitter, carrying notes of grapefruit and pine.  Following is a slight note of malt character; but what seems to set the beer apart is its dryness.  This is especially evident when the beer is sampled alongside another double IPA, such as Bells Hopslam.  The finish is dry and clean, making the beer tremendously drinkable, for its heft.  Overall, a splendid experience.  There is little doubt why it is so heralded.

Bottle.

A - Hazy golden orange with a good sized white, foamy head.

S - Big fruity hop smell. Lots of grapefruit, pineapple, orange, and just a little lemon. Good amount of pine too.

T - Similar to the smell. Lots of hops, grapefruit, pineapple, orange, lemon, pine, as well as some floral and other earthy flavors. Considering all this, it isnt too bitter. There is bitterness present, but there are so many other flavors it doesnt seem overpowering. The fruit flavors provide a very subtle sweetness along with some pale malt as well.

M - Medium to full body with good carbonation. Very creamy and smooth.

D - Great drinkability. Goes down easy and taste wonderful. The hop flavors work so well together and it is quite refreshing. Would love to sit back and enjoy a few, unfortunately the ABV (and at the moment availability) prevents that somewhat.

Notes: Wonderful beer with lots of West Coast type of hop flavors. Really good mix of hops that compliment each other. Also considering what it is and the amount of hops that are tasted, it is well balanced. There is a nice bitterness, but that is more in the background.

Poured from a bottle

A lite golden color with nice off white head, decent lacing. The beer smells nice and hoppy with some citrus overtones.. The taste is great, loaded with hops, lots of dry hopped grapefruit flavor. The fantastic thing about this beer is its dryness. I find most DIPAs are too sweet but not the Elder, the citrus flavors really cover the huge bitterness of this beer, which is so dangerously drinkable. Cheers to Vinnie!

thrown in as an extra from BAs PeprSprYoFace, you rock!  pours hazy gold with off-white head that leaves a good amount of lacing on the glass.  nose is typical hops, citrus and bready aroma.  taste is hoppy yeast and a little citrus that fades to dry.  i agree with other reviews, there is a little metallic aftertaste that prevents this from being my favorite ipa, but i wonder if that was from the few months in a bottle (bottled 11/14/09)?

Bottled on - 011410.

Appearance: Pours out a clear, brilliant, pale gold body with a sudsy, enduring, white head.

Smell: Quite a vibrant nose with many a perfumy aromatic - expressive notes of fresh florals, citrus oils, resinous pine, and even peaches fill the air. 

Taste: Starts with a simple introduction of extra pale malts with some cracker tones to it and a relatively light sweetness. Flavors of oily lemon peelings, pine needles swimming in sap, meadow flowers, white grapefruit, and even white peaches usher in a bold bitterness. Picks up some spicy accents on the back end. As one would expect, it finishes dry and bitter with a lingering resinous quality.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation. Has a slight oily slickness to the mouthfeel.

Drinkability: After well over a thousand reviews, Im not sure what there is left to be said. PtE is a stalwart of the style. Drinks with comparative ease considering the bold bitterness and staunch dryness, with almost no notice of the alcohol presence.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2010 A little disappointing.  Had very high expectations.  Tasted alot like my IPA homebrews with a metallicy, mediciney aftertaste.  2nd bottle from different vendor had the same problem.  A bit skunky.  Not bad, but certainly not worth the price.
great rosted hops aroma.  Hops!!!!  great taste to match the smell!  good mouthfeel but not my favorite.  not much aftertaste but a sweet undertone.  wonderful experience!!
On Tap at Capones.  Light Pine/Citrus aroma.  Golden body with thin lazing head.  Flavor is dominated by Pine/ Citrus but well balanced and made smooth by the sweet malts.  Light bitter aftertaste
This is the perfect IPA. The taste of hops, citrus, and the floral ending make this one of the best IPAs out there. It really is a perfect IPA.

Excellent, had on tap at Capones in Norristown, PA.  Pours a hazy golden hue, very similar to the Younger.  Aroma consists of pine, grapefruit and hops.  Did not sense the damp earth undertones as in the Younger.  Pine aroma is strong.  Taste is sweet at the start and bitter in the finish.  Nice creamy mouthfeel, very drinkable.  Not as intense as the Younger flavorwise, a step below.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2010 On Tap at Capones.  Of course you follow up the Younger with the Elder.  A very tasty brew.  Has a lot of characteristics that you find in 90 minute.  Complex double IPA but the sweet and bitter are very well balanced.  Is less creamy than the younger, giving you that nice harsh hop bitterness that double IPA fans presumably enjoy.
